Author: Shakespeare
Text: That you run mad, seeing that she is well:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: She's not well married that lives married long,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But she's best married that dies married young.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Dry up your tears, and stick your rosemary

Author: Shakespeare
Text: On this fair corse, and, as the custom is,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: In all her best array bear her to church:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For though fond nature bids us an lament,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Yet nature's tears are reason's merriment.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: All things that we ordained festival,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Turn from their office to black funeral,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Our instruments to melancholy bells,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Our wedding cheer to a sad burial feast,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Our solemn hymns to sullen dirges change,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Our bridal flowers serve for a buried corse,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And all things change them to the contrary.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sir, go you in, and, madam, go with him,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And go, Sir Paris, every one prepare

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To follow this fair corse unto her grave:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The heavens do lour upon you for some ill,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Move them no more by crossing their high will.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Exeunt CAPULET, LADY CAPULET, PARIS, and FRIAR LAURENCE

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Faith, we may put up our pipes, and be gone.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Honest goodfellows, ah, put up, put up,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For, well you know, this is a pitiful case.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, by my troth, the case may be amended.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter PETER

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Musicians, O, musicians, 'Heart's ease, Heart's

Author: Shakespeare
Text: ease:' O, an you will have me live, play 'Heart's ease.'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why 'Heart's ease?'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O, musicians, because my heart itself plays 'My

Author: Shakespeare
Text: heart is full of woe:' O, play me some merry dump,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: to comfort me.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Not a dump we, 'tis no time to play now.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You will not, then?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I will then give it you soundly.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What will you give us?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: No money, on my faith, but the gleek,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I will give you the minstrel.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Then I will give you the serving-creature.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Then will I lay the serving-creature's dagger on

Author: Shakespeare
Text: your pate. I will carry no crotchets: I'll re you,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I'll fa you, do you note me?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: An you re us and fa us, you note us.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Pray you, put up your dagger, and put out your wit.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Then have at you with my wit! I will dry-beat you

Author: Shakespeare
Text: with an iron wit, and put up my iron dagger. Answer

Author: Shakespeare
Text: me like men:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'When griping grief the heart doth wound,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And doleful dumps the mind oppress,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Then music with her silver sound'--

Author: Shakespeare
Text: why 'silver sound'? why 'music with her silver

Author: Shakespeare
Text: sound'? What say you, Simon Catling?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Marry, sir, because silver hath a sweet sound.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Pretty! What say you, Hugh Rebeck?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I say 'silver sound,' because musicians sound for silver.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Pretty too! What say you, James Soundpost?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Faith, I know not what to say.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O, I cry you mercy, you are the singer: I will say

Author: Shakespeare
Text: for you. It is 'music with her silver sound,'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: because musicians have no gold for sounding:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Then music with her silver sound

Author: Shakespeare
Text: With speedy help doth lend redress.'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What a pestilent knave is this same!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Hang him, Jack! Come, we'll in here, tarry for the

Author: Shakespeare
Text: mourners, and stay dinner.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: SCENE I. Mantua. A street.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If I may trust the flattering truth of sleep,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My dreams presage some joyful news at hand:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My bosom's lord sits lightly in his throne,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And all this day an unaccustom'd spirit

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Lifts me above the ground with cheerful thoughts.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I dreamt my lady came and found me dead--

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Strange dream, that gives a dead man leave

Author: Shakespeare
Text: to think!--

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And breathed such life with kisses in my lips,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That I revived, and was an emperor.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ah me! how sweet is love itself possess'd,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: When but love's shadows are so rich in joy!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter BALTHASAR, booted

Author: Shakespeare
Text: News from Verona!--How now, Balthasar!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Dost thou not bring me letters from the friar?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How doth my lady? Is my father well?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How fares my Juliet? that I ask again,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For nothing can be ill, if she be well.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Then she is well, and nothing can be ill:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Her body sleeps in Capel's monument,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And her immortal part with angels lives.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I saw her laid low in her kindred's vault,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And presently took post to tell it you:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O, pardon me for bringing these ill news,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Since you did leave it for my office, sir.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Is it even so? then I defy you, stars!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thou know'st my lodging: get me ink and paper,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And hire post-horses, I will hence to-night.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I do beseech you, sir, have patience:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Your looks are pale and wild, and do import

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Some misadventure.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Tush, thou art deceived:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Leave me, and do the thing I bid thee do.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Hast thou no letters to me from the friar?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: No matter: get thee gone,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And hire those horses, I'll be with thee straight.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Well, Juliet, I will lie with thee to-night.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Let's see for means: O mischief, thou art swift

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To enter in the thoughts of desperate men!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I do remember an apothecary,--

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And hereabouts he dwells,--which late I noted

Author: Shakespeare
Text: In tatter'd weeds, with overwhelming brows,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Culling of simples, meagre were his looks,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sharp misery had worn him to the bones:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And in his needy shop a tortoise hung,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: An alligator stuff'd, and other skins

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Of ill-shaped fishes, and about his shelves

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A beggarly account of empty boxes,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Green earthen pots, bladders and musty seeds,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Remnants of packthread and old cakes of roses,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Were thinly scatter'd, to make up a show.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Noting this penury, to myself I said

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'An if a man did need a poison now,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Whose sale is present death in Mantua,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Here lives a caitiff wretch would sell it him.'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O, this same thought did but forerun my need,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And this same needy man must sell it me.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As I remember, this should be the house.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Being holiday, the beggar's shop is shut.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What, ho! apothecary!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter Apothecary

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Who calls so loud?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Come hither, man. I see that thou art poor:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Hold, there is forty ducats: let me have

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A dram of poison, such soon-speeding gear

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As will disperse itself through all the veins

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That the life-weary taker may fall dead

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And that the trunk may be discharged of breath

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As violently as hasty powder fired

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Doth hurry from the fatal cannon's womb.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Such mortal drugs I have, but Mantua's law

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Is death to any he that utters them.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Art thou so bare and full of wretchedness,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And fear'st to die? famine is in thy cheeks,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Need and oppression starveth in thine eyes,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Contempt and beggary hangs upon thy back,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The world is not thy friend nor the world's law,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The world affords no law to make thee rich,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Then be not poor, but break it, and take this.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My poverty, but not my will, consents.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I pay thy poverty, and not thy will.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Put this in any liquid thing you will,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And drink it off, and, if you had the strength

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Of twenty men, it would dispatch you straight.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: There is thy gold, worse poison to men's souls,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Doing more murders in this loathsome world,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Than these poor compounds that thou mayst not sell.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I sell thee poison, thou hast sold me none.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Farewell: buy food, and get thyself in flesh.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Come, cordial and not poison, go with me

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To Juliet's grave, for there must I use thee.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: SCENE II. Friar Laurence's cell.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter FRIAR JOHN

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Holy Franciscan friar! brother, ho!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: This same should be the voice of Friar John.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Welcome from Mantua: what says Romeo?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Or, if his mind be writ, give me his letter.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Going to find a bare-foot brother out

Author: Shakespeare
Text: One of our order, to associate me,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Here in this city visiting the sick,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And finding him, the searchers of the town,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Suspecting that we both were in a house

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Where the infectious pestilence did reign,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Seal'd up the doors, and would not let us forth,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: So that my speed to Mantua there was stay'd.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Who bare my letter, then, to Romeo?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I could not send it,--here it is again,--

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Nor get a messenger to bring it thee,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: So fearful were they of infection.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Unhappy fortune! by my brotherhood,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The letter was not nice but full of charge

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Of dear import, and the neglecting it

Author: Shakespeare
Text: May do much danger. Friar John, go hence,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Get me an iron crow, and bring it straight

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Unto my cell.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Brother, I'll go and bring it thee.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Now must I to the monument alone,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Within three hours will fair Juliet wake:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: She will beshrew me much that Romeo

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Hath had no notice of these accidents,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But I will write again to Mantua,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And keep her at my cell till Romeo come,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Poor living corse, closed in a dead man's tomb!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: SCENE III. A churchyard, in it a tomb belonging to the Capulets.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter PARIS, and his Page bearing flowers and a torch

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Give me thy torch, boy: hence, and stand aloof:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Yet put it out, for I would not be seen.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Under yond yew-trees lay thee all along,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Holding thine ear close to the hollow ground,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: So shall no foot upon the churchyard tread,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Being loose, unfirm, with digging up of graves,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But thou shalt hear it: whistle then to me,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As signal that thou hear'st something approach.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Give me those flowers. Do as I bid thee, go.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: [Aside]  I am almost afraid to stand alone

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Here in the churchyard, yet I will adventure.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sweet flower, with flowers thy bridal bed I strew,--

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O woe! thy canopy is dust and stones,--

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Which with sweet water nightly I will dew,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Or, wanting that, with tears distill'd by moans:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The obsequies that I for thee will keep

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Nightly shall be to strew thy grave and weep.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The Page whistles

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The boy gives warning something doth approach.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What cursed foot wanders this way to-night,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To cross my obsequies and true love's rite?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What with a torch! muffle me, night, awhile.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter ROMEO and BALTHASAR, with a torch, mattock,  and c

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Give me that mattock and the wrenching iron.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Hold, take this letter, early in the morning

Author: Shakespeare
Text: See thou deliver it to my lord and father.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Give me the light: upon thy life, I charge thee,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Whate'er thou hear'st or seest, stand all aloof,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And do not interrupt me in my course.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why I descend into this bed of death,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Is partly to behold my lady's face,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But chiefly to take thence from her dead finger

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A precious ring, a ring that I must use

Author: Shakespeare
Text: In dear employment: therefore hence, be gone:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But if thou, jealous, dost return to pry

Author: Shakespeare
Text: In what I further shall intend to do,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: By heaven, I will tear thee joint by joint

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And strew this hungry churchyard with thy limbs:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The time and my intents are savage-wild,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: More fierce and more inexorable far

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Than empty tigers or the roaring sea.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I will be gone, sir, and not trouble you.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: So shalt thou show me friendship. Take thou that:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Live, and be prosperous: and farewell, good fellow.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: [Aside]  For all this same, I'll hide me hereabout:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: His looks I fear, and his intents I doubt.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thou detestable maw, thou womb of death,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Gorged with the dearest morsel of the earth,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thus I enforce thy rotten jaws to open,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And, in despite, I'll cram thee with more food!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Opens the tomb

Author: Shakespeare
Text: This is that banish'd haughty Montague,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That murder'd my love's cousin, with which grief,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: It is supposed, the fair creature died,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And here is come to do some villanous shame

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To the dead bodies: I will apprehend him.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Comes forward

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Stop thy unhallow'd toil, vile Montague!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Can vengeance be pursued further than death?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Condemned villain, I do apprehend thee:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Obey, and go with me, for thou must die.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I must indeed, and therefore came I hither.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Good gentle youth, tempt not a desperate man,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Fly hence, and leave me: think upon these gone,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Let them affright thee. I beseech thee, youth,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Put not another sin upon my head,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: By urging me to fury: O, be gone!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: By heaven, I love thee better than myself,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For I come hither arm'd against myself:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Stay not, be gone, live, and hereafter say,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A madman's mercy bade thee run away.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I do defy thy conjurations,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And apprehend thee for a felon here.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Wilt thou provoke me? then have at thee, boy!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O Lord, they fight! I will go call the watch.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If thou be merciful,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Open the tomb, lay me with Juliet.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: In faith, I will. Let me peruse this face.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Mercutio's kinsman, noble County Paris!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What said my man, when my betossed soul

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Did not attend him as we rode? I think

Author: Shakespeare
Text: He told me Paris should have married Juliet:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Said he not so? or did I dream it so?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Or am I mad, hearing him talk of Juliet,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To think it was so? O, give me thy hand,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: One writ with me in sour misfortune's book!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I'll bury thee in a triumphant grave,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A grave? O no! a lantern, slaughter'd youth,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For here lies Juliet, and her beauty makes

Author: Shakespeare
Text: This vault a feasting presence full of light.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Death, lie thou there, by a dead man interr'd.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Laying PARIS in the tomb

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How oft when men are at the point of death

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Have they been merry! which their keepers call

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A lightning before death: O, how may I

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Call this a lightning? O my love! my wife!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Death, that hath suck'd the honey of thy breath,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Hath had no power yet upon thy beauty:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thou art not conquer'd, beauty's ensign yet

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Is crimson in thy lips and in thy cheeks,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And death's pale flag is not advanced there.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Tybalt, liest thou there in thy bloody sheet?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O, what more favour can I do to thee,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Than with that hand that cut thy youth in twain

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To sunder his that was thine enemy?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Forgive me, cousin! Ah, dear Juliet,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why art thou yet so fair? shall I believe

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That unsubstantial death is amorous,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And that the lean abhorred monster keeps

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thee here in dark to be his paramour?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For fear of that, I still will stay with thee,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And never from this palace of dim night

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Depart again: here, here will I remain

Author: Shakespeare
Text: With worms that are thy chamber-maids, O, here

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Will I set up my everlasting rest,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And shake the yoke of inauspicious stars

Author: Shakespeare
Text: From this world-wearied flesh. Eyes, look your last!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Arms, take your last embrace! and, lips, O you

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The doors of breath, seal with a righteous kiss

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A dateless bargain to engrossing death!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Come, bitter conduct, come, unsavoury guide!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thou desperate pilot, now at once run on

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The dashing rocks thy sea-sick weary bark!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Here's to my love!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O true apothecary!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thy drugs are quick. Thus with a kiss I die.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter, at the other end of the churchyard, FRIAR LAURENCE, with a lantern, crow, and spade

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Saint Francis be my speed! how oft to-night

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Have my old feet stumbled at graves! Who's there?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Here's one, a friend, and one that knows you well.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Bliss be upon you! Tell me, good my friend,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What torch is yond, that vainly lends his light

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To grubs and eyeless skulls? as I discern,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: It burneth in the Capel's monument.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: It doth so, holy sir, and there's my master,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: One that you love.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Who is it?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Romeo.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How long hath he been there?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Full half an hour.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Go with me to the vault.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I dare not, sir

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My master knows not but I am gone hence,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And fearfully did menace me with death,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If I did stay to look on his intents.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Stay, then, I'll go alone. Fear comes upon me:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O, much I fear some ill unlucky thing.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As I did sleep under this yew-tree here,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I dreamt my master and another fought,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And that my master slew him.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Advances

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Alack, alack, what blood is this, which stains

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The stony entrance of this sepulchre?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What mean these masterless and gory swords

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To lie discolour'd by this place of peace?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enters the tomb

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Romeo! O, pale! Who else? what, Paris too?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And steep'd in blood? Ah, what an unkind hour

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Is guilty of this lamentable chance!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The lady stirs.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: JULIET wakes

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O comfortable friar! where is my lord?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I do remember well where I should be,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And there I am. Where is my Romeo?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I hear some noise. Lady, come from that nest

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Of death, contagion, and unnatural sleep:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A greater power than we can contradict

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Hath thwarted our intents. Come, come away.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thy husband in thy bosom there lies dead,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And Paris too. Come, I'll dispose of thee

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Among a sisterhood of holy nuns:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Stay not to question, for the watch is coming,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Come, go, good Juliet,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Noise again

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I dare no longer stay.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Go, get thee hence, for I will not away.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Exit FRIAR LAURENCE

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What's here? a cup, closed in my true love's hand?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Poison, I see, hath been his timeless end:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O churl! drunk all, and left no friendly drop

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To help me after? I will kiss thy lips,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Haply some poison yet doth hang on them,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To make die with a restorative.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Kisses him

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thy lips are warm.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: [Within]  Lead, boy: which way?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Yea, noise? then I'll be brief. O happy dagger!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Snatching ROMEO's dagger

Author: Shakespeare
Text: This is thy sheath,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: there rust, and let me die.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Falls on ROMEO's body, and dies

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter Watch, with the Page of PARIS

Author: Shakespeare
Text: This is the place, there, where the torch doth burn.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The ground is bloody, search about the churchyard:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Go, some of you, whoe'er you find attach.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Pitiful sight! here lies the county slain,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And Juliet bleeding, warm, and newly dead,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Who here hath lain these two days buried.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Go, tell the prince: run to the Capulets:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Raise up the Montagues: some others search:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: We see the ground whereon these woes do lie,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But the true ground of all these piteous woes

Author: Shakespeare
Text: We cannot without circumstance descry.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Re-enter some of the Watch, with BALTHASAR

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Here's Romeo's man, we found him in the churchyard.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Hold him in safety, till the prince come hither.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Re-enter others of the Watch, with FRIAR LAURENCE

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Here is a friar, that trembles, sighs and weeps:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: We took this mattock and this spade from him,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As he was coming from this churchyard side.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A great suspicion: stay the friar too.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter the PRINCE and Attendants

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What misadventure is so early up,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That calls our person from our morning's rest?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter CAPULET, LADY CAPULET, and others

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What should it be, that they so shriek abroad?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The people in the street cry Romeo,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Some Juliet, and some Paris, and all run,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: With open outcry toward our monument.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What fear is this which startles in our ears?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sovereign, here lies the County Paris slain,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And Romeo dead, and Juliet, dead before,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Warm and new kill'd.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Search, seek, and know how this foul murder comes.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Here is a friar, and slaughter'd Romeo's man,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: With instruments upon them, fit to open

Author: Shakespeare
Text: These dead men's tombs.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O heavens! O wife, look how our daughter bleeds!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: This dagger hath mista'en--for, lo, his house

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Is empty on the back of Montague,--

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And it mis-sheathed in my daughter's bosom!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O me! this sight of death is as a bell,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That warns my old age to a sepulchre.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter MONTAGUE and others

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Come, Montague, for thou art early up,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To see thy son and heir more early down.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Alas, my liege, my wife is dead to-night,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Grief of my son's exile hath stopp'd her breath:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What further woe conspires against mine age?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Look, and thou shalt see.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O thou untaught! what manners is in this?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To press before thy father to a grave?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Seal up the mouth of outrage for a while,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Till we can clear these ambiguities,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And know their spring, their head, their

Author: Shakespeare
Text: true descent,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And then will I be general of your woes,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And lead you even to death: meantime forbear,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And let mischance be slave to patience.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Bring forth the parties of suspicion.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I am the greatest, able to do least,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Yet most suspected, as the time and place

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Doth make against me of this direful murder,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And here I stand, both to impeach and purge

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Myself condemned and myself excused.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Then say at once what thou dost know in this.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I will be brief, for my short date of breath

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Is not so long as is a tedious tale.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Romeo, there dead, was husband to that Juliet,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And she, there dead, that Romeo's faithful wife:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I married them, and their stol'n marriage-day

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Was Tybalt's dooms-day, whose untimely death

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Banish'd the new-made bridegroom from the city,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For whom, and not for Tybalt, Juliet pined.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You, to remove that siege of grief from her,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Betroth'd and would have married her perforce

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To County Paris: then comes she to me,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And, with wild looks, bid me devise some mean

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To rid her from this second marriage,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Or in my cell there would she kill herself.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Then gave I her, so tutor'd by my art,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A sleeping potion, which so took effect

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As I intended, for it wrought on her

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The form of death: meantime I writ to Romeo,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That he should hither come as this dire night,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To help to take her from her borrow'd grave,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Being the time the potion's force should cease.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But he which bore my letter, Friar John,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Was stay'd by accident, and yesternight

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Return'd my letter back. Then all alone

Author: Shakespeare
Text: At the prefixed hour of her waking,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Came I to take her from her kindred's vault,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Meaning to keep her closely at my cell,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Till I conveniently could send to Romeo:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But when I came, some minute ere the time

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Of her awaking, here untimely lay

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The noble Paris and true Romeo dead.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: She wakes, and I entreated her come forth,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And bear this work of heaven with patience:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But then a noise did scare me from the tomb,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And she, too desperate, would not go with me,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But, as it seems, did violence on herself.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: All this I know, and to the marriage

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Her nurse is privy: and, if aught in this

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Miscarried by my fault, let my old life

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Be sacrificed, some hour before his time,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Unto the rigour of severest law.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: We still have known thee for a holy man.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Where's Romeo's man? what can he say in this?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I brought my master news of Juliet's death,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And then in post he came from Mantua

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To this same place, to this same monument.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: This letter he early bid me give his father,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And threatened me with death, going in the vault,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I departed not and left him there.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Give me the letter, I will look on it.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Where is the county's page, that raised the watch?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sirrah, what made your master in this place?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: He came with flowers to strew his lady's grave,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And bid me stand aloof, and so I did:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Anon comes one with light to ope the tomb,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And by and by my master drew on him,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And then I ran away to call the watch.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: This letter doth make good the friar's words,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Their course of love, the tidings of her death:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And here he writes that he did buy a poison

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Of a poor 'pothecary, and therewithal

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Came to this vault to die, and lie with Juliet.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Where be these enemies? Capulet! Montague!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: See, what a scourge is laid upon your hate,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That heaven finds means to kill your joys with love.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And I for winking at your discords too

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Have lost a brace of kinsmen: all are punish'd.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O brother Montague, give me thy hand:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: This is my daughter's jointure, for no more

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Can I demand.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But I can give thee more:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For I will raise her statue in pure gold,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That while Verona by that name is known,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: There shall no figure at such rate be set

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As that of true and faithful Juliet.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As rich shall Romeo's by his lady's lie,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Poor sacrifices of our enmity!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A glooming peace this morning with it brings,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The sun, for sorrow, will not show his head:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Go hence, to have more talk of these sad things,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Some shall be pardon'd, and some punished:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For never was a story of more woe

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Than this of Juliet and her Romeo.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: SCENE I. Before an alehouse on a heath.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter Hostess and SLY

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I'll pheeze you, in faith.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A pair of stocks, you rogue!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ye are a baggage: the Slys are no rogues, look in

Author: Shakespeare
Text: the chronicles, we came in with Richard Conqueror.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Therefore paucas pallabris, let the world slide: sessa!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You will not pay for the glasses you have burst?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: No, not a denier. Go by, Jeronimy: go to thy cold

Author: Shakespeare
Text: bed, and warm thee.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I know my remedy, I must go fetch the

Author: Shakespeare
Text: third--borough.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Third, or fourth, or fifth borough, I'll answer him

Author: Shakespeare
Text: by law: I'll not budge an inch, boy: let him come,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: and kindly.

Text: Falls asleep

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Horns winded. Enter a Lord from hunting, with his train

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Huntsman, I charge thee, tender well my hounds:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Brach Merriman, the poor cur is emboss'd,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And couple Clowder with the deep--mouth'd brach.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Saw'st thou not, boy, how Silver made it good

Author: Shakespeare
Text: At the hedge-corner, in the coldest fault?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I would not lose the dog for twenty pound.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, Belman is as good as he, my lord,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: He cried upon it at the merest loss

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And twice to-day pick'd out the dullest scent:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Trust me, I take him for the better dog.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thou art a fool: if Echo were as fleet,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I would esteem him worth a dozen such.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But sup them well and look unto them all:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To-morrow I intend to hunt again.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What's here? one dead, or drunk? See, doth he breathe?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: He breathes, my lord. Were he not warm'd with ale,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: This were a bed but cold to sleep so soundly.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O monstrous beast! how like a swine he lies!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Grim death, how foul and loathsome is thine image!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sirs, I will practise on this drunken man.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What think you, if he were convey'd to bed,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Wrapp'd in sweet clothes, rings put upon his fingers,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A most delicious banquet by his bed,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And brave attendants near him when he wakes,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Would not the beggar then forget himself?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Believe me, lord, I think he cannot choose.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: It would seem strange unto him when he waked.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Even as a flattering dream or worthless fancy.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Then take him up and manage well the jest:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Carry him gently to my fairest chamber

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And hang it round with all my wanton pictures:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Balm his foul head in warm distilled waters

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And burn sweet wood to make the lodging sweet:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Procure me music ready when he wakes,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To make a dulcet and a heavenly sound,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And if he chance to speak, be ready straight

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And with a low submissive reverence

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Say 'What is it your honour will command?'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Let one attend him with a silver basin

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Full of rose-water and bestrew'd with flowers,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Another bear the ewer, the third a diaper,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And say 'Will't please your lordship cool your hands?'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Some one be ready with a costly suit

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And ask him what apparel he will wear,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Another tell him of his hounds and horse,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And that his lady mourns at his disease:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Persuade him that he hath been lunatic,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And when he says he is, say that he dreams,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For he is nothing but a mighty lord.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: This do and do it kindly, gentle sirs:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: It will be pastime passing excellent,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If it be husbanded with modesty.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My lord, I warrant you we will play our part,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As he shall think by our true diligence

Author: Shakespeare
Text: He is no less than what we say he is.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Take him up gently and to bed with him,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And each one to his office when he wakes.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Some bear out SLY. A trumpet sounds

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sirrah, go see what trumpet 'tis that sounds:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Exit Servingman

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Belike, some noble gentleman that means,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Travelling some journey, to repose him here.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Re-enter Servingman

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How now! who is it?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: An't please your honour, players

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That offer service to your lordship.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Bid them come near.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter Players

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Now, fellows, you are welcome.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: We thank your honour.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Do you intend to stay with me tonight?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: So please your lordship to accept our duty.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: With all my heart. This fellow I remember,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Since once he play'd a farmer's eldest son:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Twas where you woo'd the gentlewoman so well:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I have forgot your name, but, sure, that part

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Was aptly fitted and naturally perform'd.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I think 'twas Soto that your honour means.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Tis very true: thou didst it excellent.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Well, you are come to me in a happy time,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The rather for I have some sport in hand

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Wherein your cunning can assist me much.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: There is a lord will hear you play to-night:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But I am doubtful of your modesties,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Lest over-eyeing of his odd behavior,--

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For yet his honour never heard a play--

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You break into some merry passion

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And so offend him, for I tell you, sirs,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If you should smile he grows impatient.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Fear not, my lord: we can contain ourselves,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Were he the veriest antic in the world.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Go, sirrah, take them to the buttery,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And give them friendly welcome every one:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Let them want nothing that my house affords.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Exit one with the Players

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sirrah, go you to Barthol'mew my page,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And see him dress'd in all suits like a lady:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That done, conduct him to the drunkard's chamber,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And call him 'madam,' do him obeisance.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Tell him from me, as he will win my love,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: He bear himself with honourable action,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Such as he hath observed in noble ladies

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Unto their lords, by them accomplished:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Such duty to the drunkard let him do

Author: Shakespeare
Text: With soft low tongue and lowly courtesy,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And say 'What is't your honour will command,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Wherein your lady and your humble wife

Author: Shakespeare
Text: May show her duty and make known her love?'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And then with kind embracements, tempting kisses,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And with declining head into his bosom,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Bid him shed tears, as being overjoy'd

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To see her noble lord restored to health,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Who for this seven years hath esteem'd him

Author: Shakespeare
Text: No better than a poor and loathsome beggar:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And if the boy have not a woman's gift

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To rain a shower of commanded tears,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: An onion will do well for such a shift,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Which in a napkin being close convey'd

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Shall in despite enforce a watery eye.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: See this dispatch'd with all the haste thou canst:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Anon I'll give thee more instructions.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Exit a Servingman

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I know the boy will well usurp the grace,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Voice, gait and action of a gentlewoman:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I long to hear him call the drunkard husband,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And how my men will stay themselves from laughter

Author: Shakespeare
Text: When they do homage to this simple peasant.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I'll in to counsel them, haply my presence

Author: Shakespeare
Text: May well abate the over-merry spleen

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Which otherwise would grow into extremes.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: SCENE II. A bedchamber in the Lord's house.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter aloft SLY, with Attendants, some with apparel, others with basin and ewer and appurtenances, and Lord

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For God's sake, a pot of small ale.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Will't please your lordship drink a cup of sack?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Will't please your honour taste of these conserves?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What raiment will your honour wear to-day?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I am Christophero Sly, call not me 'honour' nor

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'lordship:' I ne'er drank sack in my life, and if

Author: Shakespeare
Text: you give me any conserves, give me conserves of

Author: Shakespeare
Text: beef: ne'er ask me what raiment I'll wear, for I

Author: Shakespeare

Text: Which I have better'd rather than decreased:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Then tell me, if I get your daughter's love,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What dowry shall I have with her to wife?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: After my death the one half of my lands,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And in possession twenty thousand crowns.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And, for that dowry, I'll assure her of

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Her widowhood, be it that she survive me,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: In all my lands and leases whatsoever:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Let specialties be therefore drawn between us,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That covenants may be kept on either hand.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, when the special thing is well obtain'd,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That is, her love, for that is all in all.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, that is nothing: for I tell you, father,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I am as peremptory as she proud-minded,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And where two raging fires meet together

Author: Shakespeare
Text: They do consume the thing that feeds their fury:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Though little fire grows great with little wind,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Yet extreme gusts will blow out fire and all:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: So I to her and so she yields to me,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For I am rough and woo not like a babe.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Well mayst thou woo, and happy be thy speed!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But be thou arm'd for some unhappy words.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, to the proof, as mountains are for winds,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That shake not, though they blow perpetually.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Re-enter HORTENSIO, with his head broke

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How now, my friend! why dost thou look so pale?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For fear, I promise you, if I look pale.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What, will my daughter prove a good musician?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I think she'll sooner prove a soldier

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Iron may hold with her, but never lutes.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, then thou canst not break her to the lute?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, no, for she hath broke the lute to me.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I did but tell her she mistook her frets,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And bow'd her hand to teach her fingering,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: When, with a most impatient devilish spirit,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Frets, call you these?' quoth she, 'I'll fume

Author: Shakespeare
Text: with them:'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And, with that word, she struck me on the head,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And through the instrument my pate made way,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And there I stood amazed for a while,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As on a pillory, looking through the lute,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: While she did call me rascal fiddler

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And twangling Jack, with twenty such vile terms,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As had she studied to misuse me so.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Now, by the world, it is a lusty wench,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I love her ten times more than e'er I did:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O, how I long to have some chat with her!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Well, go with me and be not so discomfited:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Proceed in practise with my younger daughter,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: She's apt to learn and thankful for good turns.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Signior Petruchio, will you go with us,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Or shall I send my daughter Kate to you?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I pray you do.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Exeunt all but PETRUCHIO

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I will attend her here,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And woo her with some spirit when she comes.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Say that she rail, why then I'll tell her plain

Author: Shakespeare
Text: She sings as sweetly as a nightingale:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Say that she frown, I'll say she looks as clear

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As morning roses newly wash'd with dew:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Say she be mute and will not speak a word,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Then I'll commend her volubility,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And say she uttereth piercing eloquence:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If she do bid me pack, I'll give her thanks,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As though she bid me stay by her a week:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If she deny to wed, I'll crave the day

Author: Shakespeare
Text: When I shall ask the banns and when be married.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But here she comes, and now, Petruchio, speak.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter KATHARINA

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Good morrow, Kate, for that's your name, I hear.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Well have you heard, but something hard of hearing:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: They call me Katharina that do talk of me.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You lie, in faith, for you are call'd plain Kate,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And bonny Kate and sometimes Kate the curst,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But Kate, the prettiest Kate in Christendom

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Kate of Kate Hall, my super-dainty Kate,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For dainties are all Kates, and therefore, Kate,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Take this of me, Kate of my consolation,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Hearing thy mildness praised in every town,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thy virtues spoke of, and thy beauty sounded,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Yet not so deeply as to thee belongs,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Myself am moved to woo thee for my wife.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Moved! in good time: let him that moved you hither

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Remove you hence: I knew you at the first

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You were a moveable.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, what's a moveable?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A join'd-stool.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thou hast hit it: come, sit on me.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Asses are made to bear, and so are you.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Women are made to bear, and so are you.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: No such jade as you, if me you mean.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Alas! good Kate, I will not burden thee,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For, knowing thee to be but young and light--

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Too light for such a swain as you to catch,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And yet as heavy as my weight should be.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Should be! should--buzz!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Well ta'en, and like a buzzard.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O slow-wing'd turtle! shall a buzzard take thee?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, for a turtle, as he takes a buzzard.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Come, come, you wasp, i' faith, you are too angry.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If I be waspish, best beware my sting.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My remedy is then, to pluck it out.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, if the fool could find it where it lies,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Who knows not where a wasp does

Author: Shakespeare
Text: wear his sting? In his tail.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: In his tongue.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Whose tongue?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Yours, if you talk of tails: and so farewell.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What, with my tongue in your tail? nay, come again,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Good Kate, I am a gentleman.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That I'll try.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: She strikes him

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I swear I'll cuff you, if you strike again.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: So may you lose your arms:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If you strike me, you are no gentleman,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And if no gentleman, why then no arms.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A herald, Kate? O, put me in thy books!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What is your crest? a coxcomb?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A combless cock, so Kate will be my hen.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: No cock of mine, you crow too like a craven.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Nay, come, Kate, come, you must not look so sour.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: It is my fashion, when I see a crab.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, here's no crab, and therefore look not sour.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: There is, there is.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Then show it me.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Had I a glass, I would.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What, you mean my face?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Well aim'd of such a young one.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Now, by Saint George, I am too young for you.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Yet you are wither'd.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Tis with cares.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Nay, hear you, Kate: in sooth you scape not so.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I chafe you, if I tarry: let me go.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: No, not a whit: I find you passing gentle.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Twas told me you were rough and coy and sullen,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And now I find report a very liar,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For thou are pleasant, gamesome, passing courteous,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But slow in speech, yet sweet as spring-time flowers:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thou canst not frown, thou canst not look askance,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Nor bite the lip, as angry wenches will,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Nor hast thou pleasure to be cross in talk,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But thou with mildness entertain'st thy wooers,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: With gentle conference, soft and affable.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why does the world report that Kate doth limp?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O slanderous world! Kate like the hazel-twig

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Is straight and slender and as brown in hue

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As hazel nuts and sweeter than the kernels.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O, let me see thee walk: thou dost not halt.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Go, fool, and whom thou keep'st command.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Did ever Dian so become a grove

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As Kate this chamber with her princely gait?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O, be thou Dian, and let her be Kate,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And then let Kate be chaste and Dian sportful!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Where did you study all this goodly speech?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: It is extempore, from my mother-wit.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A witty mother! witless else her son.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Am I not wise?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Yes, keep you warm.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Marry, so I mean, sweet Katharina, in thy bed:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And therefore, setting all this chat aside,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thus in plain terms: your father hath consented

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That you shall be my wife, your dowry 'greed on,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And, Will you, nill you, I will marry you.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Now, Kate, I am a husband for your turn,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For, by this light, whereby I see thy beauty,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thy beauty, that doth make me like thee well,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thou must be married to no man but me,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For I am he am born to tame you Kate,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And bring you from a wild Kate to a Kate

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Conformable as other household Kates.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Here comes your father: never make denial,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I must and will have Katharina to my wife.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Re-enter BAPTISTA, GREMIO, and TRANIO

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Now, Signior Petruchio, how speed you with my daughter?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How but well, sir? how but well?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: It were impossible I should speed amiss.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, how now, daughter Katharina! in your dumps?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Call you me daughter? now, I promise you

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You have show'd a tender fatherly regard,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To wish me wed to one half lunatic,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A mad-cup ruffian and a swearing Jack,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That thinks with oaths to face the matter out.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Father, 'tis thus: yourself and all the world,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That talk'd of her, have talk'd amiss of her:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If she be curst, it is for policy,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For she's not froward, but modest as the dove,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: She is not hot, but temperate as the morn,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For patience she will prove a second Grissel,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And Roman Lucrece for her chastity:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And to conclude, we have 'greed so well together,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That upon Sunday is the wedding-day.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I'll see thee hang'd on Sunday first.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Hark, Petruchio, she says she'll see thee

Author: Shakespeare
Text: hang'd first.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Is this your speeding? nay, then, good night our part!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Be patient, gentlemen, I choose her for myself:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If she and I be pleased, what's that to you?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Tis bargain'd 'twixt us twain, being alone,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That she shall still be curst in company.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I tell you, 'tis incredible to believe

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How much she loves me: O, the kindest Kate!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: She hung about my neck, and kiss on kiss

Author: Shakespeare
Text: She vied so fast, protesting oath on oath,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That in a twink she won me to her love.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O, you are novices! 'tis a world to see,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How tame, when men and women are alone,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A meacock wretch can make the curstest shrew.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Give me thy hand, Kate: I will unto Venice,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To buy apparel 'gainst the wedding-day.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Provide the feast, father, and bid the guests,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I will be sure my Katharina shall be fine.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I know not what to say: but give me your hands,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: God send you joy, Petruchio! 'tis a match.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Amen, say we: we will be witnesses.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Father, and wife, and gentlemen, adieu,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I will to Venice, Sunday comes apace:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: We will have rings and things and fine array,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And kiss me, Kate, we will be married o'Sunday.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Exeunt PETRUCHIO and KATHARINA severally

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Was ever match clapp'd up so suddenly?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Faith, gentlemen, now I play a merchant's part,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And venture madly on a desperate mart.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Twas a commodity lay fretting by you:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Twill bring you gain, or perish on the seas.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The gain I seek is, quiet in the match.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: No doubt but he hath got a quiet catch.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But now, Baptists, to your younger daughter:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Now is the day we long have looked for:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I am your neighbour, and was suitor first.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And I am one that love Bianca more

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Than words can witness, or your thoughts can guess.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Youngling, thou canst not love so dear as I.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Graybeard, thy love doth freeze.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But thine doth fry.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Skipper, stand back: 'tis age that nourisheth.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But youth in ladies' eyes that flourisheth.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Content you, gentlemen: I will compound this strife:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Tis deeds must win the prize, and he of both

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That can assure my daughter greatest dower

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Shall have my Bianca's love.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Say, Signior Gremio, What can you assure her?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: First, as you know, my house within the city

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Is richly furnished with plate and gold,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Basins and ewers to lave her dainty hands,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My hangings all of Tyrian tapestry,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: In ivory coffers I have stuff'd my crowns,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: In cypress chests my arras counterpoints,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Costly apparel, tents, and canopies,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Fine linen, Turkey cushions boss'd with pearl,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Valance of Venice gold in needlework,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Pewter and brass and all things that belong

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To house or housekeeping: then, at my farm

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I have a hundred milch-kine to the pail,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sixscore fat oxen standing in my stalls,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And all things answerable to this portion.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Myself am struck in years, I must confess,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And if I die to-morrow, this is hers,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If whilst I live she will be only mine.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That 'only' came well in. Sir, list to me:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I am my father's heir and only son:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If I may have your daughter to my wife,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I'll leave her houses three or four as good,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Within rich Pisa walls, as any one

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Old Signior Gremio has in Padua,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Besides two thousand ducats by the year

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Of fruitful land, all which shall be her jointure.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What, have I pinch'd you, Signior Gremio?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Two thousand ducats by the year of land!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My land amounts not to so much in all:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That she shall have, besides an argosy

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That now is lying in Marseilles' road.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What, have I choked you with an argosy?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Gremio, 'tis known my father hath no less

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Than three great argosies, besides two galliases,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And twelve tight galleys: these I will assure her,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And twice as much, whate'er thou offer'st next.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Nay, I have offer'd all, I have no more,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And she can have no more than all I have:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If you like me, she shall have me and mine.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, then the maid is mine from all the world,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: By your firm promise: Gremio is out-vied.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I must confess your offer is the best,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And, let your father make her the assurance,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: She is your own, else, you must pardon me,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: if you should die before him, where's her dower?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That's but a cavil: he is old, I young.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And may not young men die, as well as old?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Well, gentlemen,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I am thus resolved: on Sunday next you know

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My daughter Katharina is to be married:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Now, on the Sunday following, shall Bianca

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Be bride to you, if you this assurance,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If not, Signior Gremio:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And so, I take my leave, and thank you both.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Adieu, good neighbour.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Exit BAPTISTA

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Now I fear thee not:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sirrah young gamester, your father were a fool

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To give thee all, and in his waning age

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Set foot under thy table: tut, a toy!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: An old Italian fox is not so kind, my boy.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A vengeance on your crafty wither'd hide!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Yet I have faced it with a card of ten.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Tis in my head to do my master good:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I see no reason but supposed Lucentio

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Must get a father, call'd 'supposed Vincentio,'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And that's a wonder: fathers commonly

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Do get their children, but in this case of wooing,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A child shall get a sire, if I fail not of my cunning.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: SCENE I. Padua. BAPTISTA'S house.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter LUCENTIO, HORTENSIO, and BIANCA

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Fiddler, forbear, you grow too forward, sir:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Have you so soon forgot the entertainment

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Her sister Katharina welcomed you withal?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But, wrangling pedant, this is

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The patroness of heavenly harmony:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Then give me leave to have prerogative,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And when in music we have spent an hour,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Your lecture shall have leisure for as much.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Preposterous ass, that never read so far

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To know the cause why music was ordain'd!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Was it not to refresh the mind of man

Author: Shakespeare
Text: After his studies or his usual pain?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Then give me leave to read philosophy,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And while I pause, serve in your harmony.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sirrah, I will not bear these braves of thine.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, gentlemen, you do me double wrong,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To strive for that which resteth in my choice:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I am no breeching scholar in the schools,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I'll not be tied to hours nor 'pointed times,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But learn my lessons as I please myself.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And, to cut off all strife, here sit we down:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Take you your instrument, play you the whiles,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: His lecture will be done ere you have tuned.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You'll leave his lecture when I am in tune?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That will be never: tune your instrument.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Where left we last?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Here, madam:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Hic ibat Simois, hic est Sigeia tellus,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Hic steterat Priami regia celsa senis.'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Construe them.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Hic ibat,' as I told you before, 'Simois,' I am

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Lucentio, 'hic est,' son unto Vincentio of Pisa,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Sigeia tellus,' disguised thus to get your love,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Hic steterat,' and that Lucentio that comes

Author: Shakespeare
Text: a-wooing, 'Priami,' is my man Tranio, 'regia,'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: bearing my port, 'celsa senis,' that we might

Author: Shakespeare
Text: beguile the old pantaloon.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Madam, my instrument's in tune.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Let's hear. O fie! the treble jars.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Spit in the hole, man, and tune again.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Now let me see if I can construe it: 'Hic ibat

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Simois,' I know you not, 'hic est Sigeia tellus,' I

Author: Shakespeare
Text: trust you not, 'Hic steterat Priami,' take heed

Author: Shakespeare
Text: he hear us not, 'regia,' presume not, 'celsa senis,'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: despair not.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Madam, 'tis now in tune.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: All but the base.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The base is right, 'tis the base knave that jars.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How fiery and forward our pedant is!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Now, for my life, the knave doth court my love:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Pedascule, I'll watch you better yet.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: In time I may believe, yet I mistrust.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Mistrust it not: for, sure, AEacides

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Was Ajax, call'd so from his grandfather.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I must believe my master, else, I promise you,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I should be arguing still upon that doubt:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But let it rest. Now, Licio, to you:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Good masters, take it not unkindly, pray,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That I have been thus pleasant with you both.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You may go walk, and give me leave a while:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My lessons make no music in three parts.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Are you so formal, sir? well, I must wait,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And watch withal, for, but I be deceived,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Our fine musician groweth amorous.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Madam, before you touch the instrument,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To learn the order of my fingering,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I must begin with rudiments of art,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To teach you gamut in a briefer sort,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: More pleasant, pithy and effectual,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Than hath been taught by any of my trade:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And there it is in writing, fairly drawn.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, I am past my gamut long ago.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Yet read the gamut of Hortensio.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: [Reads]  ''Gamut' I am, the ground of all accord,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'A re,' to Plead Hortensio's passion,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'B mi,' Bianca, take him for thy lord,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'C fa ut,' that loves with all affection:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'D sol re,' one clef, two notes have I:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'E la mi,' show pity, or I die.'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Call you this gamut? tut, I like it not:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Old fashions please me best, I am not so nice,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To change true rules for old inventions.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Mistress, your father prays you leave your books

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And help to dress your sister's chamber up:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You know to-morrow is the wedding-day.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Farewell, sweet masters both, I must be gone.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Exeunt BIANCA and Servant

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Faith, mistress, then I have no cause to stay.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But I have cause to pry into this pedant:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Methinks he looks as though he were in love:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Yet if thy thoughts, Bianca, be so humble

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To cast thy wandering eyes on every stale,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Seize thee that list: if once I find thee ranging,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Hortensio will be quit with thee by changing.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: SCENE II. Padua. Before BAPTISTA'S house.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: SCENE II. Padua. Before BAPTISTA'S house.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter BAPTISTA, GREMIO, TRANIO, KATHARINA, BIANCA, LUCENTIO, and others, attendants

Author: Shakespeare
Text: [To TRANIO]  Signior Lucentio, this is the

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'pointed day.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That Katharina and Petruchio should be married,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And yet we hear not of our son-in-law.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What will be said? what mockery will it be,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To want the bridegroom when the priest attends

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To speak the ceremonial rites of marriage!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What says Lucentio to this shame of ours?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: No shame but mine: I must, forsooth, be forced

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To give my hand opposed against my heart

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Unto a mad-brain rudesby full of spleen,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Who woo'd in haste and means to wed at leisure.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I told you, I, he was a frantic fool,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Hiding his bitter jests in blunt behavior:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And, to be noted for a merry man,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: He'll woo a thousand, 'point the day of marriage,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Make feasts, invite friends, and proclaim the banns,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Yet never means to wed where he hath woo'd.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Now must the world point at poor Katharina,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And say, 'Lo, there is mad Petruchio's wife,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If it would please him come and marry her!'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Patience, good Katharina, and Baptista too.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Upon my life, Petruchio means but well,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Whatever fortune stays him from his word:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Though he be blunt, I know him passing wise,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Though he be merry, yet withal he's honest.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Would Katharina had never seen him though!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Exit weeping, followed by BIANCA and others

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Go, girl, I cannot blame thee now to weep,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For such an injury would vex a very saint,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Much more a shrew of thy impatient humour.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Master, master! news, old news, and such news as

Author: Shakespeare
Text: you never heard of!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Is it new and old too? how may that be?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, is it not news, to hear of Petruchio's coming?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Is he come?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, no, sir.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: He is coming.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: When will he be here?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: When he stands where I am and sees you there.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But say, what to thine old news?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, Petruchio is coming in a new hat and an old

Author: Shakespeare
Text: jerkin, a pair of old breeches thrice turned, a pair

Author: Shakespeare
Text: of boots that have been candle-cases, one buckled,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: another laced, an old rusty sword ta'en out of the

Author: Shakespeare
Text: town-armory, with a broken hilt, and chapeless,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: with two broken points: his horse hipped with an

Author: Shakespeare
Text: old mothy saddle and stirrups of no kindred,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: besides, possessed with the glanders and like to mose

Author: Shakespeare
Text: in the chine, troubled with the lampass, infected

Author: Shakespeare
Text: with the fashions, full of wingdalls, sped with

Author: Shakespeare
Text: spavins, rayed with yellows, past cure of the fives,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: stark spoiled with the staggers, begnawn with the

Author: Shakespeare
Text: bots, swayed in the back and shoulder-shotten,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: near-legged before and with, a half-chequed bit

Author: Shakespeare
Text: and a head-stall of sheeps leather which, being

Author: Shakespeare
Text: restrained to keep him from stumbling, hath been

Author: Shakespeare
Text: often burst and now repaired with knots, one girth

Author: Shakespeare
Text: six time pieced and a woman's crupper of velure,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: which hath two letters for her name fairly set down

Author: Shakespeare
Text: in studs, and here and there pieced with packthread.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Who comes with him?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O, sir, his lackey, for all the world caparisoned

Author: Shakespeare
Text: like the horse, with a linen stock on one leg and a

Author: Shakespeare
Text: kersey boot-hose on the other, gartered with a red

Author: Shakespeare
Text: and blue list, an old hat and 'the humour of forty

Author: Shakespeare
Text: fancies' pricked in't for a feather: a monster, a

Author: Shakespeare
Text: very monster in apparel, and not like a Christian

Author: Shakespeare
Text: footboy or a gentleman's lackey.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Tis some odd humour pricks him to this fashion,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Yet oftentimes he goes but mean-apparell'd.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I am glad he's come, howsoe'er he comes.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, sir, he comes not.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Didst thou not say he comes?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Who? that Petruchio came?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, that Petruchio came.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: No, sir, I say his horse comes, with him on his back.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, that's all one.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Nay, by Saint Jamy,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I hold you a penny,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A horse and a man

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Is more than one,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And yet not many.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter PETRUCHIO and GRUMIO

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Come, where be these gallants? who's at home?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You are welcome, sir.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And yet I come not well.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And yet you halt not.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Not so well apparell'd

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As I wish you were.

Author: Shakespeare
