Text: Were it better, I should rush in thus.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But where is Kate? where is my lovely bride?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How does my father? Gentles, methinks you frown:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And wherefore gaze this goodly company,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As if they saw some wondrous monument,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Some comet or unusual prodigy?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, sir, you know this is your wedding-day:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: First were we sad, fearing you would not come,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Now sadder, that you come so unprovided.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Fie, doff this habit, shame to your estate,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: An eye-sore to our solemn festival!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And tells us, what occasion of import

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Hath all so long detain'd you from your wife,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And sent you hither so unlike yourself?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Tedious it were to tell, and harsh to hear:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sufficeth I am come to keep my word,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Though in some part enforced to digress,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Which, at more leisure, I will so excuse

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As you shall well be satisfied withal.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But where is Kate? I stay too long from her:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The morning wears, 'tis time we were at church.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: See not your bride in these unreverent robes:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Go to my chamber, Put on clothes of mine.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Not I, believe me: thus I'll visit her.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But thus, I trust, you will not marry her.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Good sooth, even thus, therefore ha' done with words:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To me she's married, not unto my clothes:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Could I repair what she will wear in me,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As I can change these poor accoutrements,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Twere well for Kate and better for myself.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But what a fool am I to chat with you,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: When I should bid good morrow to my bride,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And seal the title with a lovely kiss!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Exeunt PETRUCHIO and GRUMIO

Author: Shakespeare
Text: He hath some meaning in his mad attire:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: We will persuade him, be it possible,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To put on better ere he go to church.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I'll after him, and see the event of this.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Exeunt BAPTISTA, GREMIO, and attendants

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But to her love concerneth us to add

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Her father's liking: which to bring to pass,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As I before unparted to your worship,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I am to get a man,--whate'er he be,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: It skills not much. we'll fit him to our turn,--

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And he shall be Vincentio of Pisa,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And make assurance here in Padua

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Of greater sums than I have promised.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: So shall you quietly enjoy your hope,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And marry sweet Bianca with consent.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Were it not that my fellow-school-master

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Doth watch Bianca's steps so narrowly,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Twere good, methinks, to steal our marriage,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Which once perform'd, let all the world say no,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I'll keep mine own, despite of all the world.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That by degrees we mean to look into,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And watch our vantage in this business:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: We'll over-reach the greybeard, Gremio,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The narrow-prying father, Minola,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The quaint musician, amorous Licio,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: All for my master's sake, Lucentio.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Re-enter GREMIO

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Signior Gremio, came you from the church?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As willingly as e'er I came from school.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And is the bride and bridegroom coming home?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A bridegroom say you? 'tis a groom indeed,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A grumbling groom, and that the girl shall find.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Curster than she? why, 'tis impossible.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why he's a devil, a devil, a very fiend.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, she's a devil, a devil, the devil's dam.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Tut, she's a lamb, a dove, a fool to him!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I'll tell you, Sir Lucentio: when the priest

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Should ask, if Katharina should be his wife,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Ay, by gogs-wouns,' quoth he, and swore so loud,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That, all-amazed, the priest let fall the book,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And, as he stoop'd again to take it up,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The mad-brain'd bridegroom took him such a cuff

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That down fell priest and book and book and priest:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Now take them up,' quoth he, 'if any list.'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What said the wench when he rose again?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Trembled and shook, for why, he stamp'd and swore,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As if the vicar meant to cozen him.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But after many ceremonies done,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: He calls for wine: 'A health!' quoth he, as if

Author: Shakespeare
Text: He had been aboard, carousing to his mates

Author: Shakespeare
Text: After a storm, quaff'd off the muscadel

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And threw the sops all in the sexton's face,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Having no other reason

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But that his beard grew thin and hungerly

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And seem'd to ask him sops as he was drinking.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: This done, he took the bride about the neck

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And kiss'd her lips with such a clamorous smack

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That at the parting all the church did echo:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And I seeing this came thence for very shame,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And after me, I know, the rout is coming.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Such a mad marriage never was before:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Hark, hark! I hear the minstrels play.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Re-enter PETRUCHIO, KATHARINA, BIANCA, BAPTISTA, HORTENSIO, GRUMIO, and Train

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Gentlemen and friends, I thank you for your pains:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I know you think to dine with me to-day,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And have prepared great store of wedding cheer,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But so it is, my haste doth call me hence,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And therefore here I mean to take my leave.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Is't possible you will away to-night?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I must away to-day, before night come:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Make it no wonder, if you knew my business,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You would entreat me rather go than stay.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And, honest company, I thank you all,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That have beheld me give away myself

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To this most patient, sweet and virtuous wife:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Dine with my father, drink a health to me,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For I must hence, and farewell to you all.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Let us entreat you stay till after dinner.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Let me entreat you.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Let me entreat you.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Are you content to stay?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I am content you shall entreat me stay,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But yet not stay, entreat me how you can.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Now, if you love me, stay.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Grumio, my horse.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, sir, they be ready: the oats have eaten the horses.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Nay, then,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Do what thou canst, I will not go to-day,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: No, nor to-morrow, not till I please myself.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The door is open, sir, there lies your way,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You may be jogging whiles your boots are green,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For me, I'll not be gone till I please myself:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Tis like you'll prove a jolly surly groom,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That take it on you at the first so roundly.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O Kate, content thee, prithee, be not angry.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I will be angry: what hast thou to do?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Father, be quiet, he shall stay my leisure.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, marry, sir, now it begins to work.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Gentlemen, forward to the bridal dinner:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I see a woman may be made a fool,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If she had not a spirit to resist.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: They shall go forward, Kate, at thy command.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Obey the bride, you that attend on her,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Go to the feast, revel and domineer,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Carouse full measure to her maidenhead,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Be mad and merry, or go hang yourselves:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But for my bonny Kate, she must with me.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Nay, look not big, nor stamp, nor stare, nor fret,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I will be master of what is mine own:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: She is my goods, my chattels, she is my house,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My household stuff, my field, my barn,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My horse, my ox, my ass, my any thing,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And here she stands, touch her whoever dare,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I'll bring mine action on the proudest he

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That stops my way in Padua. Grumio,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Draw forth thy weapon, we are beset with thieves,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Rescue thy mistress, if thou be a man.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Fear not, sweet wench, they shall not touch

Author: Shakespeare
Text: thee, Kate:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I'll buckler thee against a million.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Exeunt PETRUCHIO, KATHARINA, and GRUMIO

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Nay, let them go, a couple of quiet ones.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Went they not quickly, I should die with laughing.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Of all mad matches never was the like.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Mistress, what's your opinion of your sister?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That, being mad herself, she's madly mated.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I warrant him, Petruchio is Kated.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Neighbours and friends, though bride and

Author: Shakespeare
Text: bridegroom wants

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For to supply the places at the table,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You know there wants no junkets at the feast.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Lucentio, you shall supply the bridegroom's place:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And let Bianca take her sister's room.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Shall sweet Bianca practise how to bride it?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: She shall, Lucentio. Come, gentlemen, let's go.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: SCENE I. PETRUCHIO'S country house.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter GRUMIO

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Fie, fie on all tired jades, on all mad masters, and

Author: Shakespeare
Text: all foul ways! Was ever man so beaten? was ever

Author: Shakespeare
Text: man so rayed? was ever man so weary? I am sent

Author: Shakespeare
Text: before to make a fire, and they are coming after to

Author: Shakespeare
Text: warm them. Now, were not I a little pot and soon

Author: Shakespeare
Text: hot, my very lips might freeze to my teeth, my

Author: Shakespeare
Text: tongue to the roof of my mouth, my heart in my

Author: Shakespeare
Text: belly, ere I should come by a fire to thaw me: but

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I, with blowing the fire, shall warm myself, for,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: considering the weather, a taller man than I will

Author: Shakespeare
Text: take cold. Holla, ho! Curtis.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter CURTIS

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Who is that calls so coldly?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A piece of ice: if thou doubt it, thou mayst slide

Author: Shakespeare
Text: from my shoulder to my heel with no greater a run

Author: Shakespeare
Text: but my head and my neck. A fire good Curtis.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Is my master and his wife coming, Grumio?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O, ay, Curtis, ay: and therefore fire, fire, cast

Author: Shakespeare
Text: on no water.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Is she so hot a shrew as she's reported?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: She was, good Curtis, before this frost: but, thou

Author: Shakespeare
Text: knowest, winter tames man, woman and beast, for it

Author: Shakespeare
Text: hath tamed my old master and my new mistress and

Author: Shakespeare
Text: myself, fellow Curtis.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Away, you three-inch fool! I am no beast.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Am I but three inches? why, thy horn is a foot, and

Author: Shakespeare
Text: so long am I at the least. But wilt thou make a

Author: Shakespeare
Text: fire, or shall I complain on thee to our mistress,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: whose hand, she being now at hand, thou shalt soon

Author: Shakespeare
Text: feel, to thy cold comfort, for being slow in thy hot office?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I prithee, good Grumio, tell me, how goes the world?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A cold world, Curtis, in every office but thine, and

Author: Shakespeare
Text: therefore fire: do thy duty, and have thy duty, for

Author: Shakespeare
Text: my master and mistress are almost frozen to death.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: There's fire ready, and therefore, good Grumio, the news.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, 'Jack, boy! ho! boy!' and as much news as

Author: Shakespeare
Text: will thaw.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Come, you are so full of cony-catching!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, therefore fire, for I have caught extreme cold.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Where's the cook? is supper ready, the house

Author: Shakespeare
Text: trimmed, rushes strewed, cobwebs swept, the

Author: Shakespeare
Text: serving-men in their new fustian, their white

Author: Shakespeare
Text: stockings, and every officer his wedding-garment on?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Be the jacks fair within, the jills fair without,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: the carpets laid, and every thing in order?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: All ready, and therefore, I pray thee, news.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: First, know, my horse is tired, my master and

Author: Shakespeare
Text: mistress fallen out.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Out of their saddles into the dirt, and thereby

Author: Shakespeare
Text: hangs a tale.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Let's ha't, good Grumio.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Lend thine ear.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: This is to feel a tale, not to hear a tale.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And therefore 'tis called a sensible tale: and this

Author: Shakespeare
Text: cuff was but to knock at your ear, and beseech

Author: Shakespeare
Text: listening. Now I begin: Imprimis, we came down a

Author: Shakespeare
Text: foul hill, my master riding behind my mistress,--

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Both of one horse?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What's that to thee?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, a horse.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Tell thou the tale: but hadst thou not crossed me,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: thou shouldst have heard how her horse fell and she

Author: Shakespeare
Text: under her horse, thou shouldst have heard in how

Author: Shakespeare
Text: miry a place, how she was bemoiled, how he left her

Author: Shakespeare
Text: with the horse upon her, how he beat me because

Author: Shakespeare
Text: her horse stumbled, how she waded through the dirt

Author: Shakespeare
Text: to pluck him off me, how he swore, how she prayed,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: that never prayed before, how I cried, how the

Author: Shakespeare
Text: horses ran away, how her bridle was burst, how I

Author: Shakespeare
Text: lost my crupper, with many things of worthy memory,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: which now shall die in oblivion and thou return

Author: Shakespeare
Text: unexperienced to thy grave.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: By this reckoning he is more shrew than she.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, and that thou and the proudest of you all shall

Author: Shakespeare
Text: find when he comes home. But what talk I of this?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Call forth Nathaniel, Joseph, Nicholas, Philip,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Walter, Sugarsop and the rest: let their heads be

Author: Shakespeare
Text: sleekly combed their blue coats brushed and their

Author: Shakespeare
Text: garters of an indifferent knit: let them curtsy

Author: Shakespeare
Text: with their left legs and not presume to touch a hair

Author: Shakespeare
Text: of my master's horse-tail till they kiss their

Author: Shakespeare
Text: hands. Are they all ready?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: They are.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Call them forth.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Do you hear, ho? you must meet my master to

Author: Shakespeare
Text: countenance my mistress.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, she hath a face of her own.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Who knows not that?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thou, it seems, that calls for company to

Author: Shakespeare
Text: countenance her.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I call them forth to credit her.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, she comes to borrow nothing of them.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter four or five Serving-men

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Welcome home, Grumio!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How now, Grumio!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What, Grumio!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Fellow Grumio!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How now, old lad?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Welcome, you,--how now, you,-- what, you,--fellow,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: you,--and thus much for greeting. Now, my spruce

Author: Shakespeare
Text: companions, is all ready, and all things neat?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: All things is ready. How near is our master?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: E'en at hand, alighted by this, and therefore be

Author: Shakespeare
Text: not--Cock's passion, silence! I hear my master.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter PETRUCHIO and KATHARINA

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Where be these knaves? What, no man at door

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To hold my stirrup nor to take my horse!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Where is Nathaniel, Gregory, Philip?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: ALL SERVING-MEN	Here, here, sir, here, sir.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Here, sir! here, sir! here, sir! here, sir!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You logger-headed and unpolish'd grooms!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What, no attendance? no regard? no duty?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Where is the foolish knave I sent before?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Here, sir, as foolish as I was before.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You peasant swain! you whoreson malt-horse drudge!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Did I not bid thee meet me in the park,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And bring along these rascal knaves with thee?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Nathaniel's coat, sir, was not fully made,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And Gabriel's pumps were all unpink'd i' the heel,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: There was no link to colour Peter's hat,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And Walter's dagger was not come from sheathing:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: There were none fine but Adam, Ralph, and Gregory,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The rest were ragged, old, and beggarly,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Yet, as they are, here are they come to meet you.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Go, rascals, go, and fetch my supper in.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Where is the life that late I led--

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Where are those--Sit down, Kate, and welcome.--

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sound, sound, sound, sound!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Re-enter Servants with supper

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, when, I say? Nay, good sweet Kate, be merry.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Off with my boots, you rogues! you villains, when?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: It was the friar of orders grey,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As he forth walked on his way:--

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Out, you rogue! you pluck my foot awry:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Take that, and mend the plucking off the other.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Be merry, Kate. Some water, here, what, ho!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Where's my spaniel Troilus? Sirrah, get you hence,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And bid my cousin Ferdinand come hither:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: One, Kate, that you must kiss, and be acquainted with.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Where are my slippers? Shall I have some water?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter one with water

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Come, Kate, and wash, and welcome heartily.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You whoreson villain! will you let it fall?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Patience, I pray you, 'twas a fault unwilling.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A whoreson beetle-headed, flap-ear'd knave!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Come, Kate, sit down, I know you have a stomach.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Will you give thanks, sweet Kate, or else shall I?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What's this? mutton?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Who brought it?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Tis burnt, and so is all the meat.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What dogs are these! Where is the rascal cook?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How durst you, villains, bring it from the dresser,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And serve it thus to me that love it not?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Theretake it to you, trenchers, cups, and all,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Throws the meat,  and c. about the stage

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You heedless joltheads and unmanner'd slaves!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What, do you grumble? I'll be with you straight.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I pray you, husband, be not so disquiet:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The meat was well, if you were so contented.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I tell thee, Kate, 'twas burnt and dried away,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And I expressly am forbid to touch it,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For it engenders choler, planteth anger,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And better 'twere that both of us did fast,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Since, of ourselves, ourselves are choleric,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Than feed it with such over-roasted flesh.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Be patient, to-morrow 't shall be mended,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And, for this night, we'll fast for company:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Come, I will bring thee to thy bridal chamber.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Re-enter Servants severally

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Peter, didst ever see the like?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: He kills her in her own humour.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Re-enter CURTIS

Author: Shakespeare
Text: In her chamber, making a sermon of continency to her,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And rails, and swears, and rates, that she, poor soul,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Knows not which way to stand, to look, to speak,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And sits as one new-risen from a dream.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Away, away! for he is coming hither.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Re-enter PETRUCHIO

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thus have I politicly begun my reign,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And 'tis my hope to end successfully.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My falcon now is sharp and passing empty,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And till she stoop she must not be full-gorged,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For then she never looks upon her lure.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Another way I have to man my haggard,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To make her come and know her keeper's call,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That is, to watch her, as we watch these kites

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That bate and beat and will not be obedient.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: She eat no meat to-day, nor none shall eat,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Last night she slept not, nor to-night she shall not,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As with the meat, some undeserved fault

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I'll find about the making of the bed,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And here I'll fling the pillow, there the bolster,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: This way the coverlet, another way the sheets:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, and amid this hurly I intend

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That all is done in reverend care of her,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And in conclusion she shall watch all night:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And if she chance to nod I'll rail and brawl

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And with the clamour keep her still awake.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: This is a way to kill a wife with kindness,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And thus I'll curb her mad and headstrong humour.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: He that knows better how to tame a shrew,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Now let him speak: 'tis charity to show.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter TRANIO and HORTENSIO

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Is't possible, friend Licio, that Mistress Bianca

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Doth fancy any other but Lucentio?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I tell you, sir, she bears me fair in hand.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sir, to satisfy you in what I have said,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Stand by and mark the manner of his teaching.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter BIANCA and LUCENTIO

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Now, mistress, profit you in what you read?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What, master, read you? first resolve me that.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I read that I profess, the Art to Love.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And may you prove, sir, master of your art!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: While you, sweet dear, prove mistress of my heart!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Quick proceeders, marry! Now, tell me, I pray,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You that durst swear at your mistress Bianca

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Loved none in the world so well as Lucentio.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O despiteful love! unconstant womankind!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I tell thee, Licio, this is wonderful.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Mistake no more: I am not Licio,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Nor a musician, as I seem to be,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But one that scorn to live in this disguise,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For such a one as leaves a gentleman,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And makes a god of such a cullion:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Know, sir, that I am call'd Hortensio.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Signior Hortensio, I have often heard

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Of your entire affection to Bianca,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And since mine eyes are witness of her lightness,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I will with you, if you be so contented,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Forswear Bianca and her love for ever.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: See, how they kiss and court! Signior Lucentio,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Here is my hand, and here I firmly vow

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Never to woo her no more, but do forswear her,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As one unworthy all the former favours

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That I have fondly flatter'd her withal.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And here I take the unfeigned oath,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Never to marry with her though she would entreat:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Fie on her! see, how beastly she doth court him!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Would all the world but he had quite forsworn!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For me, that I may surely keep mine oath,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I will be married to a wealthy widow,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ere three days pass, which hath as long loved me

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As I have loved this proud disdainful haggard.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And so farewell, Signior Lucentio.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Kindness in women, not their beauteous looks,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Shall win my love: and so I take my leave,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: In resolution as I swore before.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Mistress Bianca, bless you with such grace

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As 'longeth to a lover's blessed case!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Nay, I have ta'en you napping, gentle love,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And have forsworn you with Hortensio.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Tranio, you jest: but have you both forsworn me?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Mistress, we have.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Then we are rid of Licio.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I' faith, he'll have a lusty widow now,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That shall be wood and wedded in a day.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: God give him joy!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, and he'll tame her.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: He says so, Tranio.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Faith, he is gone unto the taming-school.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The taming-school! what, is there such a place?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, mistress, and Petruchio is the master,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That teacheth tricks eleven and twenty long,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To tame a shrew and charm her chattering tongue.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O master, master, I have watch'd so long

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That I am dog-weary: but at last I spied

Author: Shakespeare
Text: An ancient angel coming down the hill,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Will serve the turn.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What is he, Biondello?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Master, a mercatante, or a pedant,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I know not what, but format in apparel,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: In gait and countenance surely like a father.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And what of him, Tranio?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If he be credulous and trust my tale,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I'll make him glad to seem Vincentio,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And give assurance to Baptista Minola,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As if he were the right Vincentio

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Take in your love, and then let me alone.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Exeunt LUCENTIO and BIANCA

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Exeunt LUCENTIO and BIANCA

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter a Pedant

Author: Shakespeare
Text: God save you, sir!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And you, sir! you are welcome.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Travel you far on, or are you at the farthest?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sir, at the farthest for a week or two:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But then up farther, and as for as Rome,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And so to Tripoli, if God lend me life.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What countryman, I pray?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Of Mantua.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Of Mantua, sir? marry, God forbid!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And come to Padua, careless of your life?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My life, sir! how, I pray? for that goes hard.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Tis death for any one in Mantua

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To come to Padua. Know you not the cause?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Your ships are stay'd at Venice, and the duke,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For private quarrel 'twixt your duke and him,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Hath publish'd and proclaim'd it openly:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Tis, marvel, but that you are but newly come,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You might have heard it else proclaim'd about.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Alas! sir, it is worse for me than so,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For I have bills for money by exchange

Author: Shakespeare
Text: From Florence and must here deliver them.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Well, sir, to do you courtesy,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: This will I do, and this I will advise you:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: First, tell me, have you ever been at Pisa?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, sir, in Pisa have I often been,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Pisa renowned for grave citizens.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Among them know you one Vincentio?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I know him not, but I have heard of him,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A merchant of incomparable wealth.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: He is my father, sir, and, sooth to say,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: In countenance somewhat doth resemble you.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: [Aside]  As much as an apple doth an oyster,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: and all one.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To save your life in this extremity,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: This favour will I do you for his sake,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And think it not the worst of an your fortunes

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That you are like to Sir Vincentio.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: His name and credit shall you undertake,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And in my house you shall be friendly lodged:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Look that you take upon you as you should,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You understand me, sir: so shall you stay

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Till you have done your business in the city:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If this be courtesy, sir, accept of it.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O sir, I do, and will repute you ever

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The patron of my life and liberty.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Then go with me to make the matter good.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: This, by the way, I let you understand,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: my father is here look'd for every day,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To pass assurance of a dower in marriage

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Twixt me and one Baptista's daughter here:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: In all these circumstances I'll instruct you:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Go with me to clothe you as becomes you.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: SCENE III. A room in PETRUCHIO'S house.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter KATHARINA and GRUMIO

Author: Shakespeare
Text: No, no, forsooth, I dare not for my life.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The more my wrong, the more his spite appears:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What, did he marry me to famish me?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Beggars, that come unto my father's door,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Upon entreaty have a present aims,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If not, elsewhere they meet with charity:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But I, who never knew how to entreat,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Nor never needed that I should entreat,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Am starved for meat, giddy for lack of sleep,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: With oath kept waking and with brawling fed:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And that which spites me more than all these wants,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: He does it under name of perfect love,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As who should say, if I should sleep or eat,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Twere deadly sickness or else present death.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I prithee go and get me some repast,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I care not what, so it be wholesome food.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What say you to a neat's foot?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Tis passing good: I prithee let me have it.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I fear it is too choleric a meat.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How say you to a fat tripe finely broil'd?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I like it well: good Grumio, fetch it me.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I cannot tell, I fear 'tis choleric.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What say you to a piece of beef and mustard?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A dish that I do love to feed upon.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, but the mustard is too hot a little.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why then, the beef, and let the mustard rest.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Nay then, I will not: you shall have the mustard,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Or else you get no beef of Grumio.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Then both, or one, or any thing thou wilt.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why then, the mustard without the beef.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Go, get thee gone, thou false deluding slave,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Beats him

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That feed'st me with the very name of meat:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sorrow on thee and all the pack of you,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That triumph thus upon my misery!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Go, get thee gone, I say.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter PETRUCHIO and HORTENSIO with meat

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How fares my Kate? What, sweeting, all amort?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Mistress, what cheer?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Faith, as cold as can be.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Pluck up thy spirits, look cheerfully upon me.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Here love, thou see'st how diligent I am

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To dress thy meat myself and bring it thee:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I am sure, sweet Kate, this kindness merits thanks.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What, not a word? Nay, then thou lovest it not,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And all my pains is sorted to no proof.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Here, take away this dish.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I pray you, let it stand.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The poorest service is repaid with thanks,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And so shall mine, before you touch the meat.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Signior Petruchio, fie! you are to blame.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Come, mistress Kate, I'll bear you company.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: [Aside]  Eat it up all, Hortensio, if thou lovest me.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Much good do it unto thy gentle heart!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Kate, eat apace: and now, my honey love,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Will we return unto thy father's house

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And revel it as bravely as the best,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: With silken coats and caps and golden rings,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: With ruffs and cuffs and fardingales and things,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: With scarfs and fans and double change of bravery,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: With amber bracelets, beads and all this knavery.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What, hast thou dined? The tailor stays thy leisure,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To deck thy body with his ruffling treasure.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter Tailor

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Come, tailor, let us see these ornaments,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Lay forth the gown.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter Haberdasher

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What news with you, sir?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Here is the cap your worship did bespeak.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, this was moulded on a porringer,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A velvet dish: fie, fie! 'tis lewd and filthy:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, 'tis a cockle or a walnut-shell,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A knack, a toy, a trick, a baby's cap:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Away with it! come, let me have a bigger.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I'll have no bigger: this doth fit the time,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And gentlewomen wear such caps as these

Author: Shakespeare
Text: When you are gentle, you shall have one too,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And not till then.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: [Aside]  That will not be in haste.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, sir, I trust I may have leave to speak,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And speak I will, I am no child, no babe:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Your betters have endured me say my mind,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And if you cannot, best you stop your ears.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My tongue will tell the anger of my heart,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Or else my heart concealing it will break,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And rather than it shall, I will be free

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Even to the uttermost, as I please, in words.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, thou say'st true, it is a paltry cap,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A custard-coffin, a bauble, a silken pie:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I love thee well, in that thou likest it not.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Love me or love me not, I like the cap,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And it I will have, or I will have none.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Exit Haberdasher

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thy gown? why, ay: come, tailor, let us see't.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O mercy, God! what masquing stuff is here?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What's this? a sleeve? 'tis like a demi-cannon:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What, up and down, carved like an apple-tart?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Here's snip and nip and cut and slish and slash,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Like to a censer in a barber's shop:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, what, i' devil's name, tailor, call'st thou this?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: [Aside]  I see she's like to have neither cap nor gown.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You bid me make it orderly and well,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: According to the fashion and the time.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Marry, and did, but if you be remember'd,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I did not bid you mar it to the time.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Go, hop me over every kennel home,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For you shall hop without my custom, sir:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I'll none of it: hence! make your best of it.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I never saw a better-fashion'd gown,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: More quaint, more pleasing, nor more commendable:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Belike you mean to make a puppet of me.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, true, he means to make a puppet of thee.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: She says your worship means to make

Author: Shakespeare
Text: a puppet of her.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O monstrous arrogance! Thou liest, thou thread,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: thou thimble,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thou yard, three-quarters, half-yard, quarter, nail!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thou flea, thou nit, thou winter-cricket thou!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Braved in mine own house with a skein of thread?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Away, thou rag, thou quantity, thou remnant,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Or I shall so be-mete thee with thy yard

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As thou shalt think on prating whilst thou livest!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I tell thee, I, that thou hast marr'd her gown.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Your worship is deceived, the gown is made

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Just as my master had direction:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Grumio gave order how it should be done.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I gave him no order, I gave him the stuff.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But how did you desire it should be made?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Marry, sir, with needle and thread.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But did you not request to have it cut?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thou hast faced many things.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Face not me: thou hast braved many men, brave not

Author: Shakespeare
Text: me, I will neither be faced nor braved. I say unto

Author: Shakespeare
Text: thee, I bid thy master cut out the gown, but I did

Author: Shakespeare
Text: not bid him cut it to pieces: ergo, thou liest.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, here is the note of the fashion to testify

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Read it.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The note lies in's throat, if he say I said so.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: [Reads]  'Imprimis, a loose-bodied gown:'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Master, if ever I said loose-bodied gown, sew me in

Author: Shakespeare
Text: the skirts of it, and beat me to death with a bottom

Author: Shakespeare
Text: of brown thread: I said a gown.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: [Reads]  'With a small compassed cape:'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I confess the cape.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: [Reads]  'With a trunk sleeve:'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I confess two sleeves.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: [Reads]  'The sleeves curiously cut.'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, there's the villany.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Error i' the bill, sir, error i' the bill.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I commanded the sleeves should be cut out and

Author: Shakespeare
Text: sewed up again, and that I'll prove upon thee,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: though thy little finger be armed in a thimble.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: This is true that I say: an I had thee

Author: Shakespeare
Text: in place where, thou shouldst know it.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I am for thee straight: take thou the

Author: Shakespeare
Text: bill, give me thy mete-yard, and spare not me.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: God-a-mercy, Grumio! then he shall have no odds.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Well, sir, in brief, the gown is not for me.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You are i' the right, sir: 'tis for my mistress.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Go, take it up unto thy master's use.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Villain, not for thy life: take up my mistress'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: gown for thy master's use!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, sir, what's your conceit in that?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O, sir, the conceit is deeper than you think for:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Take up my mistress' gown to his master's use!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: [Aside]  Hortensio, say thou wilt see the tailor paid.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Go take it hence, be gone, and say no more.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Tailor, I'll pay thee for thy gown tomorrow:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Take no unkindness of his hasty words:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Away! I say, commend me to thy master.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Exit Tailor

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Well, come, my Kate, we will unto your father's

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Even in these honest mean habiliments:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Our purses shall be proud, our garments poor,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For 'tis the mind that makes the body rich,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And as the sun breaks through the darkest clouds,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: So honour peereth in the meanest habit.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What is the jay more precious than the lark,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Because his fathers are more beautiful?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Or is the adder better than the eel,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Because his painted skin contents the eye?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O, no, good Kate, neither art thou the worse

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For this poor furniture and mean array.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: if thou account'st it shame. lay it on me,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And therefore frolic: we will hence forthwith,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To feast and sport us at thy father's house.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Go, call my men, and let us straight to him,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And bring our horses unto Long-lane end,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: There will we mount, and thither walk on foot

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Let's see, I think 'tis now some seven o'clock,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And well we may come there by dinner-time.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I dare assure you, sir, 'tis almost two,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And 'twill be supper-time ere you come there.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: It shall be seven ere I go to horse:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Look, what I speak, or do, or think to do,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You are still crossing it. Sirs, let't alone:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I will not go to-day, and ere I do,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: It shall be what o'clock I say it is.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: [Aside]  Why, so this gallant will command the sun.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: SCENE IV. Padua. Before BAPTISTA'S house.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter TRANIO, and the Pedant dressed like VINCENTIO

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sir, this is the house: please it you that I call?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, what else? and but I be deceived

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Signior Baptista may remember me,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Near twenty years ago, in Genoa,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Where we were lodgers at the Pegasus.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Tis well, and hold your own, in any case,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: With such austerity as 'longeth to a father.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I warrant you.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But, sir, here comes your boy,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Twere good he were school'd.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Fear you not him. Sirrah Biondello,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Now do your duty throughly, I advise you:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Imagine 'twere the right Vincentio.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Tut, fear not me.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But hast thou done thy errand to Baptista?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I told him that your father was at Venice,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And that you look'd for him this day in Padua.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thou'rt a tall fellow: hold thee that to drink.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Here comes Baptista: set your countenance, sir.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter BAPTISTA and LUCENTIO

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Signior Baptista, you are happily met.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To the Pedant

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sir, this is the gentleman I told you of:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I pray you stand good father to me now,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Give me Bianca for my patrimony.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Soft son!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sir, by your leave: having come to Padua

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To gather in some debts, my son Lucentio

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Made me acquainted with a weighty cause

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Of love between your daughter and himself:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And, for the good report I hear of you

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And for the love he beareth to your daughter

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And she to him, to stay him not too long,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I am content, in a good father's care,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To have him match'd, and if you please to like

Author: Shakespeare
Text: No worse than I, upon some agreement

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Me shall you find ready and willing

Author: Shakespeare
Text: With one consent to have her so bestow'd,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For curious I cannot be with you,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Signior Baptista, of whom I hear so well.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sir, pardon me in what I have to say:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Your plainness and your shortness please me well.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Right true it is, your son Lucentio here

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Doth love my daughter and she loveth him,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Or both dissemble deeply their affections:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And therefore, if you say no more than this,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That like a father you will deal with him

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And pass my daughter a sufficient dower,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The match is made, and all is done:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Your son shall have my daughter with consent.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I thank you, sir. Where then do you know best

Author: Shakespeare
Text: We be affied and such assurance ta'en

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As shall with either part's agreement stand?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Not in my house, Lucentio, for, you know,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Pitchers have ears, and I have many servants:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Besides, old Gremio is hearkening still,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And happily we might be interrupted.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Then at my lodging, an it like you:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: There doth my father lie, and there, this night,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: We'll pass the business privately and well.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Send for your daughter by your servant here:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My boy shall fetch the scrivener presently.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The worst is this, that, at so slender warning,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You are like to have a thin and slender pittance.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: It likes me well. Biondello, hie you home,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And bid Bianca make her ready straight,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And, if you will, tell what hath happened,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Lucentio's father is arrived in Padua,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And how she's like to be Lucentio's wife.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I pray the gods she may with all my heart!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Dally not with the gods, but get thee gone.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Exit BIONDELLO

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Exit BIONDELLO

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Signior Baptista, shall I lead the way?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Welcome! one mess is like to be your cheer:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Come, sir, we will better it in Pisa.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I follow you.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Exeunt TRANIO, Pedant, and BAPTISTA

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Re-enter BIONDELLO

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Re-enter BIONDELLO

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Re-enter BIONDELLO

Text: Re-enter BIONDELLO

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Cambio!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What sayest thou, Biondello?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You saw my master wink and laugh upon you?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Biondello, what of that?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Faith, nothing, but has left me here behind, to

Author: Shakespeare
Text: expound the meaning or moral of his signs and tokens.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I pray thee, moralize them.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Then thus. Baptista is safe, talking with the

Author: Shakespeare
Text: deceiving father of a deceitful son.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And what of him?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: His daughter is to be brought by you to the supper.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The old priest of Saint Luke's church is at your

Author: Shakespeare
Text: command at all hours.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And what of all this?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I cannot tell, expect they are busied about a

Author: Shakespeare
Text: counterfeit assurance: take you assurance of her,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'cum privilegio ad imprimendum solum:' to the

Author: Shakespeare
Text: church, take the priest, clerk, and some sufficient

Author: Shakespeare
Text: honest witnesses: If this be not that you look for,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I have no more to say, But bid Bianca farewell for

Author: Shakespeare
Text: ever and a day.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Hearest thou, Biondello?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I cannot tarry: I knew a wench married in an

Author: Shakespeare
Text: afternoon as she went to the garden for parsley to

Author: Shakespeare
Text: stuff a rabbit, and so may you, sir: and so, adieu,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: sir. My master hath appointed me to go to Saint

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Luke's, to bid the priest be ready to come against

Author: Shakespeare
Text: you come with your appendix.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I may, and will, if she be so contented:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: She will be pleased, then wherefore should I doubt?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Hap what hap may, I'll roundly go about her:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: It shall go hard if Cambio go without her.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: SCENE V. A public road.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter PETRUCHIO, KATHARINA, HORTENSIO, and Servants

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Come on, i' God's name, once more toward our father's.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Good Lord, how bright and goodly shines the moon!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The moon! the sun: it is not moonlight now.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I say it is the moon that shines so bright.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I know it is the sun that shines so bright.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Now, by my mother's son, and that's myself,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: It shall be moon, or star, or what I list,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Or ere I journey to your father's house.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Go on, and fetch our horses back again.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Evermore cross'd and cross'd, nothing but cross'd!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Say as he says, or we shall never go.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Forward, I pray, since we have come so far,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And be it moon, or sun, or what you please:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: An if you please to call it a rush-candle,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Henceforth I vow it shall be so for me.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I say it is the moon.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I know it is the moon.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Nay, then you lie: it is the blessed sun.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Then, God be bless'd, it is the blessed sun:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But sun it is not, when you say it is not,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And the moon changes even as your mind.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What you will have it named, even that it is,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And so it shall be so for Katharina.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Petruchio, go thy ways, the field is won.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Well, forward, forward! thus the bowl should run,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And not unluckily against the bias.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But, soft! company is coming here.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter VINCENTIO

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To VINCENTIO

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Good morrow, gentle mistress: where away?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Tell me, sweet Kate, and tell me truly too,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Hast thou beheld a fresher gentlewoman?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Such war of white and red within her cheeks!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What stars do spangle heaven with such beauty,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As those two eyes become that heavenly face?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Fair lovely maid, once more good day to thee.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sweet Kate, embrace her for her beauty's sake.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A' will make the man mad, to make a woman of him.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Young budding virgin, fair and fresh and sweet,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Whither away, or where is thy abode?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Happy the parents of so fair a child,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Happier the man, whom favourable stars

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Allot thee for his lovely bed-fellow!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, how now, Kate! I hope thou art not mad:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: This is a man, old, wrinkled, faded, wither'd,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And not a maiden, as thou say'st he is.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Pardon, old father, my mistaking eyes,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That have been so bedazzled with the sun

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That everything I look on seemeth green:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Now I perceive thou art a reverend father,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Pardon, I pray thee, for my mad mistaking.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Do, good old grandsire, and withal make known

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Which way thou travellest: if along with us,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: We shall be joyful of thy company.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Fair sir, and you my merry mistress,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That with your strange encounter much amazed me,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My name is call'd Vincentio, my dwelling Pisa,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And bound I am to Padua, there to visit

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A son of mine, which long I have not seen.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Lucentio, gentle sir.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Happily we met, the happier for thy son.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And now by law, as well as reverend age,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I may entitle thee my loving father:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The sister to my wife, this gentlewoman,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thy son by this hath married. Wonder not,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Nor be grieved: she is of good esteem,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Her dowery wealthy, and of worthy birth,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Beside, so qualified as may beseem

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The spouse of any noble gentleman.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Let me embrace with old Vincentio,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And wander we to see thy honest son,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Who will of thy arrival be full joyous.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But is it true? or else is it your pleasure,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Like pleasant travellers, to break a jest

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Upon the company you overtake?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I do assure thee, father, so it is.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Come, go along, and see the truth hereof,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For our first merriment hath made thee jealous.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Exeunt all but HORTENSIO

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Well, Petruchio, this has put me in heart.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Have to my widow! and if she be froward,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Then hast thou taught Hortensio to be untoward.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: SCENE I. Padua. Before LUCENTIO'S house.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: GREMIO discovered. Enter behind BIONDELLO, LUCENTIO, and BIANCA

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Softly and swiftly, sir, for the priest is ready.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I fly, Biondello: but they may chance to need thee

Author: Shakespeare
Text: at home, therefore leave us.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Nay, faith, I'll see the church o' your back, and

Author: Shakespeare
Text: then come back to my master's as soon as I can.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Exeunt LUCENTIO, BIANCA, and BIONDELLO

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I marvel Cambio comes not all this while.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter PETRUCHIO, KATHARINA, VINCENTIO, GRUMIO, with Attendants

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sir, here's the door, this is Lucentio's house:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My father's bears more toward the market-place,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thither must I, and here I leave you, sir.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You shall not choose but drink before you go:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I think I shall command your welcome here,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And, by all likelihood, some cheer is toward.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: They're busy within, you were best knock louder.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Pedant looks out of the window

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What's he that knocks as he would beat down the gate?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Is Signior Lucentio within, sir?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: He's within, sir, but not to be spoken withal.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What if a man bring him a hundred pound or two, to

Author: Shakespeare
Text: make merry withal?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Keep your hundred pounds to yourself: he shall

Author: Shakespeare
Text: need none, so long as I live.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Nay, I told you your son was well beloved in Padua.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Do you hear, sir? To leave frivolous circumstances,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I pray you, tell Signior Lucentio that his father is

Author: Shakespeare
Text: come from Pisa, and is here at the door to speak with him.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thou liest: his father is come from Padua and here

Author: Shakespeare
Text: looking out at the window.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Art thou his father?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, sir, so his mother says, if I may believe her.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: [To VINCENTIO]  Why, how now, gentleman! why, this

Author: Shakespeare
Text: is flat knavery, to take upon you another man's name.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Lay hands on the villain: I believe a' means to

Author: Shakespeare
Text: cozen somebody in this city under my countenance.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I have seen them in the church together: God send

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'em good shipping! But who is here? mine old

Author: Shakespeare
Text: master Vincentio! now we are undone and brought to nothing.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: [Seeing BIONDELLO]

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Come hither, crack-hemp.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Hope I may choose, sir.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Come hither, you rogue. What, have you forgot me?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Forgot you! no, sir: I could not forget you, for I

Author: Shakespeare
Text: never saw you before in all my life.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What, you notorious villain, didst thou never see

Author: Shakespeare
Text: thy master's father, Vincentio?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What, my old worshipful old master? yes, marry, sir:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: see where he looks out of the window.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Is't so, indeed.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Beats BIONDELLO

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Help, help, help! here's a madman will murder me.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Help, son! help, Signior Baptista!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Exit from above

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Prithee, Kate, let's stand aside and see the end of

Author: Shakespeare
Text: this controversy.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Re-enter Pedant below, TRANIO, BAPTISTA, and Servants

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sir, what are you that offer to beat my servant?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What am I, sir! nay, what are you, sir? O immortal

Author: Shakespeare
Text: gods! O fine villain! A silken doublet! a velvet

Author: Shakespeare
Text: hose! a scarlet cloak! and a copatain hat! O, I

Author: Shakespeare
Text: am undone! I am undone! while I play the good

Author: Shakespeare
Text: husband at home, my son and my servant spend all at

Author: Shakespeare
Text: the university.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What, is the man lunatic?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sir, you seem a sober ancient gentleman by your

Author: Shakespeare
Text: habit, but your words show you a madman. Why, sir,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: what 'cerns it you if I wear pearl and gold? I

Author: Shakespeare
Text: thank my good father, I am able to maintain it.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thy father! O villain! he is a sailmaker in Bergamo.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You mistake, sir, you mistake, sir. Pray, what do

Author: Shakespeare
Text: you think is his name?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: His name! as if I knew not his name: I have brought

Author: Shakespeare
Text: him up ever since he was three years old, and his

Author: Shakespeare
Text: name is Tranio.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Away, away, mad ass! his name is Lucentio and he is

Author: Shakespeare
Text: mine only son, and heir to the lands of me, Signior Vincentio.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Lucentio! O, he hath murdered his master! Lay hold

Author: Shakespeare
Text: on him, I charge you, in the duke's name. O, my

Author: Shakespeare
Text: son, my son! Tell me, thou villain, where is my son Lucentio?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Call forth an officer.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter one with an Officer

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Carry this mad knave to the gaol. Father Baptista,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I charge you see that he be forthcoming.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Carry me to the gaol!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Stay, officer: he shall not go to prison.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Talk not, Signior Gremio: I say he shall go to prison.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Take heed, Signior Baptista, lest you be

Author: Shakespeare
Text: cony-catched in this business: I dare swear this

Author: Shakespeare
Text: is the right Vincentio.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Swear, if thou darest.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Nay, I dare not swear it.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Then thou wert best say that I am not Lucentio.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Yes, I know thee to be Signior Lucentio.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Away with the dotard! to the gaol with him!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thus strangers may be hailed and abused: O

Author: Shakespeare
Text: monstrous villain!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Re-enter BIONDELLO, with LUCENTIO and BIANCA

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O! we are spoiled and--yonder he is: deny him,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: forswear him, or else we are all undone.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: [Kneeling]  Pardon, sweet father.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Lives my sweet son?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Exeunt BIONDELLO, TRANIO, and Pedant, as fast as may be

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Pardon, dear father.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How hast thou offended?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Where is Lucentio?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Here's Lucentio,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Right son to the right Vincentio,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That have by marriage made thy daughter mine,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: While counterfeit supposes bleared thine eyne.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Here's packing, with a witness to deceive us all!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Where is that damned villain Tranio,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That faced and braved me in this matter so?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, tell me, is not this my Cambio?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Cambio is changed into Lucentio.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Love wrought these miracles. Bianca's love

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Made me exchange my state with Tranio,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: While he did bear my countenance in the town,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And happily I have arrived at the last

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Unto the wished haven of my bliss.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What Tranio did, myself enforced him to,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Then pardon him, sweet father, for my sake.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I'll slit the villain's nose, that would have sent

Author: Shakespeare
Text: me to the gaol.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But do you hear, sir? have you married my daughter

Author: Shakespeare
Text: without asking my good will?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Fear not, Baptista, we will content you, go to: but

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I will in, to be revenged for this villany.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And I, to sound the depth of this knavery.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Look not pale, Bianca, thy father will not frown.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My cake is dough, but I'll in among the rest,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Out of hope of all, but my share of the feast.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Husband, let's follow, to see the end of this ado.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: First kiss me, Kate, and we will.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What, in the midst of the street?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What, art thou ashamed of me?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: No, sir, God forbid, but ashamed to kiss.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, then let's home again. Come, sirrah, let's away.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Nay, I will give thee a kiss: now pray thee, love, stay.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Is not this well? Come, my sweet Kate:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Better once than never, for never too late.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: SCENE II. Padua. LUCENTIO'S house.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter BAPTISTA, VINCENTIO, GREMIO, the Pedant,  LUCENTIO, BIANCA, PETRUCHIO, KATHARINA, HORTENSIO,  and Widow, TRANIO, BIONDELLO, and GRUMIO the Serving-men with Tranio bringing in a banquet

Author: Shakespeare
Text: At last, though long, our jarring notes agree:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And time it is, when raging war is done,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To smile at scapes and perils overblown.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My fair Bianca, bid my father welcome,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: While I with self-same kindness welcome thine.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Brother Petruchio, sister Katharina,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And thou, Hortensio, with thy loving widow,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Feast with the best, and welcome to my house:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My banquet is to close our stomachs up,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: After our great good cheer. Pray you, sit down,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For now we sit to chat as well as eat.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Nothing but sit and sit, and eat and eat!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Padua affords this kindness, son Petruchio.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Padua affords nothing but what is kind.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For both our sakes, I would that word were true.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Now, for my life, Hortensio fears his widow.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Then never trust me, if I be afeard.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You are very sensible, and yet you miss my sense:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I mean, Hortensio is afeard of you.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: He that is giddy thinks the world turns round.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Roundly replied.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Mistress, how mean you that?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thus I conceive by him.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Conceives by me! How likes Hortensio that?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My widow says, thus she conceives her tale.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Very well mended. Kiss him for that, good widow.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'He that is giddy thinks the world turns round:'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I pray you, tell me what you meant by that.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Your husband, being troubled with a shrew,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Measures my husband's sorrow by his woe:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And now you know my meaning,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A very mean meaning.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Right, I mean you.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And I am mean indeed, respecting you.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To her, Kate!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To her, widow!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A hundred marks, my Kate does put her down.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That's my office.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Spoke like an officer, ha' to thee, lad!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Drinks to HORTENSIO

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How likes Gremio these quick-witted folks?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Believe me, sir, they butt together well.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Head, and butt! an hasty-witted body

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Would say your head and butt were head and horn.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, mistress bride, hath that awaken'd you?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, but not frighted me, therefore I'll sleep again.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Nay, that you shall not: since you have begun,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Have at you for a bitter jest or two!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Am I your bird? I mean to shift my bush,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And then pursue me as you draw your bow.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You are welcome all.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Exeunt BIANCA, KATHARINA, and Widow

Author: Shakespeare
Text: She hath prevented me. Here, Signior Tranio.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: This bird you aim'd at, though you hit her not,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Therefore a health to all that shot and miss'd.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O, sir, Lucentio slipp'd me like his greyhound,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Which runs himself and catches for his master.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A good swift simile, but something currish.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Tis well, sir, that you hunted for yourself:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Tis thought your deer does hold you at a bay.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O ho, Petruchio! Tranio hits you now.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I thank thee for that gird, good Tranio.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Confess, confess, hath he not hit you here?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A' has a little gall'd me, I confess,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And, as the jest did glance away from me,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Tis ten to one it maim'd you two outright.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Now, in good sadness, son Petruchio,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I think thou hast the veriest shrew of all.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Well, I say no: and therefore for assurance

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Let's each one send unto his wife,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And he whose wife is most obedient

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To come at first when he doth send for her,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Shall win the wager which we will propose.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Content. What is the wager?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Twenty crowns.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Twenty crowns!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I'll venture so much of my hawk or hound,

Text: Trumpets sound. Enter TIMON, addressing himself  courteously to every suitor, a Messenger from  VENTIDIUS talking with him, LUCILIUS and other servants following

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Imprison'd is he, say you?

Text: To those have shut him up, which failing,

Text: A gentleman that well deserves a help:

Text: And being enfranchised, bid him come to me.

Text: 'Tis not enough to help the feeble up,

Text: But to support him after. Fare you well.

Text: All happiness to your honour!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Lord Timon, hear me speak.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Most noble Timon, call the man before thee.

Text: Attends he here, or no? Lucilius!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Here, at your lordship's service.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: This fellow here, Lord Timon, this thy creature,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: By night frequents my house. I am a man

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That from my first have been inclined to thrift,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And my estate deserves an heir more raised

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Than one which holds a trencher.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Well, what further?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: One only daughter have I, no kin else,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: On whom I may confer what I have got:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The maid is fair, o' the youngest for a bride,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And I have bred her at my dearest cost

Author: Shakespeare
Text: In qualities of the best. This man of thine

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Attempts her love: I prithee, noble lord,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Join with me to forbid him her resort,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Myself have spoke in vain.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The man is honest.

Text: Therefore he will be, Timon:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: His honesty rewards him in itself,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: It must not bear my daughter.

Text: She is young and apt:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Our own precedent passions do instruct us

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What levity's in youth.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: [To LUCILIUS]           Love you the maid?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, my good lord, and she accepts of it.

Text: If in her marriage my consent be missing,

Text: I call the gods to witness, I will choose

Text: And dispossess her all.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: This gentleman of mine hath served me long:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To build his fortune I will strain a little,

Text: And make him weigh with her.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Most noble lord,

Author: Shakespeare

Text: Thou disease of a friend, and not himself!

Text: Has friendship such a faint and milky heart,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: It turns in less than two nights? O you gods,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I feel master's passion! this slave,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Unto his honour, has my lord's meat in him:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why should it thrive and turn to nutriment,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: When he is turn'd to poison?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O, may diseases only work upon't!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And, when he's sick to death, let not that part of nature
