Text: Which my lord paid for, be of any power

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To expel sickness, but prolong his hour!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter LUCILIUS, with three Strangers

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Who, the Lord Timon? he is my very good friend, and

Author: Shakespeare
Text: an honourable gentleman.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: We know him for no less, though we are but strangers

Author: Shakespeare
Text: to him. But I can tell you one thing, my lord, and

Author: Shakespeare
Text: which I hear from common rumours: now Lord Timon's

Author: Shakespeare
Text: happy hours are done and past, and his estate

Author: Shakespeare
Text: shrinks from him.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Fie, no, do not believe it, he cannot want for money.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But believe you this, my lord, that, not long ago,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: one of his men was with the Lord Lucullus to borrow

Author: Shakespeare
Text: so many talents, nay, urged extremely for't and

Author: Shakespeare
Text: showed what necessity belonged to't, and yet was denied.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I tell you, denied, my lord.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What a strange case was that! now, before the gods,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I am ashamed on't. Denied that honourable man!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: there was very little honour showed in't. For my own

Author: Shakespeare
Text: part, I must needs confess, I have received some

Author: Shakespeare
Text: small kindnesses from him, as money, plate, jewels

Author: Shakespeare
Text: and such-like trifles, nothing comparing to his,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: yet, had he mistook him and sent to me, I should

Author: Shakespeare
Text: ne'er have denied his occasion so many talents.

Text: Enter SERVILIUS

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter SERVILIUS

Author: Shakespeare
Text: See, by good hap, yonder's my lord,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To LUCIUS

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Servilius! you are kindly met, sir. Fare thee well:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: commend me to thy honourable virtuous lord, my very

Author: Shakespeare
Text: exquisite friend.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: May it please your honour, my lord hath sent--

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ha! what has he sent? I am so much endeared to

Author: Shakespeare
Text: that lord, he's ever sending: how shall I thank

Author: Shakespeare
Text: him, thinkest thou? And what has he sent now?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Has only sent his present occasion now, my lord,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: requesting your lordship to supply his instant use

Author: Shakespeare
Text: with so many talents.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I know his lordship is but merry with me,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: He cannot want fifty five hundred talents.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But in the mean time he wants less, my lord.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If his occasion were not virtuous,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I should not urge it half so faithfully.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Dost thou speak seriously, Servilius?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Upon my soul,'tis true, sir.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What a wicked beast was I to disfurnish myself

Author: Shakespeare
Text: against such a good time, when I might ha' shown

Author: Shakespeare
Text: myself honourable! how unluckily it happened, that I

Author: Shakespeare
Text: should purchase the day before for a little part,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: and undo a great deal of honoured! Servilius, now,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: before the gods, I am not able to do,--the more

Author: Shakespeare
Text: beast, I say:--I was sending to use Lord Timon

Author: Shakespeare
Text: myself, these gentlemen can witness! but I would

Author: Shakespeare
Text: not, for the wealth of Athens, I had done't now.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Commend me bountifully to his good lordship, and I

Author: Shakespeare
Text: hope his honour will conceive the fairest of me,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: because I have no power to be kind: and tell him

Author: Shakespeare
Text: this from me, I count it one of my greatest

Author: Shakespeare

Author: Shakespeare
Text: honourable gentleman. Good Servilius, will you

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Yes, sir, I shall.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I'll look you out a good turn, Servilius.

Author: Shakespeare

Text: 'Tis thou that rigg'st the bark and plough'st the foam,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Settlest admired reverence in a slave:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To thee be worship! and thy saints for aye

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Be crown'd with plagues that thee alone obey!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Fit I meet them.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Hail, worthy Timon!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Our late noble master!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Have I once lived to see two honest men?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Having often of your open bounty tasted,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Hearing you were retired, your friends fall'n off,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Whose thankless natures--O abhorred spirits!--

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Not all the whips of heaven are large enough:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What! to you,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Whose star-like nobleness gave life and influence

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To their whole being! I am rapt and cannot cover

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The monstrous bulk of this ingratitude

Author: Shakespeare
Text: With any size of words.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Let it go naked, men may see't the better:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You that are honest, by being what you are,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Make them best seen and known.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: He and myself

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Have travail'd in the great shower of your gifts,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And sweetly felt it.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, you are honest men.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: We are hither come to offer you our service.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Most honest men! Why, how shall I requite you?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Can you eat roots, and drink cold water? no.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What we can do, we'll do, to do you service.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ye're honest men: ye've heard that I have gold,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I am sure you have: speak truth, ye're honest men.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: So it is said, my noble lord, but therefore

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Came not my friend nor I.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Good honest men! Thou draw'st a counterfeit

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Best in all Athens: thou'rt, indeed, the best,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thou counterfeit'st most lively.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: So, so, my lord.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: E'en so, sir, as I say. And, for thy fiction,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, thy verse swells with stuff so fine and smooth

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That thou art even natural in thine art.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But, for all this, my honest-natured friends,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I must needs say you have a little fault:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Marry, 'tis not monstrous in you, neither wish I

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You take much pains to mend.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Beseech your honour

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To make it known to us.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You'll take it ill.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Will you, indeed?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Doubt it not, worthy lord.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: There's never a one of you but trusts a knave,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That mightily deceives you.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Do we, my lord?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, and you hear him cog, see him dissemble,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Know his gross patchery, love him, feed him,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Keep in your bosom: yet remain assured

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That he's a made-up villain.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I know none such, my lord.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Look you, I love you well, I'll give you gold,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Rid me these villains from your companies:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Hang them or stab them, drown them in a draught,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Confound them by some course, and come to me,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I'll give you gold enough.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Name them, my lord, let's know them.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You that way and you this, but two in company,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Each man apart, all single and alone,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Yet an arch-villain keeps him company.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If where thou art two villains shall not be,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Come not near him. If thou wouldst not reside

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But where one villain is, then him abandon.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Hence, pack! there's gold, you came for gold, ye slaves:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To Painter

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You have work'd for me, there's payment for you: hence!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To Poet

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You are an alchemist, make gold of that.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Out, rascal dogs!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Beats them out, and then retires to his cave

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter FLAVIUS and two Senators

Author: Shakespeare
Text: It is in vain that you would speak with Timon,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For he is set so only to himself

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That nothing but himself which looks like man

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Is friendly with him.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Bring us to his cave:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: It is our part and promise to the Athenians

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To speak with Timon.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: At all times alike

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Men are not still the same: 'twas time and griefs

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That framed him thus: time, with his fairer hand,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Offering the fortunes of his former days,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The former man may make him. Bring us to him,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And chance it as it may.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Here is his cave.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Peace and content be here! Lord Timon! Timon!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Look out, and speak to friends: the Athenians,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: By two of their most reverend senate, greet thee:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Speak to them, noble Timon.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: TIMON comes from his cave

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thou sun, that comfort'st, burn! Speak, and

Author: Shakespeare
Text: be hang'd:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For each true word, a blister! and each false

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Be as cauterizing to the root o' the tongue,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Consuming it with speaking!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Worthy Timon,--

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Of none but such as you, and you of Timon.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The senators of Athens greet thee, Timon.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I thank them, and would send them back the plague,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Could I but catch it for them.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O, forget

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What we are sorry for ourselves in thee.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The senators with one consent of love

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Entreat thee back to Athens, who have thought

Author: Shakespeare
Text: On special dignities, which vacant lie

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For thy best use and wearing.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: They confess

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Toward thee forgetfulness too general, gross:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Which now the public body, which doth seldom

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Play the recanter, feeling in itself

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A lack of Timon's aid, hath sense withal

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Of its own fail, restraining aid to Timon,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And send forth us, to make their sorrow'd render,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Together with a recompense more fruitful

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Than their offence can weigh down by the dram,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, even such heaps and sums of love and wealth

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As shall to thee blot out what wrongs were theirs

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And write in thee the figures of their love,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ever to read them thine.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You witch me in it,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Surprise me to the very brink of tears:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Lend me a fool's heart and a woman's eyes,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And I'll beweep these comforts, worthy senators.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Therefore, so please thee to return with us

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And of our Athens, thine and ours, to take

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The captainship, thou shalt be met with thanks,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Allow'd with absolute power and thy good name

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Live with authority: so soon we shall drive back

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Of Alcibiades the approaches wild,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Who, like a boar too savage, doth root up

Author: Shakespeare
Text: His country's peace.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And shakes his threatening sword

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Against the walls of Athens.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Therefore, Timon,--

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Well, sir, I will, therefore, I will, sir, thus:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If Alcibiades kill my countrymen,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Let Alcibiades know this of Timon,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That Timon cares not. But if be sack fair Athens,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And take our goodly aged men by the beards,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Giving our holy virgins to the stain

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Of contumelious, beastly, mad-brain'd war,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Then let him know, and tell him Timon speaks it,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: In pity of our aged and our youth,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I cannot choose but tell him, that I care not,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And let him take't at worst, for their knives care not,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: While you have throats to answer: for myself,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: There's not a whittle in the unruly camp

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But I do prize it at my love before

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The reverend'st throat in Athens. So I leave you

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To the protection of the prosperous gods,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As thieves to keepers.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Stay not, all's in vain.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, I was writing of my epitaph,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: it will be seen to-morrow: my long sickness

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Of health and living now begins to mend,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And nothing brings me all things. Go, live still,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Be Alcibiades your plague, you his,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And last so long enough!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: We speak in vain.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But yet I love my country, and am not

Author: Shakespeare
Text: One that rejoices in the common wreck,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As common bruit doth put it.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That's well spoke.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Commend me to my loving countrymen,--

Author: Shakespeare
Text: These words become your lips as they pass

Author: Shakespeare
Text: thorough them.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And enter in our ears like great triumphers

Author: Shakespeare
Text: In their applauding gates.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Commend me to them,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And tell them that, to ease them of their griefs,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Their fears of hostile strokes, their aches, losses,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Their pangs of love, with other incident throes

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That nature's fragile vessel doth sustain

Author: Shakespeare
Text: In life's uncertain voyage, I will some kindness do them:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I'll teach them to prevent wild Alcibiades' wrath.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I like this well, he will return again.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I have a tree, which grows here in my close,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That mine own use invites me to cut down,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And shortly must I fell it: tell my friends,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Tell Athens, in the sequence of degree

Author: Shakespeare
Text: From high to low throughout, that whoso please

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To stop affliction, let him take his haste,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Come hither, ere my tree hath felt the axe,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And hang himself. I pray you, do my greeting.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Trouble him no further, thus you still shall find him.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Come not to me again: but say to Athens,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Timon hath made his everlasting mansion

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Upon the beached verge of the salt flood,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Who once a day with his embossed froth

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The turbulent surge shall cover: thither come,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And let my grave-stone be your oracle.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Lips, let sour words go by and language end:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What is amiss plague and infection mend!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Graves only be men's works and death their gain!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sun, hide thy beams! Timon hath done his reign.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Retires to his cave

Author: Shakespeare
Text: His discontents are unremoveably

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Coupled to nature.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Our hope in him is dead: let us return,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And strain what other means is left unto us

Author: Shakespeare
Text: In our dear peril.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: It requires swift foot.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: SCENE II. Before the walls of Athens.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter two Senators and a Messenger

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thou hast painfully discover'd: are his files

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As full as thy report?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: have spoke the least:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Besides, his expedition promises

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Present approach.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: We stand much hazard, if they bring not Timon.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I met a courier, one mine ancient friend,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Whom, though in general part we were opposed,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Yet our old love made a particular force,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And made us speak like friends: this man was riding

Author: Shakespeare
Text: From Alcibiades to Timon's cave,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: With letters of entreaty, which imported

Author: Shakespeare
Text: His fellowship i' the cause against your city,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: In part for his sake moved.

Text: Here come our brothers.

Text: Enter the Senators from TIMON

Author: Shakespeare
Text: No talk of Timon, nothing of him expect.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The enemies' drum is heard, and fearful scouring

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Doth choke the air with dust: in, and prepare:

Text: Ours is the fall, I fear, our foes the snare.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: SCENE III. The woods. Timon's cave, and a rude tomb seen.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter a Soldier, seeking TIMON

Author: Shakespeare
Text: By all description this should be the place.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Who's here? speak, ho! No answer! What is this?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Timon is dead, who hath outstretch'd his span:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Some beast rear'd this, there does not live a man.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Dead, sure, and this his grave. What's on this tomb

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I cannot read, the character I'll take with wax:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Our captain hath in every figure skill,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: An aged interpreter, though young in days:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Before proud Athens he's set down by this,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Whose fall the mark of his ambition is.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: SCENE IV. Before the walls of Athens.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Trumpets sound. Enter ALCIBIADES with his powers

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sound to this coward and lascivious town

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Our terrible approach.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter Senators on the walls

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Till now you have gone on and fill'd the time

Author: Shakespeare
Text: With all licentious measure, making your wills

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The scope of justice, till now myself and such

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As slept within the shadow of your power

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Hav e wander'd with our traversed arms and breathed

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Our sufferance vainly: now the time is flush,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: When crouching marrow in the bearer strong

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Cries of itself 'No more:' now breathless wrong

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Shall sit and pant in your great chairs of ease,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And pursy insolence shall break his wind

Author: Shakespeare
Text: With fear and horrid flight.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Noble and young,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: When thy first griefs were but a mere conceit,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ere thou hadst power or we had cause of fear,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: We sent to thee, to give thy rages balm,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To wipe out our ingratitude with loves

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Above their quantity.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: So did we woo

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Transformed Timon to our city's love

Author: Shakespeare
Text: By humble message and by promised means:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: We were not all unkind, nor all deserve

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The common stroke of war.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: These walls of ours

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Were not erected by their hands from whom

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You have received your griefs, nor are they such

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That these great towers, trophies and schools

Author: Shakespeare
Text: should fall

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For private faults in them.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Nor are they living

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Who were the motives that you first went out,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Shame that they wanted cunning, in excess

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Hath broke their hearts. March, noble lord,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Into our city with thy banners spread:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: By decimation, and a tithed death--

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If thy revenges hunger for that food

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Which nature loathes--take thou the destined tenth,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And by the hazard of the spotted die

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Let die the spotted.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: All have not offended,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For those that were, it is not square to take

Author: Shakespeare
Text: On those that are, revenges: crimes, like lands,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Are not inherited. Then, dear countryman,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Bring in thy ranks, but leave without thy rage:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Spare thy Athenian cradle and those kin

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Which in the bluster of thy wrath must fall

Author: Shakespeare
Text: With those that have offended: like a shepherd,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Approach the fold and cull the infected forth,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But kill not all together.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What thou wilt,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thou rather shalt enforce it with thy smile

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Than hew to't with thy sword.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Set but thy foot

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Against our rampired gates, and they shall ope,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: So thou wilt send thy gentle heart before,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To say thou'lt enter friendly.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Throw thy glove,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Or any token of thine honour else,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That thou wilt use the wars as thy redress

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And not as our confusion, all thy powers

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Shall make their harbour in our town, till we

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Have seal'd thy full desire.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Then there's my glove,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Descend, and open your uncharged ports:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Those enemies of Timon's and mine own

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Whom you yourselves shall set out for reproof

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Fall and no more: and, to atone your fears

Author: Shakespeare
Text: With my more noble meaning, not a man

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Shall pass his quarter, or offend the stream

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Of regular justice in your city's bounds,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But shall be render'd to your public laws

Author: Shakespeare
Text: At heaviest answer.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Tis most nobly spoken.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Descend, and keep your words.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The Senators descend, and open the gates

Text: Enter Soldier

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My noble general, Timon is dead,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Entomb'd upon the very hem o' the sea,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And on his grave-stone this insculpture, which

Author: Shakespeare
Text: With wax I brought away, whose soft impression

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Interprets for my poor ignorance.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: [Reads the epitaph]  'Here lies a

Author: Shakespeare
Text: wretched corse, of wretched soul bereft:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Seek not my name: a plague consume you wicked

Author: Shakespeare
Text: caitiffs left!

Text: Here lie I, Timon, who, alive, all living men did hate:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Pass by and curse thy fill, but pass and stay

Author: Shakespeare
Text: not here thy gait.'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: These well express in thee thy latter spirits:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Though thou abhorr'dst in us our human griefs,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Scorn'dst our brain's flow and those our

Author: Shakespeare
Text: droplets which

Author: Shakespeare
Text: From niggard nature fall, yet rich conceit

Text: Taught thee to make vast Neptune weep for aye

Author: Shakespeare
Text: On thy low grave, on faults forgiven. Dead

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Is noble Timon: of whose memory

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Hereafter more. Bring me into your city,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And I will use the olive with my sword,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Make war breed peace, make peace stint war, make each

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Prescribe to other as each other's leech.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: SCENE I. Rome. Before the Capitol.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The Tomb of the ANDRONICI appearing, the Tribunes  and Senators aloft. Enter, below, from one side,  SATURNINUS and his Followers, and, from the other side, BASSIANUS and his Followers, with drum and colours

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Noble patricians, patrons of my right,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Defend the justice of my cause with arms,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And, countrymen, my loving followers,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Plead my successive title with your swords:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I am his first-born son, that was the last

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That wore the imperial diadem of Rome,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Then let my father's honours live in me,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Nor wrong mine age with this indignity.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Romans, friends, followers, favorers of my right,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If ever Bassianus, Caesar's son,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Were gracious in the eyes of royal Rome,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Keep then this passage to the Capitol

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And suffer not dishonour to approach

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The imperial seat, to virtue consecrate,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To justice, continence and nobility,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But let desert in pure election shine,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And, Romans, fight for freedom in your choice.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter MARCUS ANDRONICUS, aloft, with the crown

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Princes, that strive by factions and by friends

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ambitiously for rule and empery,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Know that the people of Rome, for whom we stand

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A special party, have, by common voice,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: In election for the Roman empery,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Chosen Andronicus, surnamed Pius

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For many good and great deserts to Rome:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A nobler man, a braver warrior,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Lives not this day within the city walls:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: He by the senate is accit'd home

Author: Shakespeare
Text: From weary wars against the barbarous Goths,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That, with his sons, a terror to our foes,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Hath yoked a nation strong, train'd up in arms.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ten years are spent since first he undertook

Author: Shakespeare
Text: This cause of Rome and chastised with arms

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Our enemies' pride: five times he hath return'd

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Bleeding to Rome, bearing his valiant sons

Author: Shakespeare
Text: In coffins from the field,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And now at last, laden with horror's spoils,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Returns the good Andronicus to Rome,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Renowned Titus, flourishing in arms.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Let us entreat, by honour of his name,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Whom worthily you would have now succeed.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And in the Capitol and senate's right,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Whom you pretend to honour and adore,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That you withdraw you and abate your strength,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Dismiss your followers and, as suitors should,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Plead your deserts in peace and humbleness.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How fair the tribune speaks to calm my thoughts!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Marcus Andronicus, so I do ally

Author: Shakespeare
Text: In thy uprightness and integrity,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And so I love and honour thee and thine,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thy noble brother Titus and his sons,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And her to whom my thoughts are humbled all,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Gracious Lavinia, Rome's rich ornament,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That I will here dismiss my loving friends,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And to my fortunes and the people's favor

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Commit my cause in balance to be weigh'd.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Exeunt the followers of BASSIANUS

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Friends, that have been thus forward in my right,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I thank you all and here dismiss you all,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And to the love and favor of my country

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Commit myself, my person and the cause.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Exeunt the followers of SATURNINUS

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Rome, be as just and gracious unto me

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As I am confident and kind to thee.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Open the gates, and let me in.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Tribunes, and me, a poor competitor.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Flourish. SATURNINUS and BASSIANUS go up into the Capitol

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Romans, make way: the good Andronicus.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Patron of virtue, Rome's best champion,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Successful in the battles that he fights,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: With honour and with fortune is return'd

Author: Shakespeare
Text: From where he circumscribed with his sword,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And brought to yoke, the enemies of Rome.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Drums and trumpets sounded. Enter MARTIUS and  MUTIUS, After them, two Men bearing a coffin  covered with black, then LUCIUS and QUINTUS. After  them, TITUS ANDRONICUS, and then TAMORA, with  ALARBUS, DEMETRIUS, CHIRON, AARON, and other Goths,  prisoners, Soldiers and people following. The Bearers set down the coffin, and TITUS speaks

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Hail, Rome, victorious in thy mourning weeds!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Lo, as the bark, that hath discharged her fraught,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Returns with precious jading to the bay

Author: Shakespeare
Text: From whence at first she weigh'd her anchorage,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Cometh Andronicus, bound with laurel boughs,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To re-salute his country with his tears,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Tears of true joy for his return to Rome.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thou great defender of this Capitol,

Author: Shakespeare
