Text: This day all quarrels die, Andronicus,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And let it be mine honour, good my lord,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That I have reconciled your friends and you.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For you, Prince Bassianus, I have pass'd

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My word and promise to the emperor,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That you will be more mild and tractable.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And fear not lords, and you, Lavinia,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: By my advice, all humbled on your knees,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You shall ask pardon of his majesty.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: We do, and vow to heaven and to his highness,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That what we did was mildly as we might,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Tendering our sister's honour and our own.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That, on mine honour, here I do protest.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Away, and talk not, trouble us no more.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Nay, nay, sweet emperor, we must all be friends:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The tribune and his nephews kneel for grace,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I will not be denied: sweet heart, look back.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Marcus, for thy sake and thy brother's here,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And at my lovely Tamora's entreats,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I do remit these young men's heinous faults: Stand up.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Lavinia, though you left me like a churl,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I found a friend, and sure as death I swore

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I would not part a bachelor from the priest.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Come, if the emperor's court can feast two brides,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You are my guest, Lavinia, and your friends.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: This day shall be a love-day, Tamora.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To-morrow, an it please your majesty

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To hunt the panther and the hart with me,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: With horn and hound we'll give your grace bonjour.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Be it so, Titus, and gramercy too.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: SCENE I. Rome. Before the Palace.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter AARON

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter AARON

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Now climbeth Tamora Olympus' top,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Safe out of fortune's shot, and sits aloft,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Secure of thunder's crack or lightning flash,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Advanced above pale envy's threatening reach.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As when the golden sun salutes the morn,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And, having gilt the ocean with his beams,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Gallops the zodiac in his glistering coach,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And overlooks the highest-peering hills,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: So Tamora:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Upon her wit doth earthly honour wait,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And virtue stoops and trembles at her frown.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Then, Aaron, arm thy heart, and fit thy thoughts,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To mount aloft with thy imperial mistress,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And mount her pitch, whom thou in triumph long

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Hast prisoner held, fetter'd in amorous chains

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And faster bound to Aaron's charming eyes

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Than is Prometheus tied to Caucasus.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Away with slavish weeds and servile thoughts!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I will be bright, and shine in pearl and gold,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To wait upon this new-made empress.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To wait, said I? to wanton with this queen,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: This goddess, this Semiramis, this nymph,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: This siren, that will charm Rome's Saturnine,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And see his shipwreck and his commonweal's.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Holloa! what storm is this?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter DEMETRIUS and CHIRON, braving

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Chiron, thy years want wit, thy wit wants edge,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And manners, to intrude where I am graced,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And may, for aught thou know'st, affected be.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Demetrius, thou dost over-ween in all,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And so in this, to bear me down with braves.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Tis not the difference of a year or two

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Makes me less gracious or thee more fortunate:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I am as able and as fit as thou

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To serve, and to deserve my mistress' grace,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And that my sword upon thee shall approve,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And plead my passions for Lavinia's love.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: [Aside]  Clubs, clubs! these lovers will not keep

Author: Shakespeare
Text: the peace.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, boy, although our mother, unadvised,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Gave you a dancing-rapier by your side,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Are you so desperate grown, to threat your friends?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Go to, have your lath glued within your sheath

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Till you know better how to handle it.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Meanwhile, sir, with the little skill I have,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Full well shalt thou perceive how much I dare.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, boy, grow ye so brave?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: [Coming forward]  Why, how now, lords!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: So near the emperor's palace dare you draw,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And maintain such a quarrel openly?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Full well I wot the ground of all this grudge:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I would not for a million of gold

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The cause were known to them it most concerns,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Nor would your noble mother for much more

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Be so dishonour'd in the court of Rome.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For shame, put up.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Not I, till I have sheathed

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My rapier in his bosom and withal

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thrust these reproachful speeches down his throat

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That he hath breathed in my dishonour here.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For that I am prepared and full resolved.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Foul-spoken coward, that thunder'st with thy tongue,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And with thy weapon nothing darest perform!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Away, I say!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Now, by the gods that warlike Goths adore,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: This petty brabble will undo us all.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, lords, and think you not how dangerous

Author: Shakespeare
Text: It is to jet upon a prince's right?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What, is Lavinia then become so loose,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Or Bassianus so degenerate,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That for her love such quarrels may be broach'd

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Without controlment, justice, or revenge?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Young lords, beware! and should the empress know

Author: Shakespeare
Text: This discord's ground, the music would not please.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I care not, I, knew she and all the world:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I love Lavinia more than all the world.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Youngling, learn thou to make some meaner choice:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Lavinia is thine elder brother's hope.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, are ye mad? or know ye not, in Rome

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How furious and impatient they be,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And cannot brook competitors in love?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I tell you, lords, you do but plot your deaths

Author: Shakespeare
Text: By this device.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Aaron, a thousand deaths

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Would I propose to achieve her whom I love.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To achieve her! how?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why makest thou it so strange?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: She is a woman, therefore may be woo'd,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: She is a woman, therefore may be won,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: She is Lavinia, therefore must be loved.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What, man! more water glideth by the mill

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Than wots the miller of, and easy it is

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Of a cut loaf to steal a shive, we know:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Though Bassianus be the emperor's brother.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Better than he have worn Vulcan's badge.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: [Aside]  Ay, and as good as Saturninus may.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Then why should he despair that knows to court it

Author: Shakespeare
Text: With words, fair looks and liberality?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What, hast not thou full often struck a doe,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And borne her cleanly by the keeper's nose?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, then, it seems, some certain snatch or so

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Would serve your turns.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, so the turn were served.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Aaron, thou hast hit it.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Would you had hit it too!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Then should not we be tired with this ado.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, hark ye, hark ye! and are you such fools

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To square for this? would it offend you, then

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That both should speed?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Faith, not me.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Nor me, so I were one.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For shame, be friends, and join for that you jar:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Tis policy and stratagem must do

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That you affect, and so must you resolve,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That what you cannot as you would achieve,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You must perforce accomplish as you may.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Take this of me: Lucrece was not more chaste

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Than this Lavinia, Bassianus' love.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A speedier course than lingering languishment

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Must we pursue, and I have found the path.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My lords, a solemn hunting is in hand,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: There will the lovely Roman ladies troop:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The forest walks are wide and spacious,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And many unfrequented plots there are

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Fitted by kind for rape and villany:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Single you thither then this dainty doe,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And strike her home by force, if not by words:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: This way, or not at all, stand you in hope.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Come, come, our empress, with her sacred wit

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To villany and vengeance consecrate,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Will we acquaint with all that we intend,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And she shall file our engines with advice,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That will not suffer you to square yourselves,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But to your wishes' height advance you both.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The emperor's court is like the house of Fame,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The palace full of tongues, of eyes, and ears:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The woods are ruthless, dreadful, deaf, and dull,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: There speak, and strike, brave boys, and take

Author: Shakespeare
Text: your turns,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: There serve your lusts, shadow'd from heaven's eye,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And revel in Lavinia's treasury.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thy counsel, lad, smells of no cowardice,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sit fas aut nefas, till I find the stream

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To cool this heat, a charm to calm these fits.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Per Styga, per manes vehor.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: SCENE II. A forest near Rome. Horns and cry of hounds heard.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter TITUS ANDRONICUS, with Hunters,  and c., MARCUS, LUCIUS, QUINTUS, and MARTIUS

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The hunt is up, the morn is bright and grey,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The fields are fragrant and the woods are green:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Uncouple here and let us make a bay

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And wake the emperor and his lovely bride

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And rouse the prince and ring a hunter's peal,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That all the court may echo with the noise.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sons, let it be your charge, as it is ours,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To attend the emperor's person carefully:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I have been troubled in my sleep this night,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But dawning day new comfort hath inspired.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A cry of hounds and horns, winded in a peal. Enter  SATURNINUS, TAMORA, BASSIANUS, LAVINIA, DEMETRIUS, CHIRON, and Attendants

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Many good morrows to your majesty,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Madam, to you as many and as good:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I promised your grace a hunter's peal.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And you have rung it lustily, my lord,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Somewhat too early for new-married ladies.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Lavinia, how say you?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I say, no,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I have been broad awake two hours and more.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Come on, then, horse and chariots let us have,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And to our sport.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To TAMORA

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Madam, now shall ye see

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Our Roman hunting.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I have dogs, my lord,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Will rouse the proudest panther in the chase,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And climb the highest promontory top.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And I have horse will follow where the game

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Makes way, and run like swallows o'er the plain.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Chiron, we hunt not, we, with horse nor hound,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But hope to pluck a dainty doe to ground.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: SCENE III. A lonely part of the forest.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter AARON, with a bag of gold

Author: Shakespeare
Text: He that had wit would think that I had none,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To bury so much gold under a tree,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And never after to inherit it.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Let him that thinks of me so abjectly

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Know that this gold must coin a stratagem,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Which, cunningly effected, will beget

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A very excellent piece of villany:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And so repose, sweet gold, for their unrest

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Hides the gold

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That have their alms out of the empress' chest.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter TAMORA

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My lovely Aaron, wherefore look'st thou sad,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: When every thing doth make a gleeful boast?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The birds chant melody on every bush,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The snake lies rolled in the cheerful sun,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The green leaves quiver with the cooling wind

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And make a chequer'd shadow on the ground:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Under their sweet shade, Aaron, let us sit,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And, whilst the babbling echo mocks the hounds,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Replying shrilly to the well-tuned horns,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As if a double hunt were heard at once,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Let us sit down and mark their yelping noise,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And, after conflict such as was supposed

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The wandering prince and Dido once enjoy'd,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: When with a happy storm they were surprised

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And curtain'd with a counsel-keeping cave,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: We may, each wreathed in the other's arms,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Our pastimes done, possess a golden slumber,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Whiles hounds and horns and sweet melodious birds

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Be unto us as is a nurse's song

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Of lullaby to bring her babe asleep.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Madam, though Venus govern your desires,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Saturn is dominator over mine:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What signifies my deadly-standing eye,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My silence and my cloudy melancholy,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My fleece of woolly hair that now uncurls

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Even as an adder when she doth unroll

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To do some fatal execution?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: No, madam, these are no venereal signs:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Vengeance is in my heart, death in my hand,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Blood and revenge are hammering in my head.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Hark Tamora, the empress of my soul,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Which never hopes more heaven than rests in thee,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: This is the day of doom for Bassianus:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: His Philomel must lose her tongue to-day,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thy sons make pillage of her chastity

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And wash their hands in Bassianus' blood.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Seest thou this letter? take it up, I pray thee,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And give the king this fatal plotted scroll.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Now question me no more, we are espied,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Here comes a parcel of our hopeful booty,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Which dreads not yet their lives' destruction.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ah, my sweet Moor, sweeter to me than life!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: No more, great empress, Bassianus comes:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Be cross with him, and I'll go fetch thy sons

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To back thy quarrels, whatsoe'er they be.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter BASSIANUS and LAVINIA

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Who have we here? Rome's royal empress,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Unfurnish'd of her well-beseeming troop?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Or is it Dian, habited like her,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Who hath abandoned her holy groves

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To see the general hunting in this forest?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Saucy controller of our private steps!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Had I the power that some say Dian had,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thy temples should be planted presently

Author: Shakespeare
Text: With horns, as was Actaeon's, and the hounds

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Should drive upon thy new-transformed limbs,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Unmannerly intruder as thou art!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Under your patience, gentle empress,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Tis thought you have a goodly gift in horning,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And to be doubted that your Moor and you

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Are singled forth to try experiments:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Jove shield your husband from his hounds to-day!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Tis pity they should take him for a stag.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Believe me, queen, your swarth Cimmerian

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Doth make your honour of his body's hue,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Spotted, detested, and abominable.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why are you sequester'd from all your train,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Dismounted from your snow-white goodly steed.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And wander'd hither to an obscure plot,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Accompanied but with a barbarous Moor,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If foul desire had not conducted you?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And, being intercepted in your sport,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Great reason that my noble lord be rated

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For sauciness. I pray you, let us hence,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And let her joy her raven-colour'd love,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: This valley fits the purpose passing well.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The king my brother shall have note of this.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, for these slips have made him noted long:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Good king, to be so mightily abused!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why have I patience to endure all this?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter DEMETRIUS and CHIRON

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How now, dear sovereign, and our gracious mother!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why doth your highness look so pale and wan?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Have I not reason, think you, to look pale?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: These two have 'ticed me hither to this place:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A barren detested vale, you see it is,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The trees, though summer, yet forlorn and lean,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O'ercome with moss and baleful mistletoe:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Here never shines the sun, here nothing breeds,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Unless the nightly owl or fatal raven:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And when they show'd me this abhorred pit,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: They told me, here, at dead time of the night,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A thousand fiends, a thousand hissing snakes,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ten thousand swelling toads, as many urchins,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Would make such fearful and confused cries

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As any mortal body hearing it

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Should straight fall mad, or else die suddenly.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: No sooner had they told this hellish tale,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But straight they told me they would bind me here

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Unto the body of a dismal yew,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And leave me to this miserable death:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And then they call'd me foul adulteress,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Lascivious Goth, and all the bitterest terms

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That ever ear did hear to such effect:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And, had you not by wondrous fortune come,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: This vengeance on me had they executed.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Revenge it, as you love your mother's life,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Or be ye not henceforth call'd my children.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: This is a witness that I am thy son.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Stabs BASSIANUS

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And this for me, struck home to show my strength.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Also stabs BASSIANUS, who dies

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, come, Semiramis, nay, barbarous Tamora,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For no name fits thy nature but thy own!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Give me thy poniard, you shall know, my boys

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Your mother's hand shall right your mother's wrong.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Stay, madam, here is more belongs to her,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: First thrash the corn, then after burn the straw:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: This minion stood upon her chastity,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Upon her nuptial vow, her loyalty,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And with that painted hope braves your mightiness:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And shall she carry this unto her grave?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: An if she do, I would I were an eunuch.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Drag hence her husband to some secret hole,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And make his dead trunk pillow to our lust.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But when ye have the honey ye desire,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Let not this wasp outlive, us both to sting.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I warrant you, madam, we wil l make that sure.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Come, mistress, now perforce we will enjoy

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That nice-preserved honesty of yours.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O Tamora! thou bear'st a woman's face,--

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I will not hear her speak, away with her!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sweet lords, entreat her hear me but a word.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Listen, fair madam: let it be your glory

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To see her tears, but be your heart to them

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As unrelenting flint to drops of rain.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: When did the tiger's young ones teach the dam?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O, do not learn her wrath, she taught it thee,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The milk thou suck'dst from her did turn to marble,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Even at thy teat thou hadst thy tyranny.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Yet every mother breeds not sons alike:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To CHIRON

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Do thou entreat her show a woman pity.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What, wouldst thou have me prove myself a bastard?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Tis true, the raven doth not hatch a lark:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Yet have I heard,--O, could I find it now!--

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The lion moved with pity did endure

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To have his princely paws pared all away:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Some say that ravens foster forlorn children,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The whilst their own birds famish in their nests:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O, be to me, though thy hard heart say no,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Nothing so kind, but something pitiful!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I know not what it means, away with her!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O, let me teach thee! for my father's sake,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That gave thee life, when well he might have

Author: Shakespeare
Text: slain thee,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Be not obdurate, open thy deaf ears.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Hadst thou in person ne'er offended me,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Even for his sake am I pitiless.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Remember, boys, I pour'd forth tears in vain,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To save your brother from the sacrifice,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But fierce Andronicus would not relent,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Therefore, away with her, and use her as you will,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The worse to her, the better loved of me.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O Tamora, be call'd a gentle queen,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And with thine own hands kill me in this place!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For 'tis not life that I have begg'd so long,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Poor I was slain when Bassianus died.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What begg'st thou, then? fond woman, let me go.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Tis present death I beg, and one thing more

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That womanhood denies my tongue to tell:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O, keep me from their worse than killing lust,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And tumble me into some loathsome pit,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Where never man's eye may behold my body:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Do this, and be a charitable murderer.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: So should I rob my sweet sons of their fee:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: No, let them satisfy their lust on thee.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Away! for thou hast stay'd us here too long.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: No grace? no womanhood? Ah, beastly creature!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The blot and enemy to our general name!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Confusion fall--

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Nay, then I'll stop your mouth. Bring thou her husband:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: This is the hole where Aaron bid us hide him.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: DEMETRIUS throws the body of BASSIANUS into the  pit, then exeunt DEMETRIUS and CHIRON, dragging off LAVINIA

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Farewell, my sons: see that you make her sure.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ne'er let my heart know merry cheer indeed,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Till all the Andronici be made away.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Now will I hence to seek my lovely Moor,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And let my spleenful sons this trull deflow'r.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Re-enter AARON, with QUINTUS and MARTIUS

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Come on, my lords, the better foot before:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Straight will I bring you to the loathsome pit

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Where I espied the panther fast asleep.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My sight is very dull, whate'er it bodes.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And mine, I promise you, were't not for shame,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Well could I leave our sport to sleep awhile.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Falls into the pit

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What art thou fall'n? What subtle hole is this,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Whose mouth is cover'd with rude-growing briers,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Upon whose leaves are drops of new-shed blood

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As fresh as morning dew distill'd on flowers?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A very fatal place it seems to me.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Speak, brother, hast thou hurt thee with the fall?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O brother, with the dismall'st object hurt

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That ever eye with sight made heart lament!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: [Aside]  Now will I fetch the king to find them here,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That he thereby may give a likely guess

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How these were they that made away his brother.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why dost not comfort me, and help me out

Author: Shakespeare
Text: From this unhallowed and blood-stained hole?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I am surprised with an uncouth fear,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A chilling sweat o'er-runs my trembling joints:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My heart suspects more than mine eye can see.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To prove thou hast a true-divining heart,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Aaron and thou look down into this den,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And see a fearful sight of blood and death.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Aaron is gone, and my compassionate heart

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Will not permit mine eyes once to behold

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The thing whereat it trembles by surmise,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O, tell me how it is, for ne'er till now

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Was I a child to fear I know not what.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Lord Bassianus lies embrewed here,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: All on a heap, like to a slaughter'd lamb,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: In this detested, dark, blood-drinking pit.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If it be dark, how dost thou know 'tis he?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Upon his bloody finger he doth wear

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A precious ring, that lightens all the hole,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Which, like a taper in some monument,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Doth shine upon the dead man's earthy cheeks,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And shows the ragged entrails of the pit:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: So pale did shine the moon on Pyramus

Author: Shakespeare
Text: When he by night lay bathed in maiden blood.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O brother, help me with thy fainting hand--

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If fear hath made thee faint, as me it hath--

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Out of this fell devouring receptacle,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As hateful as Cocytus' misty mouth.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Reach me thy hand, that I may help thee out,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Or, wanting strength to do thee so much good,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I may be pluck'd into the swallowing womb

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Of this deep pit, poor Bassianus' grave.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I have no strength to pluck thee to the brink.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Nor I no strength to climb without thy help.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thy hand once more, I will not loose again,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Till thou art here aloft, or I below:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thou canst not come to me: I come to thee.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Falls in

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter SATURNINUS with AARON

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Along with me: I'll see what hole is here,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And what he is that now is leap'd into it.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Say who art thou that lately didst descend

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Into this gaping hollow of the earth?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The unhappy son of old Andronicus:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Brought hither in a most unlucky hour,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To find thy brother Bassianus dead.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My brother dead! I know thou dost but jest:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: He and his lady both are at the lodge

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Upon the north side of this pleasant chase,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Tis not an hour since I left him there.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: We know not where you left him all alive,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But, out, alas! here have we found him dead.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Re-enter TAMORA, with Attendants, TITUS ANDRONICUS, and Lucius

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Where is my lord the king?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Here, Tamora, though grieved with killing grief.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Where is thy brother Bassianus?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Now to the bottom dost thou search my wound:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Poor Bassianus here lies murdered.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Then all too late I bring this fatal writ,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The complot of this timeless tragedy,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And wonder greatly that man's face can fold

Author: Shakespeare
Text: In pleasing smiles such murderous tyranny.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: She giveth SATURNINUS a letter

Author: Shakespeare
Text: [Reads]  'An if we miss to meet him handsomely--

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sweet huntsman, Bassianus 'tis we mean--

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Do thou so much as dig the grave for him:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thou know'st our meaning. Look for thy reward

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Among the nettles at the elder-tree

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Which overshades the mouth of that same pit

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Where we decreed to bury Bassianus.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Do this, and purchase us thy lasting friends.'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O Tamora! was ever heard the like?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: This is the pit, and this the elder-tree.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Look, sirs, if you can find the huntsman out

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That should have murdered Bassianus here.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My gracious lord, here is the bag of gold.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: [To TITUS]  Two of thy whelps, fell curs of

Author: Shakespeare
Text: bloody kind,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Have here bereft my brother of his life.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sirs, drag them from the pit unto the prison:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: There let them bide until we have devised

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Some never-heard-of torturing pain for them.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What, are they in this pit? O wondrous thing!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How easily murder is discovered!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: High emperor, upon my feeble knee

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I beg this boon, with tears not lightly shed,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That this fell fault of my accursed sons,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Accursed if the fault be proved in them,--

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If it be proved! you see it is apparent.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Who found this letter? Tamora, was it you?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Andronicus himself did take it up.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I did, my lord: yet let me be their bail,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For, by my father's reverend tomb, I vow

Author: Shakespeare
Text: They shall be ready at your highness' will

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To answer their suspicion with their lives.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thou shalt not bail them: see thou follow me.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Some bring the murder'd body, some the murderers:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Let them not speak a word, the guilt is plain,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For, by my soul, were there worse end than death,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That end upon them should be executed.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Andronicus, I will entreat the king,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Fear not thy sons, they shall do well enough.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Come, Lucius, come, stay not to talk with them.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: SCENE IV. Another part of the forest.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: SCENE IV. Another part of the forest.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter DEMETRIUS and CHIRON with LAVINIA, ravished, her hands cut off, and her tongue cut out

Author: Shakespeare
Text: So, now go tell, an if thy tongue can speak,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Who 'twas that cut thy tongue and ravish'd thee.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Write down thy mind, bewray thy meaning so,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: An if thy stumps will let thee play the scribe.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: See, how with signs and tokens she can scrowl.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Go home, call for sweet water, wash thy hands.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: She hath no tongue to call, nor hands to wash,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And so let's leave her to her silent walks.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: An 'twere my case, I should go hang myself.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If thou hadst hands to help thee knit the cord.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Exeunt DEMETRIUS and CHIRON

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter MARCUS

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter MARCUS

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Who is this? my niece, that flies away so fast!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Cousin, a word, where is your husband?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If I do dream, would all my wealth would wake me!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If I do wake, some planet strike me down,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That I may slumber in eternal sleep!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Speak, gentle niece, what stern ungentle hands

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Have lopp'd and hew'd and made thy body bare

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Of her two branches, those sweet ornaments,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Whose circling shadows kings have sought to sleep in,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And might not gain so great a happiness

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As have thy love? Why dost not speak to me?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Alas, a crimson river of warm blood,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Like to a bubbling fountain stirr'd with wind,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Doth rise and fall between thy rosed lips,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Coming and going with thy honey breath.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But, sure, some Tereus hath deflowered thee,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And, lest thou shouldst detect him, cut thy tongue.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ah, now thou turn'st away thy face for shame!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And, notwithstanding all this loss of blood,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As from a conduit with three issuing spouts,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Yet do thy cheeks look red as Titan's face

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Blushing to be encountered with a cloud.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Shall I speak for thee? shall I say 'tis so?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O, that I knew thy heart, and knew the beast,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That I might rail at him, to ease my mind!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sorrow concealed, like an oven stopp'd,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Doth burn the heart to cinders where it is.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Fair Philomela, she but lost her tongue,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And in a tedious sampler sew'd her mind:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But, lovely niece, that mean is cut from thee,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A craftier Tereus, cousin, hast thou met,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And he hath cut those pretty fingers off,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That could have better sew'd than Philomel.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O, had the monster seen those lily hands

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Tremble, like aspen-leaves, upon a lute,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And make the silken strings delight to kiss them,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: He would not then have touch'd them for his life!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Or, had he heard the heavenly harmony

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Which that sweet tongue hath made,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: He would have dropp'd his knife, and fell asleep

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As Cerberus at the Thracian poet's feet.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Come, let us go, and make thy father blind,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For such a sight will blind a father's eye:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: One hour's storm will drown the fragrant meads,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What will whole months of tears thy father's eyes?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Do not draw back, for we will mourn with thee

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O, could our mourning ease thy misery!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter Judges, Senators and Tribunes, with MARTIUS  and QUINTUS, bound, passing on to the place of execution, TITUS going before, pleading

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Hear me, grave fathers! noble tribunes, stay!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For pity of mine age, whose youth was spent

Author: Shakespeare
Text: In dangerous wars, whilst you securely slept,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For all my blood in Rome's great quarrel shed,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For all the frosty nights that I have watch'd,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And for these bitter tears, which now you see

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Filling the aged wrinkles in my cheeks,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Be pitiful to my condemned sons,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Whose souls are not corrupted as 'tis thought.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For two and twenty sons I never wept,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Because they died in honour's lofty bed.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Lieth down, the Judges,  and c., pass by him, and Exeunt

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For these, these, tribunes, in the dust I write

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My heart's deep languor and my soul's sad tears:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Let my tears stanch the earth's dry appetite,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My sons' sweet blood will make it shame and blush.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O earth, I will befriend thee more with rain,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That shall distil from these two ancient urns,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Than youthful April shall with all his showers:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: In summer's drought I'll drop upon thee still,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: In winter with warm tears I'll melt the snow

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And keep eternal spring-time on thy face,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: So thou refuse to drink my dear sons' blood.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter LUCIUS, with his sword drawn

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O reverend tribunes! O gentle, aged men!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Unbind my sons, reverse the doom of death,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And let me say, that never wept before,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My tears are now prevailing orators.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O noble father, you lament in vain:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The tribunes hear you not, no man is by,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And you recount your sorrows to a stone.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ah, Lucius, for thy brothers let me plead.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Grave tribunes, once more I entreat of you,--

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My gracious lord, no tribune hears you speak.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, tis no matter, man, if they did hear,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: They would not mark me, or if they did mark,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: They would not pity me, yet plead I must,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Therefore I tell my sorrows to the stones,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Who, though they cannot answer my distress,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Yet in some sort they are better than the tribunes,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For that they will not intercept my tale:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: When I do weep, they humbly at my feet

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Receive my tears and seem to weep with me,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And, were they but attired in grave weeds,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Rome could afford no tribune like to these.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A stone is soft as wax,--tribunes more hard than stones,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A stone is silent, and offendeth not,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And tribunes with their tongues doom men to death.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But wherefore stand'st thou with thy weapon drawn?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To rescue my two brothers from their death:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For which attempt the judges have pronounced

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My everlasting doom of banishment.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O happy man! they have befriended thee.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, foolish Lucius, dost thou not perceive

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That Rome is but a wilderness of tigers?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Tigers must prey, and Rome affords no prey

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But me and mine: how happy art thou, then,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: From these devourers to be banished!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But who comes with our brother Marcus here?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter MARCUS and LAVINIA

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Titus, prepare thy aged eyes to weep,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Or, if not so, thy noble heart to break:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I bring consuming sorrow to thine age.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Will it consume me? let me see it, then.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: This was thy daughter.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, Marcus, so she is.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay me, this object kills me!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Faint-hearted boy, arise, and look upon her.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Speak, Lavinia, what accursed hand

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Hath made thee handless in thy father's sight?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What fool hath added water to the sea,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Or brought a faggot to bright-burning Troy?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My grief was at the height before thou camest,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And now like Nilus, it disdaineth bounds.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Give me a sword, I'll chop off my hands too,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For they have fought for Rome, and all in vain,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And they have nursed this woe, in feeding life,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: In bootless prayer have they been held up,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And they have served me to effectless use:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Now all the service I require of them

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Is that the one will help to cut the other.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Tis well, Lavinia, that thou hast no hands,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For hands, to do Rome service, are but vain.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Speak, gentle sister, who hath martyr'd thee?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O, that delightful engine of her thoughts

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That blabb'd them with such pleasing eloquence,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Is torn from forth that pretty hollow cage,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Where, like a sweet melodious bird, it sung

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sweet varied notes, enchanting every ear!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O, say thou for her, who hath done this deed?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O, thus I found her, straying in the park,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Seeking to hide herself, as doth the deer

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That hath received some unrecuring wound.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: It was my deer, and he that wounded her

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Hath hurt me more than had he killed me dead:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For now I stand as one upon a rock

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Environed with a wilderness of sea,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Who marks the waxing tide grow wave by wave,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Expecting ever when some envious surge

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Will in his brinish bowels swallow him.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: This way to death my wretched sons are gone,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Here stands my other son, a banished man,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And here my brother, weeping at my woes.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But that which gives my soul the greatest spurn,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Is dear Lavinia, dearer than my soul.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Had I but seen thy picture in this plight,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: It would have madded me: what shall I do

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Now I behold thy lively body so?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thou hast no hands, to wipe away thy tears:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Nor tongue, to tell me who hath martyr'd thee:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thy husband he is dead: and for his death

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thy brothers are condemn'd, and dead by this.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Look, Marcus! ah, son Lucius, look on her!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: When I did name her brothers, then fresh tears

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Stood on her cheeks, as doth the honey-dew

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Upon a gather'd lily almost wither'd.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Perchance she weeps because they kill'd her husband,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Perchance because she knows them innocent.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If they did kill thy husband, then be joyful

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Because the law hath ta'en revenge on them.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: No, no, they would not do so foul a deed,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Witness the sorrow that their sister makes.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Gentle Lavinia, let me kiss thy lips.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Or make some sign how I may do thee ease:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Shall thy good uncle, and thy brother Lucius,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And thou, and I, sit round about some fountain,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Looking all downwards to behold our cheeks

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How they are stain'd, as meadows, yet not dry,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: With miry slime left on them by a flood?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And in the fountain shall we gaze so long

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Till the fresh taste be taken from that clearness,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And made a brine-pit with our bitter tears?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Or shall we cut away our hands, like thine?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Or shall we bite our tongues, and in dumb shows

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Pass the remainder of our hateful days?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What shall we do? let us, that have our tongues,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Plot some deuce of further misery,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To make us wonder'd at in time to come.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sweet father, cease your tears, for, at your grief,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: See how my wretched sister sobs and weeps.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Patience, dear niece. Good Titus, dry thine eyes.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ah, Marcus, Marcus! brother, well I wot

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thy napkin cannot drink a tear of mine,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For thou, poor man, hast drown'd it with thine own.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ah, my Lavinia, I will wipe thy cheeks.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Mark, Marcus, mark! I understand her signs:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Had she a tongue to speak, now would she say

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That to her brother which I said to thee:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: His napkin, with his true tears all bewet,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Can do no service on her sorrowful cheeks.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O, what a sympathy of woe is this,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As far from help as Limbo is from bliss!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Titus Andronicus, my lord the emperor

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sends thee this word,--that, if thou love thy sons,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Let Marcus, Lucius, or thyself, old Titus,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Or any one of you, chop off your hand,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And send it to the king: he for the same

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Will send thee hither both thy sons alive,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And that shall be the ransom for their fault.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O gracious emperor! O gentle Aaron!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Did ever raven sing so like a lark,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That gives sweet tidings of the sun's uprise?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: With all my heart, I'll send the emperor My hand:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Good Aaron, wilt thou help to chop it off?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Stay, father! for that noble hand of thine,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That hath thrown down so many enemies,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Shall not be sent: my hand will serve the turn:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My youth can better spare my blood than you,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And therefore mine shall save my brothers' lives.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Which of your hands hath not defended Rome,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And rear'd aloft the bloody battle-axe,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Writing destruction on the enemy's castle?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O, none of both but are of high desert:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My hand hath been but idle, let it serve

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To ransom my two nephews from their death,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Then have I kept it to a worthy end.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Nay, come, agree whose hand shall go along,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For fear they die before their pardon come.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My hand shall go.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: By heaven, it shall not go!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sirs, strive no more: such wither'd herbs as these

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Are meet for plucking up, and therefore mine.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sweet father, if I shall be thought thy son,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Let me redeem my brothers both from death.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And, for our father's sake and mother's care,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Now let me show a brother's love to thee.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Agree between you, I will spare my hand.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Then I'll go fetch an axe.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But I will use the axe.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Exeunt LUCIUS and MARCUS

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Come hither, Aaron, I'll deceive them both:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Lend me thy hand, and I will give thee mine.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: [Aside]  If that be call'd deceit, I will be honest,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And never, whilst I live, deceive men so:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But I'll deceive you in another sort,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And that you'll say, ere half an hour pass.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Cuts off TITUS's hand

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Re-enter LUCIUS and MARCUS

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Now stay your strife: what shall be is dispatch'd.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Good Aaron, give his majesty my hand:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Tell him it was a hand that warded him

Author: Shakespeare
Text: From thousand dangers, bid him bury it

Author: Shakespeare
Text: More hath it merited, that let it have.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As for my sons, say I account of them

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As jewels purchased at an easy price,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And yet dear too, because I bought mine own.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I go, Andronicus: and for thy hand

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Look by and by to have thy sons with thee.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Their heads, I mean. O, how this villany

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Doth fat me with the very thoughts of it!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Let fools do good, and fair men call for grace.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Aaron will have his soul black like his face.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O, here I lift this one hand up to heaven,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And bow this feeble ruin to the earth:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If any power pities wretched tears,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To that I call!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To LAVINIA

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To LAVINIA

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What, wilt thou kneel with me?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Do, then, dear heart, for heaven shall hear our prayers,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Or with our sighs we'll breathe the welkin dim,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And stain the sun with fog, as sometime clouds

Author: Shakespeare
Text: When they do hug him in their melting bosoms.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O brother, speak with possibilities,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And do not break into these deep extremes.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Is not my sorrow deep, having no bottom?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Then be my passions bottomless with them.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But yet let reason govern thy lament.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If there were reason for these miseries,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Then into limits could I bind my woes:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: When heaven doth weep, doth not the earth o'erflow?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If the winds rage, doth not the sea wax mad,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Threatening the welkin with his big-swoln face?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And wilt thou have a reason for this coil?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I am the sea, hark, how her sighs do blow!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: She is the weeping welkin, I the earth:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Then must my sea be moved with her sighs,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Then must my earth with her continual tears

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Become a deluge, overflow'd and drown'd,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For why my bowels cannot hide her woes,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But like a drunkard must I vomit them.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Then give me leave, for losers will have leave

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To ease their stomachs with their bitter tongues.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter a Messenger, with two heads and a hand

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Worthy Andronicus, ill art thou repaid

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For that good hand thou sent'st the emperor.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Here are the heads of thy two noble sons,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And here's thy hand, in scorn to thee sent back,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thy griefs their sports, thy resolution mock'd,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That woe is me to think upon thy woes

Author: Shakespeare
Text: More than remembrance of my father's death.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Now let hot AEtna cool in Sicily,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And be my heart an ever-burning hell!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: These miseries are more than may be borne.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To weep with them that weep doth ease some deal,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But sorrow flouted at is double death.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ah, that this sight should make so deep a wound,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And yet detested life not shrink thereat!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That ever death should let life bear his name,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Where life hath no more interest but to breathe!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: LAVINIA kisses TITUS

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Alas, poor heart, that kiss is comfortless

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As frozen water to a starved snake.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: When will this fearful slumber have an end?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Now, farewell, flattery: die, Andronicus,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thou dost not slumber: see, thy two sons' heads,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thy warlike hand, thy mangled daughter here:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thy other banish'd son, with this dear sight

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Struck pale and bloodless, and thy brother, I,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Even like a stony image, cold and numb.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ah, now no more will I control thy griefs:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Rend off thy silver hair, thy other hand

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Gnawing with thy teeth, and be this dismal sight

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The closing up of our most wretched eyes,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Now is a time to storm, why art thou still?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why dost thou laugh? it fits not with this hour.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, I have not another tear to shed:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Besides, this sorrow is an enemy,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And would usurp upon my watery eyes

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And make them blind with tributary tears:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Then which way shall I find Revenge's cave?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For these two heads do seem to speak to me,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And threat me I shall never come to bliss

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Till all these mischiefs be return'd again

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Even in their throats that have committed them.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Come, let me see what task I have to do.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You heavy people, circle me about,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That I may turn me to each one of you,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And swear unto my soul to right your wrongs.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The vow is made. Come, brother, take a head,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And in this hand the other I will bear.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Lavinia, thou shalt be employ'd: these arms!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Bear thou my hand, sweet wench, between thy teeth.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As for thee, boy, go get thee from my sight,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thou art an exile, and thou must not stay:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Hie to the Goths, and raise an army there:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And, if you love me, as I think you do,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Let's kiss and part, for we have much to do.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Exeunt TITUS, MARCUS, and LAVINIA

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Farewell Andronicus, my noble father,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The wofull'st man that ever lived in Rome:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Farewell, proud Rome, till Lucius come again,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: He leaves his pledges dearer than his life:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Farewell, Lavinia, my noble sister,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O, would thou wert as thou tofore hast been!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But now nor Lucius nor Lavinia lives

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But in oblivion and hateful griefs.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If Lucius live, he will requite your wrongs,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And make proud Saturnine and his empress

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Beg at the gates, like Tarquin and his queen.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Now will I to the Goths, and raise a power,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To be revenged on Rome and Saturnine.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: SCENE II. A room in Titus's house. A banquet set out.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter TITUS, MARCUS, LAVINIA and Young LUCIUS, a boy

Author: Shakespeare
Text: So, so, now sit: and look you eat no more

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Than will preserve just so much strength in us

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As will revenge these bitter woes of ours.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Marcus, unknit that sorrow-wreathen knot:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thy niece and I, poor creatures, want our hands,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And cannot passionate our tenfold grief

Author: Shakespeare
Text: With folded arms. This poor right hand of mine

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Is left to tyrannize upon my breast,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Who, when my heart, all mad with misery,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Beats in this hollow prison of my flesh,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Then thus I thump it down.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thou map of woe, that thus dost talk in signs!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: When thy poor heart beats with outrageous beating,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thou canst not strike it thus to make it still.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Wound it with sighing, girl, kill it with groans,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Or get some little knife between thy teeth,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And just against thy heart make thou a hole,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That all the tears that thy poor eyes let fall

Author: Shakespeare
Text: May run into that sink, and soaking in

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Drown the lamenting fool in sea-salt tears.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Fie, brother, fie! teach her not thus to lay

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Such violent hands upon her tender life.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How now! has sorrow made thee dote already?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, Marcus, no man should be mad but I.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What violent hands can she lay on her life?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ah, wherefore dost thou urge the name of hands,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To bid AEneas tell the tale twice o'er,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How Troy was burnt and he made miserable?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O, handle not the theme, to talk of hands,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Lest we remember still that we have none.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Fie, fie, how franticly I square my talk,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As if we should forget we had no hands,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If Marcus did not name the word of hands!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Come, let's fall to, and, gentle girl, eat this:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Here is no drink! Hark, Marcus, what she says,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I can interpret all her martyr'd signs,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: She says she drinks no other drink but tears,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Brew'd with her sorrow, mesh'd upon her cheeks:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Speechless complainer, I will learn thy thought,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: In thy dumb action will I be as perfect

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As begging hermits in their holy prayers:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thou shalt not sigh, nor hold thy stumps to heaven,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Nor wink, nor nod, nor kneel, nor make a sign,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But I of these will wrest an alphabet

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And by still practise learn to know thy meaning.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Good grandsire, leave these bitter deep laments:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Make my aunt merry with some pleasing tale.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Alas, the tender boy, in passion moved,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Doth weep to see his grandsire's heaviness.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Peace, tender sapling, thou art made of tears,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And tears will quickly melt thy life away.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: MARCUS strikes the dish with a knife

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What dost thou strike at, Marcus, with thy knife?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: At that that I have kill'd, my lord, a fly.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Out on thee, murderer! thou kill'st my heart,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Mine eyes are cloy'd with view of tyranny:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A deed of death done on the innocent

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Becomes not Titus' brother: get thee gone:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I see thou art not for my company.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Alas, my lord, I have but kill'd a fly.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But how, if that fly had a father and mother?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How would he hang his slender gilded wings,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And buzz lamenting doings in the air!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Poor harmless fly,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That, with his pretty buzzing melody,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Came here to make us merry! and thou hast

Author: Shakespeare
Text: kill'd him.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Pardon me, sir, it was a black ill-favor'd fly,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Like to the empress' Moor, therefore I kill'd him.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O, O, O,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Then pardon me for reprehending thee,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For thou hast done a charitable deed.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Give me thy knife, I will insult on him,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Flattering myself, as if it were the Moor

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Come hither purposely to poison me.--

Author: Shakespeare
Text: There's for thyself, and that's for Tamora.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ah, sirrah!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Yet, I think, we are not brought so low,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But that between us we can kill a fly

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That comes in likeness of a coal-black Moor.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Alas, poor man! grief has so wrought on him,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: He takes false shadows for true substances.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Come, take away. Lavinia, go with me:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I'll to thy closet, and go read with thee

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sad stories chanced in the times of old.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Come, boy, and go with me: thy sight is young,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And thou shalt read when mine begin to dazzle.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: SCENE I. Rome. Titus's garden.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter young LUCIUS, and LAVINIA running after him,  and the boy flies from her, with books under his arm. Then enter TITUS and MARCUS

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Help, grandsire, help! my aunt Lavinia

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Follows me every where, I know not why:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Good uncle Marcus, see how swift she comes.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Alas, sweet aunt, I know not what you mean.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Stand by me, Lucius, do not fear thine aunt.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: She loves thee, boy, too well to do thee harm.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, when my father was in Rome she did.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What means my niece Lavinia by these signs?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Fear her not, Lucius: somewhat doth she mean:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: See, Lucius, see how much she makes of thee:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Somewhither would she have thee go with her.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ah, boy, Cornelia never with more care

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Read to her sons than she hath read to thee

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sweet poetry and Tully's Orator.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Canst thou not guess wherefore she plies thee thus?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My lord, I know not, I, nor can I guess,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Unless some fit or frenzy do possess her:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For I have heard my grandsire say full oft,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Extremity of griefs would make men mad,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And I have read that Hecuba of Troy

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ran mad through sorrow: that made me to fear,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Although, my lord, I know my noble aunt

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Loves me as dear as e'er my mother did,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And would not, but in fury, fright my youth:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Which made me down to throw my books, and fly--

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Causeless, perhaps. But pardon me, sweet aunt:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And, madam, if my uncle Marcus go,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I will most willingly attend your ladyship.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Lucius, I will.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: LAVINIA turns over with her stumps the books which LUCIUS has let fall

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How now, Lavinia! Marcus, what means this?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Some book there is that she desires to see.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Which is it, girl, of these? Open them, boy.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But thou art deeper read, and better skill'd

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Come, and take choice of all my library,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And so beguile thy sorrow, till the heavens

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Reveal the damn'd contriver of this deed.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why lifts she up her arms in sequence thus?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I think she means that there was more than one

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Confederate in the fact: ay, more there was,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Or else to heaven she heaves them for revenge.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Lucius, what book is that she tosseth so?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Grandsire, 'tis Ovid's Metamorphoses,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My mother gave it me.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For love of her that's gone,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Perhaps she cull'd it from among the rest.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Soft! see how busily she turns the leaves!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Helping her

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What would she find? Lavinia, shall I read?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: This is the tragic tale of Philomel,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And treats of Tereus' treason and his rape:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And rape, I fear, was root of thine annoy.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: See, brother, see, note how she quotes the leaves.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Lavinia, wert thou thus surprised, sweet girl,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ravish'd and wrong'd, as Philomela was,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Forced in the ruthless, vast, and gloomy woods? See, see!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, such a place there is, where we did hunt--

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O, had we never, never hunted there!--

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Pattern'd by that the poet here describes,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: By nature made for murders and for rapes.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O, why should nature build so foul a den,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Unless the gods delight in tragedies?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Give signs, sweet girl, for here are none

Author: Shakespeare
Text: but friends,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What Roman lord it was durst do the deed:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Or slunk not Saturnine, as Tarquin erst,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That left the camp to sin in Lucrece' bed?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sit down, sweet niece: brother, sit down by me.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Apollo, Pallas, Jove, or Mercury,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Inspire me, that I may this treason find!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My lord, look here: look here, Lavinia:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: This sandy plot is plain, guide, if thou canst

Author: Shakespeare
Text: This after me, when I have writ my name

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Without the help of any hand at all.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: He writes his name with his staff, and guides it with feet and mouth

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Cursed be that heart that forced us to this shift!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Write thou good niece, and here display, at last,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What God will have discover'd for revenge,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Heaven guide thy pen to print thy sorrows plain,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That we may know the traitors and the truth!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: She takes the staff in her mouth, and guides it with her stumps, and writes

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O, do ye read, my lord, what she hath writ?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Stuprum. Chiron. Demetrius.'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What, what! the lustful sons of Tamora

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Performers of this heinous, bloody deed?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Magni Dominator poli,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Tam lentus audis scelera? tam lentus vides?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O, calm thee, gentle lord, although I know

Author: Shakespeare
Text: There is enough written upon this earth

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To stir a mutiny in the mildest thoughts

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And arm the minds of infants to exclaims.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My lord, kneel down with me, Lavinia, kneel,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And kneel, sweet boy, the Roman Hector's hope,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And swear with me, as, with the woful fere

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And father of that chaste dishonour'd dame,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Lord Junius Brutus sware for Lucrece' rape,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That we will prosecute by good advice

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Mortal revenge upon these traitorous Goths,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And see their blood, or die with this reproach.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Tis sure enough, an you knew how.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But if you hunt these bear-whelps, then beware:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The dam will wake, and, if she wind you once,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: She's with the lion deeply still in league,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And lulls him whilst she playeth on her back,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And when he sleeps will she do what she list.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You are a young huntsman, Marcus, let it alone,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And, come, I will go get a leaf of brass,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And with a gad of steel will write these words,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And lay it by: the angry northern wind

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Will blow these sands, like Sibyl's leaves, abroad,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And where's your lesson, then? Boy, what say you?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I say, my lord, that if I were a man,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Their mother's bed-chamber should not be safe

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For these bad bondmen to the yoke of Rome.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, that's my boy! thy father hath full oft

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For his ungrateful country done the like.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And, uncle, so will I, an if I live.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Come, go with me into mine armoury,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Lucius, I'll fit thee, and withal, my boy,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Shalt carry from me to the empress' sons

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Presents that I intend to send them both:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Come, come, thou'lt do thy message, wilt thou not?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, with my dagger in their bosoms, grandsire.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: No, boy, not so, I'll teach thee another course.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Lavinia, come. Marcus, look to my house:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Lucius and I'll go brave it at the court:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, marry, will we, sir, and we'll be waited on.

Author: Shakespeare

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O heavens, can you hear a good man groan,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And not relent, or not compassion him?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Marcus, attend him in his ecstasy,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That hath more scars of sorrow in his heart

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Than foemen's marks upon his batter'd shield,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But yet so just that he will not revenge.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Revenge, ye heavens, for old Andronicus!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: SCENE II. The same. A room in the palace.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter, from one side, AARON, DEMETRIUS, and  CHIRON, from the other side, Young LUCIUS, and an  Attendant, with a bundle of weapons, and verses writ upon them

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Demetrius, here's the son of Lucius,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: He hath some message to deliver us.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, some mad message from his mad grandfather.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My lords, with all the humbleness I may,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I greet your honours from Andronicus.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And pray the Roman gods confound you both!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Gramercy, lovely Lucius: what's the news?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: [Aside]  That you are both decipher'd, that's the news,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For villains mark'd with rape.--May it please you,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My grandsire, well advised, hath sent by me

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The goodliest weapons of his armoury

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To gratify your honourable youth,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The hope of Rome, for so he bade me say,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And so I do, and with his gifts present

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Your lordships, that, whenever you have need,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You may be armed and appointed well:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And so I leave you both:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: like bloody villains.
