Text: Exeunt Young LUCIUS, and Attendant

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What's here? A scroll, and written round about?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Let's see,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Integer vitae, scelerisque purus,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Non eget Mauri jaculis, nec arcu.'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O, 'tis a verse in Horace, I know it well:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I read it in the grammar long ago.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, just, a verse in Horace, right, you have it.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Now, what a thing it is to be an ass!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Here's no sound jest! the old man hath found their guilt,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And sends them weapons wrapped about with lines,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That wound, beyond their feeling, to the quick.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But were our witty empress well afoot,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: She would applaud Andronicus' conceit:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But let her rest in her unrest awhile.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And now, young lords, was't not a happy star

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Led us to Rome, strangers, and more than so,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Captives, to be advanced to this height?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: It did me good, before the palace gate

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To brave the tribune in his brother's hearing.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But me more good, to see so great a lord

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Basely insinuate and send us gifts.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Had he not reason, Lord Demetrius?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Did you not use his daughter very friendly?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I would we had a thousand Roman dames

Author: Shakespeare
Text: At such a bay, by turn to serve our lust.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A charitable wish and full of love.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Here lacks but your mother for to say amen.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And that would she for twenty thousand more.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Come, let us go, and pray to all the gods

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For our beloved mother in her pains.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: [Aside]  Pray to the devils, the gods have given us over.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why do the emperor's trumpets flourish thus?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Belike, for joy the emperor hath a son.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter a Nurse, with a blackamoor Child in her arms

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Good morr ow, lords:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O, tell me, did you see Aaron the Moor?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Well, more or less, or ne'er a whit at all,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Here Aaron is, and what with Aaron now?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O gentle Aaron, we are all undone!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Now help, or woe betide thee evermore!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, what a caterwauling dost thou keep!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What dost thou wrap and fumble in thine arms?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O, that which I would hide from heaven's eye,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Our empress' shame, and stately Rome's disgrace!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: She is deliver'd, lords, she is deliver'd.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I mean, she is brought a-bed.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Well, God give her good rest! What hath he sent her?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A devil.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, then she is the devil's dam, a joyful issue.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A joyless, dismal, black, and sorrowful issue:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Here is the babe, as loathsome as a toad

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Amongst the fairest breeders of our clime:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The empress sends it thee, thy stamp, thy seal,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And bids thee christen it with thy dagger's point.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Zounds, ye whore! is black so base a hue?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sweet blowse, you are a beauteous blossom, sure.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Villain, what hast thou done?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That which thou canst not undo.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thou hast undone our mother.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Villain, I have done thy mother.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And therein, hellish dog, thou hast undone.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Woe to her chance, and damn'd her loathed choice!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Accursed the offspring of so foul a fiend!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: It shall not live.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: It shall not die.

Text: That highly may advantage thee to hear:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If thou wilt not, befall what may befall,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I'll speak no more but 'Vengeance rot you all!'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Say on: an if it please me which thou speak'st

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thy child shall live, and I will see it nourish'd.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: An if it please thee! why, assure thee, Lucius,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Twill vex thy soul to hear what I shall speak,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For I must talk of murders, rapes and massacres,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Acts of black night, abominable deeds,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Complots of mischief, treason, villanies

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ruthful to hear, yet piteously perform'd:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And this shall all be buried by my death,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Unless thou swear to me my child shall live.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Tell on thy mind, I say thy child shall live.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Swear that he shall, and then I will begin.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Who should I swear by? thou believest no god:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That granted, how canst thou believe an oath?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What if I do not? as, indeed, I do not,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Yet, for I know thou art religious

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And hast a thing within thee called conscience,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: With twenty popish tricks and ceremonies,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Which I have seen thee careful to observe,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Therefore I urge thy oath, for that I know

Author: Shakespeare
Text: An idiot holds his bauble for a god

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And keeps the oath which by that god he swears,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To that I'll urge him: therefore thou shalt vow

Author: Shakespeare
Text: By that same god, what god soe'er it be,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That thou adorest and hast in reverence,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To save my boy, to nourish and bring him up,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Or else I will discover nought to thee.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Even by my god I swear to thee I will.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: First know thou, I begot him on the empress.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O most insatiate and luxurious woman!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Tut, Lucius, this was but a deed of charity

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To that which thou shalt hear of me anon.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Twas her two sons that murder'd Bassianus,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: They cut thy sister's tongue and ravish'd her

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And cut her hands and trimm'd her as thou saw'st.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O detestable villain! call'st thou that trimming?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, she was wash'd and cut and trimm'd, and 'twas

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Trim sport for them that had the doing of it.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O barbarous, beastly villains, like thyself!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Indeed, I was their tutor to instruct them:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That codding spirit had they from their mother,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As sure a card as ever won the set,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That bloody mind, I think, they learn'd of me,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As true a dog as ever fought at head.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Well, let my deeds be witness of my worth.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I train'd thy brethren to that guileful hole

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Where the dead corpse of Bassianus lay:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I wrote the letter that thy father found

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And hid the gold within the letter mention'd,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Confederate with the queen and her two sons:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And what not done, that thou hast cause to rue,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Wherein I had no stroke of mischief in it?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I play'd the cheater for thy father's hand,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And, when I had it, drew myself apart

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And almost broke my heart with extreme laughter:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I pry'd me through the crevice of a wall

Author: Shakespeare
Text: When, for his hand, he had his two sons' heads,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Beheld his tears, and laugh'd so heartily,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That both mine eyes were rainy like to his :

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And when I told the empress of this sport,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: She swooned almost at my pleasing tale,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And for my tidings gave me twenty kisses.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What, canst thou say all this, and never blush?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, like a black dog, as the saying is.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Art thou not sorry for these heinous deeds?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, that I had not done a thousand more.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Even now I curse the day--and yet, I think,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Few come within the compass of my curse,--

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Wherein I did not some notorious ill,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As kill a man, or else devise his death,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ravish a maid, or plot the way to do it,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Accuse some innocent and forswear myself,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Set deadly enmity between two friends,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Make poor men's cattle break their necks,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Set fire on barns and hay-stacks in the night,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And bid the owners quench them with their tears.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Oft have I digg'd up dead men from their graves,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And set them upright at their dear friends' doors,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Even when their sorrows almost were forgot,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And on their skins, as on the bark of trees,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Have with my knife carved in Roman letters,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Let not your sorrow die, though I am dead.'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Tut, I have done a thousand dreadful things

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As willingly as one would kill a fly,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And nothing grieves me heartily indeed

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But that I cannot do ten thousand more.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Bring down the devil, for he must not die

Author: Shakespeare
Text: So sweet a death as hanging presently.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If there be devils, would I were a devil,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To live and burn in everlasting fire,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: So I might have your company in hell,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But to torment you with my bitter tongue!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sirs, stop his mouth, and let him speak no more.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter a Goth

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My lord, there is a messenger from Rome

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Desires to be admitted to your presence.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Let him come near.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Welcome, AEmilius	what's the news from Rome?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Lord Lucius, and you princes of the Goths,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The Roman emperor greets you all by me,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And, for he understands you are in arms,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: He craves a parley at your father's house,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Willing you to demand your hostages,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And they shall be immediately deliver'd.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What says our general?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: AEmilius, let the emperor give his pledges

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Unto my father and my uncle Marcus,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And we will come. March away.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: SCENE II. Rome. Before TITUS's house.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter TAMORA, DEMETRIUS, and CHIRON, disguised

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thus, in this strange and sad habiliment,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I will encounter with Andronicus,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And say I am Revenge, sent from below

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To join with him and right his heinous wrongs.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Knock at his study, where, they say, he keeps,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To ruminate strange plots of dire revenge,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Tell him Revenge is come to join with him,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And work confusion on his enemies.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: They knock

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter TITUS, above

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Who doth molest my contemplation?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Is it your trick to make me ope the door,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That so my sad decrees may fly away,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And all my study be to no effect?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You are deceived: for what I mean to do

Author: Shakespeare
Text: See here in bloody lines I have set down,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And what is written shall be executed.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Titus, I am come to talk with thee.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: No, not a word, how can I grace my talk,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Wanting a hand to give it action?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thou hast the odds of me, therefore no more.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If thou didst know me, thou wouldest talk with me.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I am not mad, I know thee well enough:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Witness this wretched stump, witness these crimson lines,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Witness these trenches made by grief and care,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Witness the tiring day and heavy night,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Witness all sorrow, that I know thee well

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For our proud empress, mighty Tamora:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Is not thy coming for my other hand?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Know, thou sad man, I am not Tamora,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: She is thy enemy, and I thy friend:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I am Revenge: sent from the infernal kingdom,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To ease the gnawing vulture of thy mind,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: By working wreakful vengeance on thy foes.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Come down, and welcome me to this world's light,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Confer with me of murder and of death:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: There's not a hollow cave or lurking-place,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: No vast obscurity or misty vale,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Where bloody murder or detested rape

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Can couch for fear, but I will find them out,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And in their ears tell them my dreadful name,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Revenge, which makes the foul offender quake.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Art thou Revenge? and art thou sent to me,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To be a torment to mine enemies?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I am, therefore come down, and welcome me.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Do me some service, ere I come to thee.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Lo, by thy side where Rape and Murder stands,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Now give me some surance that thou art Revenge,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Stab them, or tear them on thy chariot-wheels,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And then I'll come and be thy waggoner,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And whirl along with thee about the globe.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Provide thee two proper palfreys, black as jet,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To hale thy vengeful waggon swift away,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And find out murderers in their guilty caves:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And when thy car is loaden with their heads,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I will dismount, and by the waggon-wheel

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Trot, like a servile footman, all day long,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Even from Hyperion's rising in the east

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Until his very downfall in the sea:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And day by day I'll do this heavy task,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: So thou destroy Rapine and Murder there.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: These are my ministers, and come with me.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Are these thy ministers? what are they call'd?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Rapine and Murder, therefore called so,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Cause they take vengeance of such kind of men.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Good Lord, how like the empress' sons they are!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And you, the empress! but we worldly men

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Have miserable, mad, mistaking eyes.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O sweet Revenge, now do I come to thee,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And, if one arm's embracement will content thee,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I will embrace thee in it by and by.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: This closing with him fits his lunacy

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Whate'er I forge to feed his brain-sick fits,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Do you uphold and maintain in your speeches,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For now he firmly takes me for Revenge,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And, being credulous in this mad thought,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I'll make him send for Lucius his son,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And, whilst I at a banquet hold him sure,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I'll find some cunning practise out of hand,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To scatter and disperse the giddy Goths,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Or, at the least, make them his enemies.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: See, here he comes, and I must ply my theme.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter TITUS below

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Long have I been forlorn, and all for thee:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Welcome, dread Fury, to my woful house:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Rapine and Murder, you are welcome too.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How like the empress and her sons you are!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Well are you fitted, had you but a Moor:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Could not all hell afford you such a devil?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For well I wot the empress never wags

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But in her company there is a Moor,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And, would you represent our queen aright,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: It were convenient you had such a devil:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But welcome, as you are. What shall we do?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What wouldst thou have us do, Andronicus?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Show me a murderer, I'll deal with him.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Show me a villain that hath done a rape,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And I am sent to be revenged on him.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Show me a thousand that have done thee wrong,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And I will be revenged on them all.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Look round about the wicked streets of Rome,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And when thou find'st a man that's like thyself.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Good Murder, stab him, he's a murderer.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Go thou with him, and when it is thy hap

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To find another that is like to thee,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Good Rapine, stab him, he's a ravisher.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Go thou with them, and in the emperor's court

Author: Shakespeare
Text: There is a queen, attended by a Moor,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Well mayst thou know her by thy own proportion,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: for up and down she doth resemble thee:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I pray thee, do on them some violent death,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: They have been violent to me and mine.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Well hast thou lesson'd us, this shall we do.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But would it please thee, good Andronicus,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To send for Lucius, thy thrice-valiant son,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Who leads towards Rome a band of warlike Goths,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And bid him come and banquet at thy house,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: When he is here, even at thy solemn feast,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I will bring in the empress and her sons,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The emperor himself and all thy foes,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And at thy mercy shalt they stoop and kneel,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And on them shalt thou ease thy angry heart.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What says Andronicus to this device?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Marcus, my brother! 'tis sad Titus calls.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Go, gentle Marcus, to thy nephew Lucius,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thou shalt inquire him out among the Goths:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Bid him repair to me, and bring with him

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Some of the chiefest princes of the Goths,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Bid him encamp his soldiers where they are:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Tell him the emperor and the empress too

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Feast at my house, and he shall feast with them.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: This do thou for my love, and so let him,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As he regards his aged father's life.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: This will I do, and soon return again.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Now will I hence about thy business,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And take my ministers along with me.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Nay, nay, let Rape and Murder stay with me,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Or else I'll call my brother back again,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And cleave to no revenge but Lucius.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: [Aside to her sons]  What say you, boys? will you

Author: Shakespeare
Text: bide with him,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Whiles I go tell my lord the emperor

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How I have govern'd our determined jest?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Yield to his humour, smooth and speak him fair,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And tarry with him till I turn again.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: [Aside]  I know them all, though they suppose me mad,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And will o'erreach them in their own devices:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A pair of cursed hell-hounds and their dam!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Madam, depart at pleasure, leave us here.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Farewell, Andronicus: Revenge now goes

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To lay a complot to betray thy foes.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I know thou dost, and, sweet Revenge, farewell.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Exit TAMORA

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Tell us, old man, how shall we be employ'd?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Tut, I have work enough for you to do.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Publius, come hither, Caius, and Valentine!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter PUBLIUS and others

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Know you these two?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The empress' sons, I take them, Chiron and Demetrius.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Fie, Publius, fie! thou art too much deceived,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The one is Murder, Rape is the other's name,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And therefore bind them, gentle Publius.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Caius and Valentine, lay hands on them.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Oft have you heard me wish for such an hour,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And now I find it, therefore bind them sure,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And stop their mouths, if they begin to cry.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: PUBLIUS,  and c. lay hold on CHIRON and DEMETRIUS

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Villains, forbear! we are the empress' sons.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And therefore do we what we are commanded.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Stop close their mouths, let them not speak a word.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Is he sure bound? look that you bind them fast.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Re-enter TITUS, with LAVINIA, he bearing a knife, and she a basin

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Come, come, Lavinia, look, thy foes are bound.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sirs, stop their mouths, let them not speak to me,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But let them hear what fearful words I utter.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O villains, Chiron and Demetrius!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Here stands the spring whom you have stain'd with mud,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: This goodly summer with your winter mix'd.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You kill'd her husband, and for that vile fault

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Two of her brothers were condemn'd to death,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My hand cut off and made a merry jest,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Both her sweet hands, her tongue, and that more dear

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Than hands or tongue, her spotless chastity,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Inhuman traitors, you constrain'd and forced.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What would you say, if I should let you speak?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Villains, for shame you could not beg for grace.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Hark, wretches! how I mean to martyr you.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: This one hand yet is left to cut your throats,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Whilst that Lavinia 'tween her stumps doth hold

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The basin that receives your guilty blood.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You know your mother means to feast with me,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And calls herself Revenge, and thinks me mad:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Hark, villains! I will grind your bones to dust

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And with your blood and it I'll make a paste,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And of the paste a coffin I will rear

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And make two pasties of your shameful heads,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And bid that strumpet, your unhallow'd dam,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Like to the earth swallow her own increase.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: This is the feast that I have bid her to,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And this the banquet she shall surfeit on,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For worse than Philomel you used my daughter,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And worse than Progne I will be revenged:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And now prepare your throats. Lavinia, come,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: He cuts their throats

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Receive the blood: and when that they are dead,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Let me go grind their bones to powder small

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And with this hateful liquor temper it,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And in that paste let their vile heads be baked.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Come, come, be every one officious

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To make this banquet, which I wish may prove

Author: Shakespeare
Text: More stern and bloody than the Centaurs' feast.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: So, now bring them in, for I'll play the cook,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And see them ready 'gainst their mother comes.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Exeunt, bearing the dead bodies

Author: Shakespeare
Text: SCENE III. Court of TITUS's house. A banquet set out.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter LUCIUS, MARCUS, and Goths, with AARON prisoner

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Uncle Marcus, since it is my father's mind

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That I repair to Rome, I am content.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And ours with thine, befall what fortune will.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Good uncle, take you in this barbarous Moor,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: This ravenous tiger, this accursed devil,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Let him receive no sustenance, fetter him

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Till he be brought unto the empress' face,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For testimony of her foul proceedings:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And see the ambush of our friends be strong,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I fear the emperor means no good to us.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Some devil whisper curses in mine ear,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And prompt me, that my tongue may utter forth

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The venomous malice of my swelling heart!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Away, inhuman dog! unhallow'd slave!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sirs, help our uncle to convey him in.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Exeunt Goths, with AARON. Flourish within

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The trumpets show the emperor is at hand.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter SATURNINUS and TAMORA, with AEMILIUS, Tribunes, Senators, and others

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What, hath the firmament more suns than one?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What boots it thee to call thyself a sun?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Rome's emperor, and nephew, break the parle,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: These quarrels must be quietly debated.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The feast is ready, which the careful Titus

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Hath ordain'd to an honourable end,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For peace, for love, for league, and good to Rome:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Please you, therefore, draw nigh, and take your places.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Marcus, we will.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Hautboys sound. The Company sit down at table

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter TITUS dressed like a Cook, LAVINIA veiled,  Young LUCIUS, and others. TITUS places the dishes on the table

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Welcome, my gracious lord, welcome, dread queen,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Welcome, ye warlike Goths, welcome, Lucius,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And welcome, all: although the cheer be poor,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Twill fill your stomachs, please you eat of it.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why art thou thus attired, Andronicus?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Because I would be sure to have all well,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To entertain your highness and your empress.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: We are beholding to you, good Andronicus.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: An if your highness knew my heart, you were.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My lord the emperor, resolve me this:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Was it well done of rash Virginius

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To slay his daughter with his own right hand,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Because she was enforced, stain'd, and deflower'd?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: It was, Andronicus.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Your reason, mighty lord?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Because the girl should not survive her shame,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And by her presence still renew his sorrows.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A reason mighty, strong, and effectual,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A pattern, precedent, and lively warrant,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For me, most wretched, to perform the like.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Die, die, Lavinia, and thy shame with thee,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Kills LAVINIA

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And, with thy shame, thy father's sorrow die!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What hast thou done, unnatural and unkind?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Kill'd her, for whom my tears have made me blind.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I am as woful as Virginius was,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And have a thousand times more cause than he

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To do this outrage: and it now is done.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What, was she ravish'd? tell who did the deed.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Will't please you eat? will't please your

Author: Shakespeare
Text: highness feed?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why hast thou slain thine only daughter thus?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Not I, 'twas Chiron and Demetrius:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: They ravish'd her, and cut away her tongue,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And they, 'twas they, that did her all this wrong.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Go fetch them hither to us presently.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, there they are both, baked in that pie,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Whereof their mother daintily hath fed,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Eating the flesh that she herself hath bred.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Tis true, 'tis true, witness my knife's sharp point.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Kills TAMORA

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Die, frantic wretch, for this accursed deed!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Kills TITUS

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Can the son's eye behold his father bleed?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: There's meed for meed, death for a deadly deed!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Kills SATURNINUS. A great tumult. LUCIUS, MARCUS, and others go up into the balcony

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You sad-faced men, people and sons of Rome,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: By uproar sever'd, like a flight of fowl

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Scatter'd by winds and high tempestuous gusts,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O, let me teach you how to knit again

Text: No notes of sally, for the heavens, sweet brother.

Text: Be gone, I say: the gods have heard me swear.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The gods are deaf to hot and peevish vows:

Text: They are polluted offerings, more abhorr'd

Text: Than spotted livers in the sacrifice.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O, be persuaded! do not count it holy

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To hurt by being just: it is as lawful,

Text: For we would give much, to use violent thefts,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And rob in the behalf of charity.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: It is the purpose that makes strong the vow,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But vows to every purpose must not hold:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Unarm, sweet Hector.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Hold you still, I say,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Mine honour keeps the weather of my fate:

Text: Lie every man holds dear, but the brave man

Text: Holds honour far more precious-dear than life.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How now, young man! mean'st thou to fight to-day?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Cassandra, call my father to persuade.

Text: Exit CASSANDRA

Text: No, faith, young Troilus, doff thy harness, youth,

Text: I am to-day i' the vein of chivalry:

Text: Let grow thy sinews till their knots be strong,

Text: And tempt not yet the brushes of the war.

Text: Unarm thee, go, and doubt thou not, brave boy,

Text: I'll stand to-day for thee and me and Troy.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Brother, you have a vice of mercy in you,

Text: Which better fits a lion than a man.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What vice is that, good Troilus? chide me for it.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: When many times the captive Grecian falls,

Text: Even in the fan and wind of your fair sword,

Text: You bid them rise, and live.

Text: For the love of all the gods,

Text: Beckoning with fiery truncheon my retire,

Text: Not Priamus and Hecuba on knees,

Text: To tell thee that this day is ominous:

Text: And lasting in her sad remembrance.

Text: To pay this debt of love but to a brother,

Author: Shakespeare

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What country, friends, is this?

Text: This is Illyria, lady.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Perchance he is not drown'd: what think you, sailors?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: It is perchance that you yourself were saved.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O my poor brother! and so perchance may he be.

Text: True, madam: and, to comfort you with chance,

Text: Assure yourself, after our ship did split,

Text: When you and those poor number saved with you

Author: Shakespeare

Text: To a strong mast that lived upon the sea,

Text: So long as I could see.

Text: Whereto thy speech serves for authority,

Text: Orsino.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Orsino! I have heard my father name him:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: He was a bachelor then.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For but a month ago I went from hence,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And then 'twas fresh in murmur,--as, you know,

Text: That he did seek the love of fair Olivia.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A virtuous maid, the daughter of a count

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That died some twelvemonth since, then leaving her

Author: Shakespeare
Text: In the protection of his son, her brother,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Who shortly also died: for whose dear love,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: They say, she hath abjured the company

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And sight of men.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Till I had made mine own occasion mellow,

Author: Shakespeare

Text: That were hard to compass,

Text: Because she will admit no kind of suit,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: No, not the duke's.

Text: There is a fair behavior in thee, captain,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And though that nature with a beauteous wall

Text: Doth oft close in pollution, yet of thee

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I will believe thou hast a mind that suits

Author: Shakespeare
Text: With this thy fair and outward character.

Author: Shakespeare

Author: Shakespeare

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For such disguise as haply shall become

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The form of my intent. I'll serve this duke:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thou shall present me as an eunuch to him:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: It may be worth thy pains, for I can sing

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And speak to him in many sorts of music

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That will allow me very worth his service.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What else may hap to time I will commit,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Only shape thou thy silence to my wit.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Be you his eunuch, and your mute I'll be:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: When my tongue blabs, then let mine eyes not see.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I thank thee: lead me on.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: nights: your cousin, my lady, takes great

Author: Shakespeare

Author: Shakespeare
Text: he hath the gift of a coward to allay the gust he

Author: Shakespeare
Text: he would quickly have the gift of a grave.

Author: Shakespeare

Author: Shakespeare
Text: that say so of him. Who are they?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: With drinking healths to my niece: I'll drink to

Author: Shakespeare
Text: her as long as there is a passage in my throat and

Author: Shakespeare

Text: that will not drink to my niece till his brains turn

Author: Shakespeare
Text: o' the toe like a parish-top. What, wench!

Text: Ay, sir, I have them at my fingers' ends: marry,

Author: Shakespeare

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Not yet old enough for a man, nor young enough for

Author: Shakespeare
Text: a boy, as a squash is before 'tis a peascod, or a

Author: Shakespeare
Text: cooling when 'tis almost an apple: 'tis with him

Author: Shakespeare
Text: in standing water, between boy and man. He is very

Author: Shakespeare
Text: well-favoured and he speaks very shrewishly, one

Author: Shakespeare
Text: would think his mother's milk were scarce out of him.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Let him approach: call in my gentlewoman.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Gentlewoman, my lady calls.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Give me my veil: come, throw it o'er my face.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: We'll once more hear Orsino's embassy.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter VIOLA, and Attendants

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The honourable lady of the house, which is she?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Speak to me, I shall answer for her.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Most radiant, exquisite and unmatchable beauty,--I

Author: Shakespeare
Text: pray you, tell me if this be the lady of the house,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: for I never saw her: I would be loath to cast away

Author: Shakespeare
Text: my speech, for besides that it is excellently well

Author: Shakespeare
Text: penned, I have taken great pains to con it. Good

Author: Shakespeare
Text: beauties, let me sustain no scorn, I am very

Author: Shakespeare
Text: comptible, even to the least sinister usage.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Whence came you, sir?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I can say little more than I have studied, and that

Author: Shakespeare
Text: question's out of my part. Good gentle one, give me

Author: Shakespeare
Text: modest assurance if you be the lady of the house,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: that I may proceed in my speech.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Are you a comedian?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: No, my profound heart: and yet, by the very fangs

Author: Shakespeare
Text: of malice I swear, I am not that I play. Are you

Author: Shakespeare
Text: the lady of the house?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If I do not usurp myself, I am.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Most certain, if you are she, you do usurp

Author: Shakespeare
Text: yourself, for what is yours to bestow is not yours

Author: Shakespeare
Text: to reserve. But this is from my commission: I will

Author: Shakespeare
Text: on with my speech in your praise, and then show you

Author: Shakespeare
Text: the heart of my message.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Come to what is important in't: I forgive you the praise.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Alas, I took great pains to study it, and 'tis poetical.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: It is the more like to be feigned: I pray you,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: keep it in. I heard you were saucy at my gates,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: and allowed your approach rather to wonder at you

Author: Shakespeare
Text: than to hear you. If you be not mad, be gone, if

Author: Shakespeare
Text: you have reason, be brief: 'tis not that time of

Author: Shakespeare
Text: moon with me to make one in so skipping a dialogue.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Will you hoist sail, sir? here lies your way.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: No, good swabber, I am to hull here a little

Author: Shakespeare
Text: longer. Some mollification for your giant, sweet

Author: Shakespeare
Text: lady. Tell me your mind: I am a messenger.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sure, you have some hideous matter to deliver, when

Author: Shakespeare
Text: the courtesy of it is so fearful. Speak your office.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: It alone concerns your ear. I bring no overture of

Author: Shakespeare
Text: war, no taxation of homage: I hold the olive in my

Author: Shakespeare
Text: hand, my words are as fun of peace as matter.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Yet you began rudely. What are you? what would you?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The rudeness that hath appeared in me have I

Author: Shakespeare
Text: learned from my entertainment. What I am, and what I

Author: Shakespeare
Text: would, are as secret as maidenhead, to your ears,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: divinity, to any other's, profanation.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Give us the place alone: we will hear this divinity.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Exeunt MARIA and Attendants

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Now, sir, what is your text?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Most sweet lady,--

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A comfortable doctrine, and much may be said of it.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Where lies your text?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: In Orsino's bosom.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: In his bosom! In what chapter of his bosom?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To answer by the method, in the first of his heart.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O, I have read it: it is heresy. Have you no more to say?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Good madam, let me see your face.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Have you any commission from your lord to negotiate

Author: Shakespeare
Text: with my face? You are now out of your text: but

Author: Shakespeare
Text: we will draw the curtain and show you the picture.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Look you, sir, such a one I was this present: is't

Author: Shakespeare
Text: not well done?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Excellently done, if God did all.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Tis in grain, sir, 'twill endure wind and weather.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Tis beauty truly blent, whose red and white

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Nature's own sweet and cunning hand laid on:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Lady, you are the cruell'st she alive,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If you will lead these graces to the grave

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And leave the world no copy.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O, sir, I will not be so hard-hearted, I will give

Author: Shakespeare
Text: out divers schedules of my beauty: it shall be

Author: Shakespeare
Text: inventoried, and every particle and utensil

Author: Shakespeare
Text: labelled to my will: as, item, two lips,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: indifferent red, item, two grey eyes, with lids to

Author: Shakespeare
Text: them, item, one neck, one chin, and so forth. Were

Author: Shakespeare
Text: you sent hither to praise me?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I see you what you are, you are too proud,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But, if you were the devil, you are fair.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My lord and master loves you: O, such love

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Could be but recompensed, though you were crown'd

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The nonpareil of beauty!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How does he love me?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: With adorations, fertile tears,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: With groans that thunder love, with sighs of fire.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Your lord does know my mind, I cannot love him:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Yet I suppose him virtuous, know him noble,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Of great estate, of fresh and stainless youth,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: In voices well divulged, free, learn'd and valiant,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And in dimension and the shape of nature

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A gracious person: but yet I cannot love him,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: He might have took his answer long ago.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If I did love you in my master's flame,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: With such a suffering, such a deadly life,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: In your denial I would find no sense,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I would not understand it.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, what would you?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Make me a willow cabin at your gate,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And call upon my soul within the house,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Write loyal cantons of contemned love

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And sing them loud even in the dead of night,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Halloo your name to the reverberate hills

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And make the babbling gossip of the air

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Cry out 'Olivia!' O, You should not rest

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Between the elements of air and earth,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But you should pity me!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You might do much.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What is your parentage?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Above my fortunes, yet my state is well:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I am a gentleman.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Get you to your lord,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I cannot love him: let him send no more,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Unless, perchance, you come to me again,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To tell me how he takes it. Fare you well:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I thank you for your pains: spend this for me.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I am no fee'd post, lady, keep your purse:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My master, not myself, lacks recompense.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Love make his heart of flint that you shall love,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And let your fervor, like my master's, be

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Placed in contempt! Farewell, fair cruelty.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'What is your parentage?'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Above my fortunes, yet my state is well:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I am a gentleman.' I'll be sworn thou art,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thy tongue, thy face, thy limbs, actions and spirit,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Do give thee five-fold blazon: not too fast:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: soft, soft!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Unless the master were the man. How now!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Even so quickly may one catch the plague?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Methinks I feel this youth's perfections

Author: Shakespeare
Text: With an invisible and subtle stealth

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To creep in at mine eyes. Well, let it be.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What ho, Malvolio!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Here, madam, at your service.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Run after that same peevish messenger,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The county's man: he left this ring behind him,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Would I or not: tell him I'll none of it.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Desire him not to flatter with his lord,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Nor hold him up with hopes, I am not for him:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If that the youth will come this way to-morrow,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I'll give him reasons for't: hie thee, Malvolio.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I do I know not what, and fear to find

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Mine eye too great a flatterer for my mind.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Fate, show thy force: ourselves we do not owe,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What is decreed must be, and be this so.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: SCENE I. The sea-coast.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter ANTONIO and SEBASTIAN

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Will you stay no longer? nor will you not that I go with you?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: By your patience, no. My stars shine darkly over

Author: Shakespeare
Text: me: the malignancy of my fate might perhaps

Author: Shakespeare
Text: distemper yours, therefore I shall crave of you your

Author: Shakespeare
Text: leave that I may bear my evils alone: it were a bad

Author: Shakespeare
Text: recompense for your love, to lay any of them on you.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: ANTONIO: Let me yet know of you whither you are bound.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: No, sooth, sir: my determinate voyage is mere

Author: Shakespeare
Text: extravagancy. But I perceive in you so excellent a

Author: Shakespeare
Text: touch of modesty, that you will not extort from me

Author: Shakespeare
Text: what I am willing to keep in, therefore it charges

Author: Shakespeare
Text: me in manners the rather to express myself. You

Author: Shakespeare
Text: must know of me then, Antonio, my name is Sebastian,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: which I called Roderigo. My father was that

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sebastian of Messaline, whom I know you have heard

Author: Shakespeare
Text: of. He left behind him myself and a sister, both

Author: Shakespeare
Text: born in an hour: if the heavens had been pleased,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: would we had so ended! but you, sir, altered that,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: for some hour before you took me from the breach of

Author: Shakespeare
Text: the sea was my sister drowned.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Alas the day!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A lady, sir, though it was said she much resembled

Author: Shakespeare
Text: me, was yet of many accounted beautiful: but,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: though I could not with such estimable wonder

Author: Shakespeare
Text: overfar believe that, yet thus far I will boldly

Author: Shakespeare
Text: publish her, she bore a mind that envy could not but

Author: Shakespeare
Text: call fair. She is drowned already, sir, with salt

Author: Shakespeare
Text: water, though I seem to drown her remembrance again with more.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Pardon me, sir, your bad entertainment.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O good Antonio, forgive me your trouble.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If you will not murder me for my love, let me be

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If you will not undo what you have done, that is,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: kill him whom you have recovered, desire it not.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Fare ye well at once: my bosom is full of kindness,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: and I am yet so near the manners of my mother, that

Author: Shakespeare
Text: upon the least occasion more mine eyes will tell

Author: Shakespeare
Text: tales of me. I am bound to the Count Orsino's court: farewell.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The gentleness of all the gods go with thee!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I have many enemies in Orsino's court,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Else would I very shortly see thee there.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But, come what may, I do adore thee so,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That danger shall seem sport, and I will go.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter VIOLA, MALVOLIO following

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Were not you even now with the Countess Olivia?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Even now, sir, on a moderate pace I have since

Author: Shakespeare
Text: arrived but hither.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: She returns this ring to you, sir: you might have

Author: Shakespeare
Text: saved me my pains, to have taken it away yourself.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: She adds, moreover, that you should put your lord

Author: Shakespeare
Text: into a desperate assurance she will none of him:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: and one thing more, that you be never so hardy to

Author: Shakespeare
Text: come again in his affairs, unless it be to report

Author: Shakespeare
Text: your lord's taking of this. Receive it so.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: She took the ring of me: I'll none of it.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Come, sir, you peevishly threw it to her, and her

Author: Shakespeare
Text: will is, it should be so returned: if it be worth

Author: Shakespeare
Text: stooping for, there it lies in your eye, if not, be

Author: Shakespeare
Text: it his that finds it.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I left no ring with her: what means this lady?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Fortune forbid my outside have not charm'd her!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: She made good view of me, indeed, so much,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That sure methought her eyes had lost her tongue,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For she did speak in starts distractedly.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: She loves me, sure, the cunning of her passion

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Invites me in this churlish messenger.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: None of my lord's ring! why, he sent her none.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I am the man: if it be so, as 'tis,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Poor lady, she were better love a dream.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Disguise, I see, thou art a wickedness,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Wherein the pregnant enemy does much.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How easy is it for the proper-false

Author: Shakespeare
Text: In women's waxen hearts to set their forms!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Alas, our frailty is the cause, not we!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For such as we are made of, such we be.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How will this fadge? my master loves her dearly,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And I, poor monster, fond as much on him,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And she, mistaken, seems to dote on me.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What will become of this? As I am man,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My state is desperate for my master's love,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As I am woman,--now alas the day!--

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What thriftless sighs shall poor Olivia breathe!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O time! thou must untangle this, not I,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: It is too hard a knot for me to untie!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: SCENE III. OLIVIA's house.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter SIR TOBY BELCH and SIR ANDREW

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Approach, Sir Andrew: not to be abed after

Author: Shakespeare
Text: midnight is to be up betimes, and 'diluculo

Author: Shakespeare
Text: surgere,' thou know'st,--

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Nay, my troth, I know not: but I know, to be up

Author: Shakespeare
Text: late is to be up late.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A false conclusion: I hate it as an unfilled can.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To be up after midnight and to go to bed then, is

Author: Shakespeare
Text: early: so that to go to bed after midnight is to go

Author: Shakespeare
Text: to bed betimes. Does not our life consist of the

Author: Shakespeare
Text: four elements?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Faith, so they say, but I think it rather consists

Author: Shakespeare
Text: of eating and drinking.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thou'rt a scholar, let us therefore eat and drink.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Marian, I say! a stoup of wine!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Here comes the fool, i' faith.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How now, my hearts! did you never see the picture

Author: Shakespeare
Text: of 'we three'?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Welcome, ass. Now let's have a catch.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: By my troth, the fool has an excellent breast. I

Author: Shakespeare
Text: had rather than forty shillings I had such a leg,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: and so sweet a breath to sing, as the fool has. In

Author: Shakespeare
Text: sooth, thou wast in very gracious fooling last

Author: Shakespeare
Text: night, when thou spokest of Pigrogromitus, of the

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Vapians passing the equinoctial of Queubus: 'twas

Author: Shakespeare
Text: very good, i' faith. I sent thee sixpence for thy

Author: Shakespeare
Text: leman: hadst it?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I did impeticos thy gratillity, for Malvolio's nose

Author: Shakespeare
Text: is no whipstock: my lady has a white hand, and the

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Myrmidons are no bottle-ale houses.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Excellent! why, this is the best fooling, when all

Author: Shakespeare
Text: is done. Now, a song.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Come on, there is sixpence for you: let's have a song.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: There's a testril of me too: if one knight give a--

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Would you have a love-song, or a song of good life?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A love-song, a love-song.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, ay: I care not for good life.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O mistress mine, where are you roaming?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O, stay and hear, your true love's coming,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That can sing both high and low:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Trip no further, pretty sweeting,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Journeys end in lovers meeting,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Every wise man's son doth know.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Excellent good, i' faith.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Good, good.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What is love? 'tis not hereafter,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Present mirth hath present laughter,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What's to come is still unsure:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: In delay there lies no plenty,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Then come kiss me, sweet and twenty,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Youth's a stuff will not endure.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A mellifluous voice, as I am true knight.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A contagious breath.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Very sweet and contagious, i' faith.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To hear by the nose, it is dulcet in contagion.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But shall we make the welkin dance indeed? shall we

Author: Shakespeare
Text: rouse the night-owl in a catch that will draw three

Author: Shakespeare
Text: souls out of one weaver? shall we do that?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: An you love me, let's do't: I am dog at a catch.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: By'r lady, sir, and some dogs will catch well.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Most certain. Let our catch be, 'Thou knave.'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Hold thy peace, thou knave,' knight? I shall be

Author: Shakespeare
Text: constrained in't to call thee knave, knight.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Tis not the first time I have constrained one to

Author: Shakespeare
Text: call me knave. Begin, fool: it begins 'Hold thy peace.'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I shall never begin if I hold my peace.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Good, i' faith. Come, begin.

Text: Enter MARIA

Text: Enter MARIA

Text: Enter MARIA

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What a caterwauling do you keep here! If my lady

Author: Shakespeare
Text: have not called up her steward Malvolio and bid him

Author: Shakespeare
Text: turn you out of doors, never trust me.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My lady's a Cataian, we are politicians, Malvolio's

Author: Shakespeare
Text: a Peg-a-Ramsey, and 'Three merry men be we.' Am not

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I consanguineous? am I not of her blood?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Tillyvally. Lady!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'There dwelt a man in Babylon, lady, lady!'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Beshrew me, the knight's in admirable fooling.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, he does well enough if he be disposed, and so do

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I too: he does it with a better grace, but I do it

Author: Shakespeare
Text: more natural.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: [Sings]  'O, the twelfth day of December,'--

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For the love o' God, peace!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter MALVOLIO

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter MALVOLIO

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My masters, are you mad? or what are you? Have ye

Author: Shakespeare
Text: no wit, manners, nor honesty, but to gabble like

Author: Shakespeare
Text: tinkers at this time of night? Do ye make an

Author: Shakespeare
Text: alehouse of my lady's house, that ye squeak out your

Author: Shakespeare
Text: coziers' catches without any mitigation or remorse

Author: Shakespeare
Text: of voice? Is there no respect of place, persons, nor

Author: Shakespeare
Text: time in you?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: We did keep time, sir, in our catches. Sneck up!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sir Toby, I must be round with you. My lady bade me

Author: Shakespeare
Text: tell you, that, though she harbours you as her

Author: Shakespeare
Text: kinsman, she's nothing allied to your disorders. If

Author: Shakespeare
Text: you can separate yourself and your misdemeanors, you

Author: Shakespeare
Text: are welcome to the house, if not, an it would please

Author: Shakespeare
Text: you to take leave of her, she is very willing to bid

Author: Shakespeare
Text: you farewell.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Farewell, dear heart, since I must needs be gone.'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Nay, good Sir Toby.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'His eyes do show his days are almost done.'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Is't even so?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'But I will never die.'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sir Toby, there you lie.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: This is much credit to you.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Shall I bid him go?'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'What an if you do?'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Shall I bid him go, and spare not?'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'O no, no, no, no, you dare not.'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Out o' tune, sir: ye lie. Art any more than a

Author: Shakespeare
Text: steward? Dost thou think, because thou art

Author: Shakespeare
Text: virtuous, there shall be no more cakes and ale?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Yes, by Saint Anne, and ginger shall be hot i' the

Author: Shakespeare
Text: mouth too.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thou'rt i' the right. Go, sir, rub your chain with

Author: Shakespeare
Text: crumbs. A stoup of wine, Maria!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Mistress Mary, if you prized my lady's favour at any

Author: Shakespeare
Text: thing more than contempt, you would not give means

Author: Shakespeare
Text: for this uncivil rule: she shall know of it, by this hand.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Go shake your ears.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Twere as good a deed as to drink when a man's

Author: Shakespeare
Text: a-hungry, to challenge him the field, and then to

Author: Shakespeare
Text: break promise with him and make a fool of him.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Do't, knight: I'll write thee a challenge: or I'll

Author: Shakespeare
Text: deliver thy indignation to him by word of mouth.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sweet Sir Toby, be patient for tonight: since the

Author: Shakespeare
Text: youth of the count's was today with thy lady, she is

Author: Shakespeare
Text: much out of quiet. For Monsieur Malvolio, let me

Author: Shakespeare
Text: alone with him: if I do not gull him into a

Author: Shakespeare
Text: nayword, and make him a common recreation, do not

Author: Shakespeare
Text: think I have wit enough to lie straight in my bed:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I know I can do it.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Possess us, possess us, tell us something of him.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Marry, sir, sometimes he is a kind of puritan.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O, if I thought that I'ld beat him like a dog!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What, for being a puritan? thy exquisite reason,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: dear knight?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I have no exquisite reason for't, but I have reason

Author: Shakespeare
Text: good enough.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The devil a puritan that he is, or any thing

Author: Shakespeare
Text: constantly, but a time-pleaser, an affectioned ass,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: that cons state without book and utters it by great

Author: Shakespeare
Text: swarths: the best persuaded of himself, so

Author: Shakespeare
Text: crammed, as he thinks, with excellencies, that it is

Author: Shakespeare
Text: his grounds of faith that all that look on him love

Author: Shakespeare
Text: him, and on that vice in him will my revenge find

Author: Shakespeare
Text: notable cause to work.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What wilt thou do?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I will drop in his way some obscure epistles of

Author: Shakespeare
Text: love, wherein, by the colour of his beard, the shape

Author: Shakespeare
Text: of his leg, the manner of his gait, the expressure

Author: Shakespeare
Text: of his eye, forehead, and complexion, he shall find

Author: Shakespeare
Text: himself most feelingly personated. I can write very

Author: Shakespeare
Text: like my lady your niece: on a forgotten matter we

Author: Shakespeare
Text: can hardly make distinction of our hands.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Excellent! I smell a device.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I have't in my nose too.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: He shall think, by the letters that thou wilt drop,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: that they come from my niece, and that she's in

Author: Shakespeare
Text: love with him.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My purpose is, indeed, a horse of that colour.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And your horse now would make him an ass.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ass, I doubt not.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O, 'twill be admirable!

Text: He hath been most notoriously abused.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Pursue him and entreat him to a peace:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: He hath not told us of the captain yet:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: When that is known and golden time convents,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A solemn combination shall be made

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Of our dear souls. Meantime, sweet sister,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: We will not part from hence. Cesario, come,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For so you shall be, while you are a man,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But when in other habits you are seen,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Orsino's mistress and his fancy's queen.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Exeunt all, except Clown

Author: Shakespeare
Text: When that I was and a little tiny boy,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: With hey, ho, the wind and the rain,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A foolish thing was but a toy,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But when I came to man's estate,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: With hey, ho,  and c.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: With hey, ho,  and c.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: With hey, ho,  and c.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: With hey, ho,  and c.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Gainst knaves and thieves men shut their gate,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For the rain,  and c.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For the rain,  and c.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For the rain,  and c.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But when I came, alas! to wive,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: By swaggering could I never thrive,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But when I came unto my beds,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: With toss-pots still had drunken heads,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A great while ago the world begun,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But that's all one, our play is done,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And we'll strive to please you every day.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter VALENTINE and PROTEUS

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Cease to persuade, my loving Proteus:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Home-keeping youth have ever homely wits.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Were't not affection chains thy tender days

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To the sweet glances of thy honour'd love,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I rather would entreat thy company

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To see the wonders of the world abroad,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Than, living dully sluggardized at home,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Wear out thy youth with shapeless idleness.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But since thou lovest, love still and thrive therein,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Even as I would when I to love begin.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Wilt thou be gone? Sweet Valentine, adieu!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Think on thy Proteus, when thou haply seest

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Some rare note-worthy object in thy travel:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Wish me partaker in thy happiness

Author: Shakespeare
Text: When thou dost meet good hap, and in thy danger,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If ever danger do environ thee,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Commend thy grievance to my holy prayers,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For I will be thy beadsman, Valentine.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And on a love-book pray for my success?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Upon some book I love I'll pray for thee.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That's on some shallow story of deep love:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How young Leander cross'd the Hellespont.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That's a deep story of a deeper love:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For he was more than over shoes in love.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Tis true, for you are over boots in love,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And yet you never swum the Hellespont.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Over the boots? nay, give me not the boots.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: No, I will not, for it boots thee not.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To be in love, where scorn is bought with groans,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Coy looks with heart-sore sighs, one fading moment's mirth

Author: Shakespeare
Text: With twenty watchful, weary, tedious nights:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If haply won, perhaps a hapless gain,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If lost, why then a grievous labour won,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: However, but a folly bought with wit,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Or else a wit by folly vanquished.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: So, by your circumstance, you call me fool.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: So, by your circumstance, I fear you'll prove.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Tis love you cavil at: I am not Love.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Love is your master, for he masters you:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And he that is so yoked by a fool,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Methinks, should not be chronicled for wise.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Yet writers say, as in the sweetest bud

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The eating canker dwells, so eating love

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Inhabits in the finest wits of all.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And writers say, as the most forward bud

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Is eaten by the canker ere it blow,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Even so by love the young and tender wit

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Is turn'd to folly, blasting in the bud,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Losing his verdure even in the prime

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And all the fair effects of future hopes.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But wherefore waste I time to counsel thee,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That art a votary to fond desire?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Once more adieu! my father at the road

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Expects my coming, there to see me shipp'd.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And thither will I bring thee, Valentine.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sweet Proteus, no, now let us take our leave.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To Milan let me hear from thee by letters

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Of thy success in love, and what news else

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Betideth here in absence of thy friend,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And likewise will visit thee with mine.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: All happiness bechance to thee in Milan!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As much to you at home! and so, farewell.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: He after honour hunts, I after love:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: He leaves his friends to dignify them more,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I leave myself, my friends and all, for love.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thou, Julia, thou hast metamorphosed me,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Made me neglect my studies, lose my time,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: War with good counsel, set the world at nought,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Made wit with musing weak, heart sick with thought.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter SPEED

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter SPEED

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sir Proteus, save you! Saw you my master?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But now he parted hence, to embark for Milan.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Twenty to one then he is shipp'd already,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And I have play'd the sheep in losing him.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Indeed, a sheep doth very often stray,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: An if the shepherd be a while away.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You conclude that my master is a shepherd, then,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: and I a sheep?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why then, my horns are his horns, whether I wake or sleep.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A silly answer and fitting well a sheep.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: This proves me still a sheep.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: True, and thy master a shepherd.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Nay, that I can deny by a circumstance.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: It shall go hard but I'll prove it by another.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The shepherd seeks the sheep, and not the sheep the

Author: Shakespeare
Text: shepherd, but I seek my master, and my master seeks

Author: Shakespeare
Text: not me: therefore I am no sheep.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The sheep for fodder follow the shepherd, the

Author: Shakespeare
Text: shepherd for food follows not the sheep: thou for

Author: Shakespeare
Text: wages followest thy master, thy master for wages

Author: Shakespeare
Text: follows not thee: therefore thou art a sheep.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Such another proof will make me cry 'baa.'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But, dost thou hear? gavest thou my letter to Julia?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay sir: I, a lost mutton, gave your letter to her,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: a laced mutton, and she, a laced mutton, gave me, a

Author: Shakespeare
Text: lost mutton, nothing for my labour.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Here's too small a pasture for such store of muttons.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If the ground be overcharged, you were best stick her.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Nay: in that you are astray, 'twere best pound you.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Nay, sir, less than a pound shall serve me for

Author: Shakespeare
Text: carrying your letter.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You mistake, I mean the pound,--a pinfold.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: From a pound to a pin? fold it over and over,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Tis threefold too little for carrying a letter to

Author: Shakespeare
Text: your lover.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But what said she?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: [First nodding]  Ay.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Nod--Ay--why, that's noddy.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You mistook, sir, I say, she did nod: and you ask

Author: Shakespeare
Text: me if she did nod, and I say, 'Ay.'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And that set together is noddy.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Now you have taken the pains to set it together,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: take it for your pains.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: No, no, you shall have it for bearing the letter.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Well, I perceive I must be fain to bear with you.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why sir, how do you bear with me?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Marry, sir, the letter, very orderly, having nothing

Author: Shakespeare
Text: but the word 'noddy' for my pains.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Beshrew me, but you have a quick wit.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And yet it cannot overtake your slow purse.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Come come, open the matter in brief: what said she?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Open your purse, that the money and the matter may

Author: Shakespeare
Text: be both at once delivered.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Well, sir, here is for your pains. What said she?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Truly, sir, I think you'll hardly win her.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, couldst thou perceive so much from her?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sir, I could perceive nothing at all from her, no,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: not so much as a ducat for delivering your letter:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: and being so hard to me that brought your mind, I

Author: Shakespeare
Text: fear she'll prove as hard to you in telling your

Author: Shakespeare
Text: mind. Give her no token but stones, for she's as

Author: Shakespeare
Text: hard as steel.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What said she? nothing?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: No, not so much as 'Take this for thy pains.' To

Author: Shakespeare
Text: testify your bounty, I thank you, you have testerned

Author: Shakespeare
Text: me, in requital whereof, henceforth carry your

Author: Shakespeare
Text: letters yourself: and so, sir, I'll commend you to my master.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Go, go, be gone, to save your ship from wreck,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Which cannot perish having thee aboard,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Being destined to a drier death on shore.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Exit SPEED

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I must go send some better messenger:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I fear my Julia would not deign my lines,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Receiving them from such a worthless post.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter JULlA and LUCETTA

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But say, Lucetta, now we are alone,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Wouldst thou then counsel me to fall in love?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, madam, so you stumble not unheedfully.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Of all the fair resort of gentlemen

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That every day with parle encounter me,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: In thy opinion which is worthiest love?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Please you repeat their names, I'll show my mind

Author: Shakespeare
Text: According to my shallow simple skill.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What think'st thou of the fair Sir Eglamour?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As of a knight well-spoken, neat and fine,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But, were I you, he never should be mine.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What think'st thou of the rich Mercatio?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Well of his wealth, but of himself, so so.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What think'st thou of the gentle Proteus?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Lord, Lord! to see what folly reigns in us!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How now! what means this passion at his name?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Pardon, dear madam: 'tis a passing shame

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That I, unworthy body as I am,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Should censure thus on lovely gentlemen.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why not on Proteus, as of all the rest?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Then thus: of many good I think him best.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I have no other, but a woman's reason,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I think him so because I think him so.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And wouldst thou have me cast my love on him?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, if you thought your love not cast away.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why he, of all the rest, hath never moved me.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Yet he, of all the rest, I think, best loves ye.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: His little speaking shows his love but small.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Fire that's closest kept burns most of all.

Author: Shakespeare
