Text: They do not love that do not show their love.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O, they love least that let men know their love.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I would I knew his mind.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Peruse this paper, madam.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'To Julia.' Say, from whom?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That the contents will show.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Say, say, who gave it thee?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Valentine's page, and sent, I think, from Proteus.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: He would have given it you, but I, being in the way,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Did in your name receive it: pardon the

Author: Shakespeare
Text: fault I pray.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Now, by my modesty, a goodly broker!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Dare you presume to harbour wanton lines?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To whisper and conspire against my youth?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Now, trust me, 'tis an office of great worth

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And you an officer fit for the place.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Or else return no more into my sight.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To plead for love deserves more fee than hate.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Will ye be gone?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That you may ruminate.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And yet I would I had o'erlooked the letter:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: It were a shame to call her back again

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And pray her to a fault for which I chid her.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What a fool is she, that knows I am a maid,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And would not force the letter to my view!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Since maids, in modesty, say 'no' to that

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Which they would have the profferer construe 'ay.'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Fie, fie, how wayward is this foolish love

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That, like a testy babe, will scratch the nurse

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And presently all humbled kiss the rod!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How churlishly I chid Lucetta hence,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: When willingly I would have had her here!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How angerly I taught my brow to frown,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: When inward joy enforced my heart to smile!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My penance is to call Lucetta back

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And ask remission for my folly past.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What ho! Lucetta!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Re-enter LUCETTA

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Re-enter LUCETTA

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What would your ladyship?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Is't near dinner-time?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I would it were,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That you might kill your stomach on your meat

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And not upon your maid.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What is't that you took up so gingerly?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why didst thou stoop, then?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To take a paper up that I let fall.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And is that paper nothing?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Nothing concerning me.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Then let it lie for those that it concerns.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Madam, it will not lie where it concerns

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Unless it have a false interpeter.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Some love of yours hath writ to you in rhyme.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That I might sing it, madam, to a tune.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Give me a note: your ladyship can set.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As little by such toys as may be possible.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Best sing it to the tune of 'Light o' love.'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: It is too heavy for so light a tune.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Heavy! belike it hath some burden then?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, and melodious were it, would you sing it.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And why not you?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I cannot reach so high.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Let's see your song. How now, minion!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Keep tune there still, so you will sing it out:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And yet methinks I do not like this tune.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You do not?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: No, madam, it is too sharp.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You, minion, are too saucy.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Nay, now you are too flat

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And mar the concord with too harsh a descant:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: There wanteth but a mean to fill your song.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The mean is drown'd with your unruly bass.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Indeed, I bid the base for Proteus.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: This babble shall not henceforth trouble me.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Here is a coil with protestation!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Tears the letter

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Go get you gone, and let the papers lie:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You would be fingering them, to anger me.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: She makes it strange, but she would be best pleased

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To be so anger'd with another letter.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Nay, would I were so anger'd with the same!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O hateful hands, to tear such loving words!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Injurious wasps, to feed on such sweet honey

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And kill the bees that yield it with your stings!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I'll kiss each several paper for amends.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Look, here is writ 'kind Julia.' Unkind Julia!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As in revenge of thy ingratitude,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I throw thy name against the bruising stones,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Trampling contemptuously on thy disdain.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And here is writ 'love-wounded Proteus.'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Poor wounded name! my bosom as a bed

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Shall lodge thee till thy wound be thoroughly heal'd,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And thus I search it with a sovereign kiss.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But twice or thrice was 'Proteus' written down.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Be calm, good wind, blow not a word away

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Till I have found each letter in the letter,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Except mine own name: that some whirlwind bear

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Unto a ragged fearful-hanging rock

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And throw it thence into the raging sea!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Lo, here in one line is his name twice writ,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Poor forlorn Proteus, passionate Proteus,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To the sweet Julia:' that I'll tear away.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And yet I will not, sith so prettily

Author: Shakespeare
Text: He couples it to his complaining names.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thus will I fold them one on another:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Now kiss, embrace, contend, do what you will.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Dinner is ready, and your father stays.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Well, let us go.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What, shall these papers lie like tell-tales here?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If you respect them, best to take them up.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Nay, I was taken up for laying them down:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Yet here they shall not lie, for catching cold.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I see you have a month's mind to them.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, madam, you may say what sights you see,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I see things too, although you judge I wink.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Come, come, will't please you go?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: SCENE III. The same. ANTONIO's house.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter ANTONIO and PANTHINO

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Tell me, Panthino, what sad talk was that

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Wherewith my brother held you in the cloister?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Twas of his nephew Proteus, your son.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, what of him?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: He wonder'd that your lordship

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Would suffer him to spend his youth at home,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: While other men, of slender reputation,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Put forth their sons to seek preferment out:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Some to the wars, to try their fortune there,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Some to discover islands far away,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Some to the studious universities.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For any or for all these exercises,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: He said that Proteus your son was meet,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And did request me to importune you

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To let him spend his time no more at home,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Which would be great impeachment to his age,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: In having known no travel in his youth.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Nor need'st thou much importune me to that

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Whereon this month I have been hammering.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I have consider'd well his loss of time

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And how he cannot be a perfect man,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Not being tried and tutor'd in the world:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Experience is by industry achieved

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And perfected by the swift course of time.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Then tell me, whither were I best to send him?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I think your lordship is not ignorant

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How his companion, youthful Valentine,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Attends the emperor in his royal court.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I know it well.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Twere good, I think, your lordship sent him thither:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: There shall he practise tilts and tournaments,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Hear sweet discourse, converse with noblemen.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And be in eye of every exercise

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Worthy his youth and nobleness of birth.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I like thy counsel, well hast thou advised:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And that thou mayst perceive how well I like it,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The execution of it shall make known.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Even with the speediest expedition

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I will dispatch him to the emperor's court.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To-morrow, may it please you, Don Alphonso,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: With other gentlemen of good esteem,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Are journeying to salute the emperor

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And to commend their service to his will.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Good company, with them shall Proteus go:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And, in good time! now will we break with him.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter PROTEUS

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter PROTEUS

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter PROTEUS

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter PROTEUS

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter PROTEUS

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sweet love! sweet lines! sweet life!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Here is her hand, the agent of her heart,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Here is her oath for love, her honour's pawn.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O, that our fathers would applaud our loves,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To seal our happiness with their consents!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O heavenly Julia!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How now! what letter are you reading there?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: May't please your lordship, 'tis a word or two

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Of commendations sent from Valentine,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Deliver'd by a friend that came from him.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Lend me the letter, let me see what news.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: There is no news, my lord, but that he writes

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How happily he lives, how well beloved

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And daily graced by the emperor,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Wishing me with him, partner of his fortune.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And how stand you affected to his wish?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As one relying on your lordship's will

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And not depending on his friendly wish.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My will is something sorted with his wish.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Muse not that I thus suddenly proceed,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For what I will, I will, and there an end.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I am resolved that thou shalt spend some time

Author: Shakespeare
Text: With Valentinus in the emperor's court:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What maintenance he from his friends receives,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Like exhibition thou shalt have from me.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To-morrow be in readiness to go:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Excuse it not, for I am peremptory.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My lord, I cannot be so soon provided:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Please you, deliberate a day or two.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Look, what thou want'st shall be sent after thee:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: No more of stay! to-morrow thou must go.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Come on, Panthino: you shall be employ'd

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To hasten on his expedition.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Exeunt ANTONIO and PANTHINO

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thus have I shunn'd the fire for fear of burning,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And drench'd me in the sea, where I am drown'd.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I fear'd to show my father Julia's letter,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Lest he should take exceptions to my love,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And with the vantage of mine own excuse

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Hath he excepted most against my love.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O, how this spring of love resembleth

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The uncertain glory of an April day,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Which now shows all the beauty of the sun,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And by and by a cloud takes all away!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Re-enter PANTHINO

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sir Proteus, your father calls for you:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: He is in haste, therefore, I pray you to go.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, this it is: my heart accords thereto,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And yet a thousand times it answers 'no.'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter VALENTINE and SPEED

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter VALENTINE and SPEED

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sir, your glove.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Not mine, my gloves are on.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, then, this may be yours, for this is but one.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ha! let me see: ay, give it me, it's mine:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sweet ornament that decks a thing divine!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ah, Silvia, Silvia!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Madam Silvia! Madam Silvia!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How now, sirrah?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: She is not within hearing, sir.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, sir, who bade you call her?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Your worship, sir, or else I mistook.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Well, you'll still be too forward.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And yet I was last chidden for being too slow.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Go to, sir: tell me, do you know Madam Silvia?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: She that your worship loves?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, how know you that I am in love?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Marry, by these special marks: first, you have

Author: Shakespeare
Text: learned, like Sir Proteus, to wreathe your arms,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: like a malecontent, to relish a love-song, like a

Author: Shakespeare
Text: robin-redbreast, to walk alone, like one that had

Author: Shakespeare
Text: the pestilence, to sigh, like a school-boy that had

Author: Shakespeare
Text: lost his A B C, to weep, like a young wench that had

Author: Shakespeare
Text: buried her grandam, to fast, like one that takes

Author: Shakespeare
Text: diet, to watch like one that fears robbing, to

Author: Shakespeare
Text: speak puling, like a beggar at Hallowmas. You were

Author: Shakespeare
Text: wont, when you laughed, to crow like a cock, when you

Author: Shakespeare
Text: walked, to walk like one of the lions, when you

Author: Shakespeare
Text: fasted, it was presently after dinner, when you

Author: Shakespeare
Text: looked sadly, it was for want of money: and now you

Author: Shakespeare
Text: are metamorphosed with a mistress, that, when I look

Author: Shakespeare
Text: on you, I can hardly think you my master.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Are all these things perceived in me?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: They are all perceived without ye.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Without me? they cannot.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Without you? nay, that's certain, for, without you

Author: Shakespeare
Text: were so simple, none else would: but you are so

Author: Shakespeare
Text: without these follies, that these follies are within

Author: Shakespeare
Text: you and shine through you like the water in an

Author: Shakespeare
Text: urinal, that not an eye that sees you but is a

Author: Shakespeare
Text: physician to comment on your malady.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But tell me, dost thou know my lady Silvia?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: She that you gaze on so as she sits at supper?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Hast thou observed that? even she, I mean.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, sir, I know her not.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Dost thou know her by my gazing on her, and yet

Author: Shakespeare
Text: knowest her not?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Is she not hard-favoured, sir?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Not so fair, boy, as well-favoured.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sir, I know that well enough.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That she is not so fair as, of you, well-favoured.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I mean that her beauty is exquisite, but her favour infinite.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That's because the one is painted and the other out

Author: Shakespeare
Text: of all count.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How painted? and how out of count?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Marry, sir, so painted, to make her fair, that no

Author: Shakespeare
Text: man counts of her beauty.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How esteemest thou me? I account of her beauty.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You never saw her since she was deformed.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How long hath she been deformed?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ever since you loved her.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I have loved her ever since I saw her, and still I

Author: Shakespeare
Text: see her beautiful.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If you love her, you cannot see her.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Because Love is blind. O, that you had mine eyes,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: or your own eyes had the lights they were wont to

Author: Shakespeare
Text: have when you chid at Sir Proteus for going

Author: Shakespeare
Text: ungartered!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What should I see then?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Your own present folly and her passing deformity:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: for he, being in love, could not see to garter his

Author: Shakespeare
Text: hose, and you, being in love, cannot see to put on your hose.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Belike, boy, then, you are in love, for last

Author: Shakespeare
Text: morning you could not see to wipe my shoes.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: True, sir, I was in love with my bed: I thank you,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: you swinged me for my love, which makes me the

Author: Shakespeare
Text: bolder to chide you for yours.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: In conclusion, I stand affected to her.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I would you were set, so your affection would cease.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Last night she enjoined me to write some lines to

Author: Shakespeare
Text: one she loves.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And have you?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Are they not lamely writ?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: No, boy, but as well as I can do them. Peace!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: here she comes.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: [Aside]  O excellent motion! O exceeding puppet!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Now will he interpret to her.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter SILVIA

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter SILVIA

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Madam and mistress, a thousand good-morrows.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: [Aside]  O, give ye good even! here's a million of manners.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sir Valentine and servant, to you two thousand.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: [Aside]  He should give her interest and she gives it him.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As you enjoin'd me, I have writ your letter

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Unto the secret nameless friend of yours,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Which I was much unwilling to proceed in

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But for my duty to your ladyship.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I thank you gentle servant: 'tis very clerkly done.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Now trust me, madam, it came hardly off,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For being ignorant to whom it goes

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I writ at random, very doubtfully.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Perchance you think too much of so much pains?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: No, madam, so it stead you, I will write

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Please you command, a thousand times as much, And yet--

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A pretty period! Well, I guess the sequel,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And yet I will not name it, and yet I care not,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And yet take this again, and yet I thank you,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Meaning henceforth to trouble you no more.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: [Aside]  And yet you will, and yet another 'yet.'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What means your ladyship? do you not like it?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Yes, yes, the lines are very quaintly writ,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But since unwillingly, take them again.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Nay, take them.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Madam, they are for you.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, ay: you writ them, sir, at my request,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But I will none of them, they are for you,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I would have had them writ more movingly.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Please you, I'll write your ladyship another.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And when it's writ, for my sake read it over,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And if it please you, so, if not, why, so.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If it please me, madam, what then?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, if it please you, take it for your labour:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And so, good morrow, servant.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O jest unseen, inscrutable, invisible,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As a nose on a man's face, or a weathercock on a steeple!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My master sues to her, and she hath

Author: Shakespeare
Text: taught her suitor,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: He being her pupil, to become her tutor.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O excellent device! was there ever heard a better,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That my master, being scribe, to himself should write

Author: Shakespeare
Text: the letter?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How now, sir? what are you reasoning with yourself?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Nay, I was rhyming: 'tis you that have the reason.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To be a spokesman for Madam Silvia.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To yourself: why, she wooes you by a figure.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What figure?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: By a letter, I should say.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, she hath not writ to me?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What need she, when she hath made you write to

Author: Shakespeare
Text: yourself? Why, do you not perceive the jest?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: No believing you, indeed, sir. But did you perceive

Author: Shakespeare
Text: her earnest?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: She gave me none, except an angry word.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, she hath given you a letter.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That's the letter I writ to her friend.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And that letter hath she delivered, and there an end.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I would it were no worse.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I'll warrant you, 'tis as well:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For often have you writ to her, and she, in modesty,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Or else for want of idle time, could not again reply,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Or fearing else some messenger that might her mind discover,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Herself hath taught her love himself to write unto her lover.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: All this I speak in print, for in print I found it.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why muse you, sir? 'tis dinner-time.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I have dined.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, but hearken, sir, though the chameleon Love can

Author: Shakespeare
Text: feed on the air, I am one that am nourished by my

Author: Shakespeare
Text: victuals, and would fain have meat. O, be not like

Author: Shakespeare
Text: your mistress, be moved, be moved.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: SCENE II. Verona. JULIA'S house.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter PROTEUS and JULIA

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter PROTEUS and JULIA

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Have patience, gentle Julia.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I must, where is no remedy.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: When possibly I can, I will return.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If you turn not, you will return the sooner.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Keep this remembrance for thy Julia's sake.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Giving a ring

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why then, we'll make exchange, here, take you this.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And seal the bargain with a holy kiss.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Here is my hand for my true constancy,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And when that hour o'erslips me in the day

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Wherein I sigh not, Julia, for thy sake,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The next ensuing hour some foul mischance

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Torment me for my love's forgetfulness!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My father stays my coming, answer not,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The tide is now: nay, not thy tide of tears,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That tide will stay me longer than I should.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Julia, farewell!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Exit JULIA

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What, gone without a word?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, so true love should do: it cannot speak,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For truth hath better deeds than words to grace it.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter PANTHINO

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter PANTHINO

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sir Proteus, you are stay'd for.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Go, I come, I come.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Alas! this parting strikes poor lovers dumb.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter LAUNCE, leading a dog

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Nay, 'twill be this hour ere I have done weeping,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: all the kind of the Launces have this very fault. I

Author: Shakespeare
Text: have received my proportion, like the prodigious

Author: Shakespeare
Text: son, and am going with Sir Proteus to the Imperial's

Author: Shakespeare
Text: court. I think Crab, my dog, be the sourest-natured

Author: Shakespeare
Text: dog that lives: my mother weeping, my father

Author: Shakespeare
Text: wailing, my sister crying, our maid howling, our cat

Author: Shakespeare
Text: wringing her hands, and all our house in a great

Author: Shakespeare
Text: perplexity, yet did not this cruel-hearted cur shed

Author: Shakespeare
Text: one tear: he is a stone, a very pebble stone, and

Author: Shakespeare
Text: has no more pity in him than a dog: a Jew would have

Author: Shakespeare
Text: wept to have seen our parting, why, my grandam,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: having no eyes, look you, wept herself blind at my

Author: Shakespeare
Text: parting. Nay, I'll show you the manner of it. This

Author: Shakespeare
Text: shoe is my father: no, this left shoe is my father:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: no, no, this left shoe is my mother: nay, that

Author: Shakespeare
Text: cannot be so neither: yes, it is so, it is so, it

Author: Shakespeare
Text: hath the worser sole. This shoe, with the hole in

Author: Shakespeare
Text: it, is my mother, and this my father, a vengeance

Author: Shakespeare
Text: on't! there 'tis: now, sit, this staff is my

Author: Shakespeare
Text: sister, for, look you, she is as white as a lily and

Author: Shakespeare
Text: as small as a wand: this hat is Nan, our maid: I

Author: Shakespeare
Text: am the dog: no, the dog is himself, and I am the

Author: Shakespeare
Text: dog--Oh! the dog is me, and I am myself, ay, so,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: so. Now come I to my father, Father, your blessing:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: now should not the shoe speak a word for weeping:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: now should I kiss my father, well, he weeps on. Now

Author: Shakespeare
Text: come I to my mother: O, that she could speak now

Author: Shakespeare
Text: like a wood woman! Well, I kiss her, why, there

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'tis, here's my mother's breath up and down. Now

Author: Shakespeare
Text: come I to my sister, mark the moan she makes. Now

Author: Shakespeare
Text: the dog all this while sheds not a tear nor speaks a

Author: Shakespeare
Text: word, but see how I lay the dust with my tears.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Launce, away, away, aboard! thy master is shipped

Author: Shakespeare
Text: and thou art to post after with oars. What's the

Author: Shakespeare
Text: matter? why weepest thou, man? Away, ass! You'll

Author: Shakespeare
Text: lose the tide, if you tarry any longer.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: It is no matter if the tied were lost, for it is the

Author: Shakespeare
Text: unkindest tied that ever any man tied.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What's the unkindest tide?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, he that's tied here, Crab, my dog.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Tut, man, I mean thou'lt lose the flood, and, in

Author: Shakespeare
Text: losing the flood, lose thy voyage, and, in losing

Author: Shakespeare
Text: thy voyage, lose thy master, and, in losing thy

Author: Shakespeare
Text: master, lose thy service, and, in losing thy

Author: Shakespeare
Text: service,--Why dost thou stop my mouth?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For fear thou shouldst lose thy tongue.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Where should I lose my tongue?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: In thy tale.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: In thy tail!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Lose the tide, and the voyage, and the master, and

Author: Shakespeare
Text: the service, and the tied! Why, man, if the river

Author: Shakespeare
Text: were dry, I am able to fill it with my tears, if the

Author: Shakespeare
Text: wind were down, I could drive the boat with my sighs.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Come, come away, man, I was sent to call thee.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sir, call me what thou darest.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Wilt thou go?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Well, I will go.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter SILVIA, VALENTINE, THURIO, and SPEED

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Servant!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Mistress?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Master, Sir Thurio frowns on you.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, boy, it's for love.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Not of you.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Of my mistress, then.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Twere good you knocked him.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Servant, you are sad.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Indeed, madam, I seem so.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Seem you that you are not?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Haply I do.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: So do counterfeits.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: So do you.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What seem I that I am not?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Wise.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What instance of the contrary?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Your folly.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And how quote you my folly?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I quote it in your jerkin.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My jerkin is a doublet.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Well, then, I'll double your folly.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What, angry, Sir Thurio! do you change colour?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Give him leave, madam, he is a kind of chameleon.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That hath more mind to feed on your blood than live

Author: Shakespeare
Text: in your air.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You have said, sir.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, sir, and done too, for this time.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I know it well, sir, you always end ere you begin.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A fine volley of words, gentlemen, and quickly shot off.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Tis indeed, madam, we thank the giver.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Who is that, servant?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Yourself, sweet lady, for you gave the fire. Sir

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thurio borrows his wit from your ladyship's looks,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: and spends what he borrows kindly in your company.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sir, if you spend word for word with me, I shall

Author: Shakespeare
Text: make your wit bankrupt.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I know it well, sir, you have an exchequer of words,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: and, I think, no other treasure to give your

Author: Shakespeare
Text: followers, for it appears by their bare liveries,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: that they live by your bare words.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: No more, gentlemen, no more:--here comes my father.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter DUKE

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter DUKE

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Now, daughter Silvia, you are hard beset.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sir Valentine, your father's in good health:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What say you to a letter from your friends

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Of much good news?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My lord, I will be thankful.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To any happy messenger from thence.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Know ye Don Antonio, your countryman?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, my good lord, I know the gentleman

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To be of worth and worthy estimation

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And not without desert so well reputed.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Hath he not a son?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, my good lord, a son that well deserves

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The honour and regard of such a father.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You know him well?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I know him as myself, for from our infancy

Author: Shakespeare
Text: We have conversed and spent our hours together:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And though myself have been an idle truant,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Omitting the sweet benefit of time

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To clothe mine age with angel-like perfection,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Yet hath Sir Proteus, for that's his name,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Made use and fair advantage of his days,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: His years but young, but his experience old,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: His head unmellow'd, but his judgment ripe,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And, in a word, for far behind his worth

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Comes all the praises that I now bestow,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: He is complete in feature and in mind

Author: Shakespeare
Text: With all good grace to grace a gentleman.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Beshrew me, sir, but if he make this good,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: He is as worthy for an empress' love

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As meet to be an emperor's counsellor.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Well, sir, this gentleman is come to me,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: With commendation from great potentates,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And here he means to spend his time awhile:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I think 'tis no unwelcome news to you.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Should I have wish'd a thing, it had been he.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Welcome him then according to his worth.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Silvia, I speak to you, and you, Sir Thurio,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For Valentine, I need not cite him to it:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I will send him hither to you presently.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: This is the gentleman I told your ladyship

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Had come along with me, but that his mistress

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Did hold his eyes lock'd in her crystal looks.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Belike that now she hath enfranchised them

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Upon some other pawn for fealty.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Nay, sure, I think she holds them prisoners still.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Nay, then he should be blind, and, being blind

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How could he see his way to seek out you?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, lady, Love hath twenty pair of eyes.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: They say that Love hath not an eye at all.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To see such lovers, Thurio, as yourself:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Upon a homely object Love can wink.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Have done, have done, here comes the gentleman.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Exit THURIO

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Exit THURIO

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Welcome, dear Proteus! Mistress, I beseech you,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Confirm his welcome with some special favour.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: His worth is warrant for his welcome hither,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If this be he you oft have wish'd to hear from.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Mistress, it is: sweet lady, entertain him

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To be my fellow-servant to your ladyship.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Too low a mistress for so high a servant.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Not so, sweet  lady: but too mean a servant

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To have a look of such a worthy mistress.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Leave off discourse of disability:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sweet lady, entertain him for your servant.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My duty will I boast of, nothing else.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And duty never yet did want his meed:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Servant, you are welcome to a worthless mistress.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I'll die on him that says so but yourself.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That you are welcome?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That you are worthless.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Re-enter THURIO

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Madam, my lord your father would speak with you.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I wait upon his pleasure. Come, Sir Thurio,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Go with me. Once more, new servant, welcome:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I'll leave you to confer of home affairs,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: When you have done, we look to hear from you.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: We'll both attend upon your ladyship.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Exeunt SILVIA and THURIO

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Now, tell me, how do all from whence you came?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Your friends are well and have them much commended.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And how do yours?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I left them all in health.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How does your lady? and how thrives your love?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My tales of love were wont to weary you,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I know you joy not in a love discourse.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, Proteus, but that life is alter'd now:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I have done penance for contemning Love,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Whose high imperious thoughts have punish'd me

Author: Shakespeare
Text: With bitter fasts, with penitential groans,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: With nightly tears and daily heart-sore sighs,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For in revenge of my contempt of love,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Love hath chased sleep from my enthralled eyes

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And made them watchers of mine own heart's sorrow.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O gentle Proteus, Love's a mighty lord,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And hath so humbled me, as, I confess,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: There is no woe to his correction,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Nor to his service no such joy on earth.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Now no discourse, except it be of love,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Now can I break my fast, dine, sup and sleep,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Upon the very naked name of love.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enough, I read your fortune in your eye.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Was this the idol that you worship so?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Even she, and is she not a heavenly saint?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: No, but she is an earthly paragon.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Call her divine.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I will not flatter her.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O, flatter me, for love delights in praises.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: When I was sick, you gave me bitter pills,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And I must minister the like to you.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Then speak the truth by her, if not divine,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Yet let her be a principality,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sovereign to all the creatures on the earth.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Except my mistress.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sweet, except not any,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Except thou wilt except against my love.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Have I not reason to prefer mine own?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And I will help thee to prefer her too:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: She shall be dignified with this high honour--

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To bear my lady's train, lest the base earth

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Should from her vesture chance to steal a kiss

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And, of so great a favour growing proud,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Disdain to root the summer-swelling flower

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And make rough winter everlastingly.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, Valentine, what braggardism is this?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Pardon me, Proteus: all I can is nothing

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To her whose worth makes other worthies nothing,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: She is alone.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Then let her alone.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Not for the world: why, man, she is mine own,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And I as rich in having such a jewel

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As twenty seas, if all their sand were pearl,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The water nectar and the rocks pure gold.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Forgive me that I do not dream on thee,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Because thou see'st me dote upon my love.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My foolish rival, that her father likes

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Only for his possessions are so huge,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Is gone with her along, and I must after,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For love, thou know'st, is full of jealousy.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But she loves you?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, and we are betroth'd: nay, more, our,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: marriage-hour,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: With all the cunning manner of our flight,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Determined of, how I must climb her window,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The ladder made of cords, and all the means

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Plotted and 'greed on for my happiness.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Good Proteus, go with me to my chamber,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: In these affairs to aid me with thy counsel.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Go on before, I shall inquire you forth:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I must unto the road, to disembark

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Some necessaries that I needs must use,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And then I'll presently attend you.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Will you make haste?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Exit VALENTINE

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Even as one heat another heat expels,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Or as one nail by strength drives out another,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: So the remembrance of my former love

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Is by a newer object quite forgotten.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Is it mine, or Valentine's praise,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Her true perfection, or my false transgression,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That makes me reasonless to reason thus?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: She is fair, and so is Julia that I love--

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That I did love, for now my love is thaw'd,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Which, like a waxen image, 'gainst a fire,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Bears no impression of the thing it was.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Methinks my zeal to Valentine is cold,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And that I love him not as I was wont.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O, but I love his lady too too much,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And that's the reason I love him so little.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How shall I dote on her with more advice,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That thus without advice begin to love her!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Tis but her picture I have yet beheld,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And that hath dazzled my reason's light,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But when I look on her perfections,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: There is no reason but I shall be blind.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If I can cheque my erring love, I will,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If not, to compass her I'll use my skill.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: SCENE V. The same. A street.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter SPEED and LAUNCE severally

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Launce! by mine honesty, welcome to Milan!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Forswear not thyself, sweet youth, for I am not

Author: Shakespeare
Text: welcome. I reckon this always, that a man is never

Author: Shakespeare
Text: undone till he be hanged, nor never welcome to a

Author: Shakespeare
Text: place till some certain shot be paid and the hostess

Author: Shakespeare
Text: say 'Welcome!'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Come on, you madcap, I'll to the alehouse with you

Author: Shakespeare
Text: presently, where, for one shot of five pence, thou

Author: Shakespeare
Text: shalt have five thousand welcomes. But, sirrah, how

Author: Shakespeare
Text: did thy master part with Madam Julia?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Marry, after they closed in earnest, they parted very

Author: Shakespeare
Text: fairly in jest.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But shall she marry him?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How then? shall he marry her?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: No, neither.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What, are they broken?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: No, they are both as whole as a fish.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, then, how stands the matter with them?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Marry, thus: when it stands well with him, it

Author: Shakespeare
Text: stands well with her.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What an ass art thou! I understand thee not.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What a block art thou, that thou canst not! My

Author: Shakespeare
Text: staff understands me.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What thou sayest?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, and what I do too: look thee, I'll but lean,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: and my staff understands me.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: It stands under thee, indeed.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, stand-under and under-stand is all one.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But tell me true, will't be a match?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ask my dog: if he say ay, it will! if he say no,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: it will, if he shake his tail and say nothing, it will.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The conclusion is then that it will.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thou shalt never get such a secret from me but by a parable.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Tis well that I get it so. But, Launce, how sayest

Author: Shakespeare
Text: thou, that my master is become a notable lover?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I never knew him otherwise.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Than how?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A notable lubber, as thou reportest him to be.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, thou whoreson ass, thou mistakest me.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, fool, I meant not thee, I meant thy master.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I tell thee, my master is become a hot lover.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, I tell thee, I care not though he burn himself

Author: Shakespeare
Text: in love. If thou wilt, go with me to the alehouse,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: if not, thou art an Hebrew, a Jew, and not worth the

Author: Shakespeare
Text: name of a Christian.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Because thou hast not so much charity in thee as to

Author: Shakespeare
Text: go to the ale with a Christian. Wilt thou go?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: At thy service.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: SCENE VI. The same. The DUKE'S palace.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To leave my Julia, shall I be forsworn,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To love fair Silvia, shall I be forsworn,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To wrong my friend, I shall be much forsworn,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And even that power which gave me first my oath

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Provokes me to this threefold perjury,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Love bade me swear and Love bids me forswear.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O sweet-suggesting Love, if thou hast sinned,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Teach me, thy tempted subject, to excuse it!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: At first I did adore a twinkling star,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But now I worship a celestial sun.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Unheedful vows may heedfully be broken,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And he wants wit that wants resolved will

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To learn his wit to exchange the bad for better.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Fie, fie, unreverend tongue! to call her bad,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Whose sovereignty so oft thou hast preferr'd

Author: Shakespeare
Text: With twenty thousand soul-confirming oaths.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I cannot leave to love, and yet I do,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But there I leave to love where I should love.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Julia I lose and Valentine I lose:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If I keep them, I needs must lose myself,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If I lose them, thus find I by their loss

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For Valentine myself, for Julia Silvia.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I to myself am dearer than a friend,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For love is still most precious in itself,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And Silvia--witness Heaven, that made her fair!--

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Shows Julia but a swarthy Ethiope.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I will forget that Julia is alive,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Remembering that my love to her is dead,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And Valentine I'll hold an enemy,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Aiming at Silvia as a sweeter friend.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I cannot now prove constant to myself,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Without some treachery used to Valentine.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: This night he meaneth with a corded ladder

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To climb celestial Silvia's chamber-window,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Myself in counsel, his competitor.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Now presently I'll give her father notice

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Of their disguising and pretended flight,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Who, all enraged, will banish Valentine,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For Thurio, he intends, shall wed his daughter,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But, Valentine being gone, I'll quickly cross

Author: Shakespeare
Text: By some sly trick blunt Thurio's dull proceeding.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Love, lend me wings to make my purpose swift,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As thou hast lent me wit to plot this drift!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: SCENE VII. Verona. JULIA'S house.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter JULIA and LUCETTA

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Counsel, Lucetta, gentle girl, assist me,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And even in kind love I do conjure thee,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Who art the table wherein all my thoughts

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Are visibly character'd and engraved,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To lesson me and tell me some good mean

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How, with my honour, I may undertake

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A journey to my loving Proteus.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Alas, the way is wearisome and long!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A true-devoted pilgrim is not weary

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To measure kingdoms with his feeble steps,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Much less shall she that hath Love's wings to fly,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And when the flight is made to one so dear,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Of such divine perfection, as Sir Proteus.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Better forbear till Proteus make return.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O, know'st thou not his looks are my soul's food?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Pity the dearth that I have pined in,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: By longing for that food so long a time.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Didst thou but know the inly touch of love,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thou wouldst as soon go kindle fire with snow

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As seek to quench the fire of love with words.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I do not seek to quench your love's hot fire,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But qualify the fire's extreme rage,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Lest it should burn above the bounds of reason.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The more thou damm'st it up, the more it burns.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The current that with gentle murmur glides,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thou know'st, being stopp'd, impatiently doth rage,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But when his fair course is not hindered,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: He makes sweet music with the enamell'ed stones,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Giving a gentle kiss to every sedge

Author: Shakespeare
Text: He overtaketh in his pilgrimage,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And so by many winding nooks he strays

Author: Shakespeare
Text: With willing sport to the wild ocean.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Then let me go and hinder not my course

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I'll be as patient as a gentle stream

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And make a pastime of each weary step,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Till the last step have brought me to my love,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And there I'll rest, as after much turmoil

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A blessed soul doth in Elysium.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But in what habit will you go along?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Not like a woman, for I would prevent

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The loose encounters of lascivious men:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Gentle Lucetta, fit me with such weeds

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As may beseem some well-reputed page.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, then, your ladyship must cut your hair.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: No, girl, I'll knit it up in silken strings

Author: Shakespeare
Text: With twenty odd-conceited true-love knots.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To be fantastic may become a youth

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Of greater time than I shall show to be.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What fashion, madam shall I make your breeches?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That fits as well as 'Tell me, good my lord,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What compass will you wear your farthingale?'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why even what fashion thou best likest, Lucetta.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You must needs have them with a codpiece, madam.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Out, out, Lucetta! that would be ill-favour'd.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A round hose, madam, now's not worth a pin,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Unless you have a codpiece to stick pins on.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Lucetta, as thou lovest me, let me have

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What thou thinkest meet and is most mannerly.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But tell me, wench, how will the world repute me

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For undertaking so unstaid a journey?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I fear me, it will make me scandalized.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If you think so, then stay at home and go not.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Nay, that I will not.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Then never dream on infamy, but go.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If Proteus like your journey when you come,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: No matter who's displeased when you are gone:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I fear me, he will scarce be pleased withal.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That is the least, Lucetta, of my fear:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A thousand oaths, an ocean of his tears

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And instances of infinite of love

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Warrant me welcome to my Proteus.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: All these are servants to deceitful men.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Base men, that use them to so base effect!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But truer stars did govern Proteus' birth

Author: Shakespeare
Text: His words are bonds, his oaths are oracles,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: His love sincere, his thoughts immaculate,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: His tears pure messengers sent from his heart,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: His heart as far from fraud as heaven from earth.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Pray heaven he prove so, when you come to him!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Now, as thou lovest me, do him not that wrong

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To bear a hard opinion of his truth:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Only deserve my love by loving him,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And presently go with me to my chamber,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To take a note of what I stand in need of,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To furnish me upon my longing journey.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: All that is mine I leave at thy dispose,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My goods, my lands, my reputation,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Only, in lieu thereof, dispatch me hence.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Come, answer not, but to it presently!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I am impatient of my tarriance.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter DUKE, THURIO, and PROTEUS

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sir Thurio, give us leave, I pray, awhile,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: We have some secrets to confer about.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Now, tell me, Proteus, what's your will with me?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My gracious lord, that which I would discover

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The law of friendship bids me to conceal,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But when I call to mind your gracious favours

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Done to me, undeserving as I am,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My duty pricks me on to utter that

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Which else no worldly good should draw from me.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Know, worthy prince, Sir Valentine, my friend,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: This night intends to steal away your daughter:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Myself am one made privy to the plot.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I know you have determined to bestow her

Author: Shakespeare
Text: On Thurio, whom your gentle daughter hates,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And should she thus be stol'n away from you,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: It would be much vexation to your age.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thus, for my duty's sake, I rather chose

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To cross my friend in his intended drift

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Than, by concealing it, heap on your head

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A pack of sorrows which would press you down,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Being unprevented, to your timeless grave.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Proteus, I thank thee for thine honest care,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Which to requite, command me while I live.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: This love of theirs myself have often seen,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Haply when they have judged me fast asleep,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And oftentimes have purposed to forbid

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sir Valentine her company and my court:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But fearing lest my jealous aim might err

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And so unworthily disgrace the man,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A rashness that I ever yet have shunn'd,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I gave him gentle looks, thereby to find

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That which thyself hast now disclosed to me.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And, that thou mayst perceive my fear of this,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Knowing that tender youth is soon suggested,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I nightly lodge her in an upper tower,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The key whereof myself have ever kept,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And thence she cannot be convey'd away.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Know, noble lord, they have devised a mean

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How he her chamber-window will ascend

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And with a corded ladder fetch her down,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For which the youthful lover now is gone

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And this way comes he with it presently,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Where, if it please you, you may intercept him.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But, good my Lord, do it so cunningly

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That my discovery be not aimed at,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For love of you, not hate unto my friend,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Hath made me publisher of this pretence.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Upon mine honour, he shall never know

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That I had any light from thee of this.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Adieu, my Lord, Sir Valentine is coming.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sir Valentine, whither away so fast?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Please it your grace, there is a messenger

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That stays to bear my letters to my friends,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And I am going to deliver them.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Be they of much import?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The tenor of them doth but signify

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My health and happy being at your court.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Nay then, no matter, stay with me awhile,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I am to break with thee of some affairs

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That touch me near, wherein thou must be secret.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Tis not unknown to thee that I have sought

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To match my friend Sir Thurio to my daughter.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I know it well, my Lord, and, sure, the match

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Were rich and honourable, besides, the gentleman

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Is full of virtue, bounty, worth and qualities

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Beseeming such a wife as your fair daughter:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Cannot your Grace win her to fancy him?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: No, trust me, she is peevish, sullen, froward,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Proud, disobedient, stubborn, lacking duty,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Neither regarding that she is my child

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Nor fearing me as if I were her father,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And, may I say to thee, this pride of hers,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Upon advice, hath drawn my love from her,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And, where I thought the remnant of mine age

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Should have been cherish'd by her child-like duty,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I now am full resolved to take a wife

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And turn her out to who will take her in:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Then let her beauty be her wedding-dower,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For me and my possessions she esteems not.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What would your Grace have me to do in this?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: There is a lady in Verona here

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Whom I affect, but she is nice and coy

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And nought esteems my aged eloquence:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Now therefore would I have thee to my tutor--

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For long agone I have forgot to court,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Besides, the fashion of the time is changed--

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How and which way I may bestow myself

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To be regarded in her sun-bright eye.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Win her with gifts, if she respect not words:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Dumb jewels often in their silent kind

Author: Shakespeare
Text: More than quick words do move a woman's mind.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But she did scorn a present that I sent her.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A woman sometimes scorns what best contents her.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Send her another, never give her o'er,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For scorn at first makes after-love the more.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If she do frown, 'tis not in hate of you,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But rather to beget more love in you:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If she do chide, 'tis not to have you gone,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For why, the fools are mad, if left alone.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Take no repulse, whatever she doth say,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For 'get you gone,' she doth not mean 'away!'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Flatter and praise, commend, extol their graces,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Though ne'er so black, say they have angels' faces.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That man that hath a tongue, I say, is no man,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If with his tongue he cannot win a woman.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But she I mean is promised by her friends

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Unto a youthful gentleman of worth,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And kept severely from resort of men,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That no man hath access by day to her.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, then, I would resort to her by night.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, but the doors be lock'd and keys kept safe,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That no man hath recourse to her by night.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What lets but one may enter at her window?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Her chamber is aloft, far from the ground,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And built so shelving that one cannot climb it

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Without apparent hazard of his life.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why then, a ladder quaintly made of cords,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To cast up, with a pair of anchoring hooks,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Would serve to scale another Hero's tower,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: So bold Leander would adventure it.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Now, as thou art a gentleman of blood,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Advise me where I may have such a ladder.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: When would you use it? pray, sir, tell me that.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: This very night, for Love is like a child,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That longs for every thing that he can come by.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: By seven o'clock I'll get you such a ladder.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But, hark thee, I will go to her alone:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How shall I best convey the ladder thither?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: It will be light, my lord, that you may bear it

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Under a cloak that is of any length.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A cloak as long as thine will serve the turn?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Then let me see thy cloak:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I'll get me one of such another length.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, any cloak will serve the turn, my lord.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How shall I fashion me to wear a cloak?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I pray thee, let me feel thy cloak upon me.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What letter is this same? What's here? 'To Silvia'!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And here an engine fit for my proceeding.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I'll be so bold to break the seal for once.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'My thoughts do harbour with my Silvia nightly,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And slaves they are to me that send them flying:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O, could their master come and go as lightly,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Himself would lodge where senseless they are lying!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My herald thoughts in thy pure bosom rest them:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: While I, their king, that hither them importune,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Do curse the grace that with such grace hath bless'd them,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Because myself do want my servants' fortune:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I curse myself, for they are sent by me,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That they should harbour where their lord would be.'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Silvia, this night I will enfranchise thee.'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Tis so, and here's the ladder for the purpose.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, Phaeton,--for thou art Merops' son,--

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Wilt thou aspire to guide the heavenly car

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And with thy daring folly burn the world?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Wilt thou reach stars, because they shine on thee?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Go, base intruder! overweening slave!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Bestow thy fawning smiles on equal mates,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And think my patience, more than thy desert,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Is privilege for thy departure hence:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thank me for this more than for all the favours

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Which all too much I have bestow'd on thee.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But if thou linger in my territories

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Longer than swiftest expedition

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Will give thee time to leave our royal court,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: By heaven! my wrath shall far exceed the love

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I ever bore my daughter or thyself.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Be gone! I will not hear thy vain excuse,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But, as thou lovest thy life, make speed from hence.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And why not death rather than living torment?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To die is to be banish'd from myself,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And Silvia is myself: banish'd from her

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Is self from self: a deadly banishment!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What light is light, if Silvia be not seen?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What joy is joy, if Silvia be not by?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Unless it be to think that she is by

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And feed upon the shadow of perfection

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Except I be by Silvia in the night,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: There is no music in the nightingale,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Unless I look on Silvia in the day,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: There is no day for me to look upon,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: She is my essence, and I leave to be,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If I be not by her fair influence

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Foster'd, illumined, cherish'd, kept alive.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I fly not death, to fly his deadly doom:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Tarry I here, I but attend on death:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But, fly I hence, I fly away from life.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter PROTEUS and LAUNCE

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Run, boy, run, run, and seek him out.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Soho, soho!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What seest thou?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Him we go to find: there's not a hair on's head

Author: Shakespeare
Text: but 'tis a Valentine.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Valentine?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Who then? his spirit?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Can nothing speak? Master, shall I strike?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Who wouldst thou strike?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Villain, forbear.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, sir, I'll strike nothing: I pray you,--

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sirrah, I say, forbear. Friend Valentine, a word.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My ears are stopt and cannot hear good news,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: So much of bad already hath possess'd them.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Then in dumb silence will I bury mine,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For they are harsh, untuneable and bad.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Is Silvia dead?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: No, Valentine.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: No, Valentine.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: No Valentine, indeed, for sacred Silvia.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Hath she forsworn me?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: No Valentine, if Silvia have forsworn me.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What is your news?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sir, there is a proclamation that you are vanished.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That thou art banished--O, that's the news!--

Author: Shakespeare
Text: From hence, from Silvia and from me thy friend.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O, I have fed upon this woe already,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And now excess of it will make me surfeit.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Doth Silvia know that I am banished?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, ay, and she hath offer'd to the doom--

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Which, unreversed, stands in effectual force--

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A sea of melting pearl, which some call tears:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Those at her father's churlish feet she tender'd,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: With them, upon her knees, her humble self,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Wringing her hands, whose whiteness so became them

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As if but now they waxed pale for woe:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But neither bended knees, pure hands held up,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sad sighs, deep groans, nor silver-shedding tears,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Could penetrate her uncompassionate sire,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But Valentine, if he be ta'en, must die.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Besides, her intercession chafed him so,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: When she for thy repeal was suppliant,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That to close prison he commanded her,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: With many bitter threats of biding there.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: No more, unless the next word that thou speak'st

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Have some malignant power upon my life:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If so, I pray thee, breathe it in mine ear,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As ending anthem of my endless dolour.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Cease to lament for that thou canst not help,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And study help for that which thou lament'st.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Time is the nurse and breeder of all good.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Here if thou stay, thou canst not see thy love,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Besides, thy staying will abridge thy life.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Hope is a lover's staff, walk hence with that

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And manage it against despairing thoughts.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thy letters may be here, though thou art hence,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Which, being writ to me, shall be deliver'd

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Even in the milk-white bosom of thy love.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The time now serves not to expostulate:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Come, I'll convey thee through the city-gate,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And, ere I part with thee, confer at large

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Of all that may concern thy love-affairs.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As thou lovest Silvia, though not for thyself,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Regard thy danger, and along with me!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I pray thee, Launce, an if thou seest my boy,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Bid him make haste and meet me at the North-gate.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Go, sirrah, find him out. Come, Valentine.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O my dear Silvia! Hapless Valentine!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Exeunt VALENTINE and PROTEUS

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I am but a fool, look you, and yet I have the wit to

Author: Shakespeare
Text: think my master is a kind of a knave: but that's

Author: Shakespeare
Text: all one, if he be but one knave. He lives not now

Author: Shakespeare
Text: that knows me to be in love, yet I am in love, but a

Author: Shakespeare
Text: team of horse shall not pluck that from me, nor who

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'tis I love, and yet 'tis a woman, but what woman, I

Author: Shakespeare
Text: will not tell myself, and yet 'tis a milkmaid, yet

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'tis not a maid, for she hath had gossips, yet 'tis

Author: Shakespeare
Text: a maid, for she is her master's maid, and serves for

Author: Shakespeare
Text: wages. She hath more qualities than a water-spaniel,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: which is much in a bare Christian.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Pulling out a paper

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Here is the cate-log of her condition.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Imprimis: She can fetch and carry.' Why, a horse

Author: Shakespeare
Text: can do no more: nay, a horse cannot fetch, but only

Author: Shakespeare
Text: carry, therefore is she better than a jade. 'Item:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: She can milk,' look you, a sweet virtue in a maid

Author: Shakespeare
Text: with clean hands.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How now, Signior Launce! what news with your

Author: Shakespeare
Text: mastership?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: With my master's ship? why, it is at sea.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Well, your old vice still, mistake the word. What

Author: Shakespeare
Text: news, then, in your paper?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The blackest news that ever thou heardest.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, man, how black?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, as black as ink.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Let me read them.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Fie on thee, jolt-head! thou canst not read.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thou liest, I can.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I will try thee. Tell me this: who begot thee?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Marry, the son of my grandfather.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O illiterate loiterer! it was the son of thy

Author: Shakespeare
Text: grandmother: this proves that thou canst not read.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Come, fool, come, try me in thy paper.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: There, and St. Nicholas be thy speed!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: [Reads]  'Imprimis: She can milk.'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, that she can.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Item: She brews good ale.'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And thereof comes the proverb: 'Blessing of your

Author: Shakespeare
Text: heart, you brew good ale.'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Item: She can sew.'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That's as much as to say, Can she so?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Item: She can knit.'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What need a man care for a stock with a wench, when

Author: Shakespeare
Text: she can knit him a stock?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Item: She can wash and scour.'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A special virtue: for then she need not be washed

Author: Shakespeare
Text: and scoured.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Item: She can spin.'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Then may I set the world on wheels, when she can

Author: Shakespeare
Text: spin for her living.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Item: She hath many nameless virtues.'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That's as much as to say, bastard virtues, that,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: indeed, know not their fathers and therefore have no names.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Here follow her vices.'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Close at the heels of her virtues.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Item: She is not to be kissed fasting in respect

Author: Shakespeare
Text: of her breath.'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Well, that fault may be mended with a breakfast. Read on.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Item: She hath a sweet mouth.'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That makes amends for her sour breath.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Item: She doth talk in her sleep.'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: It's no matter for that, so she sleep not in her talk.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Item: She is slow in words.'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O villain, that set this down among her vices! To

Author: Shakespeare
Text: be slow in words is a woman's only virtue: I pray

Author: Shakespeare
