Text: thee, out with't, and place it for her chief virtue.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Item: She is proud.'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Out with that too, it was Eve's legacy, and cannot

Author: Shakespeare
Text: be ta'en from her.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Item: She hath no teeth.'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I care not for that neither, because I love crusts.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Item: She is curst.'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Well, the best is, she hath no teeth to bite.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Item: She will often praise her liquor.'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If her liquor be good, she shall: if she will not, I

Author: Shakespeare
Text: will, for good things should be praised.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Item: She is too liberal.'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Of her tongue she cannot, for that's writ down she

Author: Shakespeare
Text: is slow of, of her purse she shall not, for that

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I'll keep shut: now, of another thing she may, and

Author: Shakespeare
Text: that cannot I help. Well, proceed.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Item: She hath more hair than wit, and more faults

Author: Shakespeare
Text: than hairs, and more wealth than faults.'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Stop there, I'll have her: she was mine, and not

Author: Shakespeare
Text: mine, twice or thrice in that last article.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Rehearse that once more.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Item: She hath more hair than wit,'--

Author: Shakespeare
Text: More hair than wit? It may be, I'll prove it. The

Author: Shakespeare
Text: cover of the salt hides the salt, and therefore it

Author: Shakespeare
Text: is more than the salt, the hair that covers the wit

Author: Shakespeare
Text: is more than the wit, for the greater hides the

Author: Shakespeare
Text: less. What's next?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'And more faults than hairs,'--

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That's monstrous: O, that that were out!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'And more wealth than faults.'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, that word makes the faults gracious. Well,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I'll have her, and if it be a match, as nothing is

Author: Shakespeare
Text: impossible,--

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, then will I tell thee--that thy master stays

Author: Shakespeare
Text: for thee at the North-gate.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For thee! ay, who art thou? he hath stayed for a

Author: Shakespeare
Text: better man than thee.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And must I go to him?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thou must run to him, for thou hast stayed so long

Author: Shakespeare
Text: that going will scarce serve the turn.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why didst not tell me sooner? pox of your love letters!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Now will he be swinged for reading my letter, an

Author: Shakespeare
Text: unmannerly slave, that will thrust himself into

Author: Shakespeare
Text: secrets! I'll after, to rejoice in the boy's correction.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter DUKE and THURIO

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sir Thurio, fear not but that she will love you,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Now Valentine is banish'd from her sight.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Since his exile she hath despised me most,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Forsworn my company and rail'd at me,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That I am desperate of obtaining her.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: This weak impress of love is as a figure

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Trenched in ice, which with an hour's heat

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Dissolves to water and doth lose his form.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A little time will melt her frozen thoughts

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And worthless Valentine shall be forgot.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How now, Sir Proteus! Is your countryman

Author: Shakespeare
Text: According to our proclamation gone?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Gone, my good lord.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My daughter takes his going grievously.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A little time, my lord, will kill that grief.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: So I believe, but Thurio thinks not so.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Proteus, the good conceit I hold of thee--

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For thou hast shown some sign of good desert--

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Makes me the better to confer with thee.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Longer than I prove loyal to your grace

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Let me not live to look upon your grace.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thou know'st how willingly I would effect

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The match between Sir Thurio and my daughter.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And also, I think, thou art not ignorant

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How she opposes her against my will

Author: Shakespeare
Text: She did, my lord, when Valentine was here.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, and perversely she persevers so.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What might we do to make the girl forget

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The love of Valentine and love Sir Thurio?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The best way is to slander Valentine

Author: Shakespeare
Text: With falsehood, cowardice and poor descent,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Three things that women highly hold in hate.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, but she'll think that it is spoke in hate.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, if his enemy deliver it:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Therefore it must with circumstance be spoken

Author: Shakespeare
Text: By one whom she esteemeth as his friend.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Then you must undertake to slander him.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And that, my lord, I shall be loath to do:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Tis an ill office for a gentleman,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Especially against his very friend.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Where your good word cannot advantage him,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Your slander never can endamage him,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Therefore the office is indifferent,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Being entreated to it by your friend.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You have prevail'd, my lord, if I can do it

Author: Shakespeare
Text: By ought that I can speak in his dispraise,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: She shall not long continue love to him.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But say this weed her love from Valentine,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: It follows not that she will love Sir Thurio.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Therefore, as you unwind her love from him,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Lest it should ravel and be good to none,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You must provide to bottom it on me,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Which must be done by praising me as much

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As you in worth dispraise Sir Valentine.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And, Proteus, we dare trust you in this kind,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Because we know, on Valentine's report,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You are already Love's firm votary

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And cannot soon revolt and change your mind.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Upon this warrant shall you have access

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Where you with Silvia may confer at large,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For she is lumpish, heavy, melancholy,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And, for your friend's sake, will be glad of you,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Where you may temper her by your persuasion

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To hate young Valentine and love my friend.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As much as I can do, I will effect:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But you, Sir Thurio, are not sharp enough,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You must lay lime to tangle her desires

Author: Shakespeare
Text: By wailful sonnets, whose composed rhymes

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Should be full-fraught with serviceable vows.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Much is the force of heaven-bred poesy.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Say that upon the altar of her beauty

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You sacrifice your tears, your sighs, your heart:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Write till your ink be dry, and with your tears

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Moist it again, and frame some feeling line

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That may discover such integrity:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For Orpheus' lute was strung with poets' sinews,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Whose golden touch could soften steel and stones,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Make tigers tame and huge leviathans

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Forsake unsounded deeps to dance on sands.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: After your dire-lamenting elegies,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Visit by night your lady's chamber-window

Author: Shakespeare
Text: With some sweet concert, to their instruments

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Tune a deploring dump: the night's dead silence

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Will well become such sweet-complaining grievance.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: This, or else nothing, will inherit her.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: This discipline shows thou hast been in love.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And thy advice this night I'll put in practise.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Therefore, sweet Proteus, my direction-giver,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Let us into the city presently

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To sort some gentlemen well skill'd in music.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I have a sonnet that will serve the turn

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To give the onset to thy good advice.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: About it, gentlemen!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: We'll wait upon your grace till after supper,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And afterward determine our proceedings.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Even now about it! I will pardon you.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: SCENE I. The frontiers of Mantua. A forest.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter certain Outlaws

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Fellows, stand fast, I see a passenger.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If there be ten, shrink not, but down with 'em.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Stand, sir, and throw us that you have about ye:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If not: we'll make you sit and rifle you.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sir, we are undone, these are the villains

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That all the travellers do fear so much.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My friends,--

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That's not so, sir: we are your enemies.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Peace! we'll hear him.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, by my beard, will we, for he's a proper man.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Then know that I have little wealth to lose:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A man I am cross'd with adversity,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My riches are these poor habiliments,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Of which if you should here disfurnish me,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You take the sum and substance that I have.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Whither travel you?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To Verona.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Whence came you?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: From Milan.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Have you long sojourned there?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Some sixteen months, and longer might have stay'd,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If crooked fortune had not thwarted me.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What, were you banish'd thence?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I was.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For that which now torments me to rehearse:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I kill'd a man, whose death I much repent,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Bu t yet I slew him manfully in fight,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Without false vantage or base treachery.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, ne'er repent it, if it were done so.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But were you banish'd for so small a fault?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I was, and held me glad of such a doom.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Have you the tongues?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My youthful travel therein made me happy,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Or else I often had been miserable.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: By the bare scalp of Robin Hood's fat friar,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: This fellow were a king for our wild faction!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: We'll have him. Sirs, a word.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Master, be one of them, it's an honourable kind of thievery.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Peace, villain!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Tell us this: have you any thing to take to?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Nothing but my fortune.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Know, then, that some of us are gentlemen,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Such as the fury of ungovern'd youth

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thrust from the company of awful men:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Myself was from Verona banished

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For practising to steal away a lady,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: An heir, and near allied unto the duke.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And I from Mantua, for a gentleman,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Who, in my mood, I stabb'd unto the heart.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And I for such like petty crimes as these,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But to the purpose--for we cite our faults,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That they may hold excus'd our lawless lives,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And partly, seeing you are beautified

Author: Shakespeare
Text: With goodly shape and by your own report

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A linguist and a man of such perfection

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As we do in our quality much want--

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Indeed, because you are a banish'd man,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Therefore, above the rest, we parley to you:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Are you content to be our general?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To make a virtue of necessity

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And live, as we do, in this wilderness?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What say'st thou? wilt thou be of our consort?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Say ay, and be the captain of us all:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: We'll do thee homage and be ruled by thee,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Love thee as our commander and our king.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But if thou scorn our courtesy, thou diest.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thou shalt not live to brag what we have offer'd.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I take your offer and will live with you,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Provided that you do no outrages

Author: Shakespeare
Text: On silly women or poor passengers.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: No, we detest such vile base practises.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Come, go with us, we'll bring thee to our crews,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And show thee all the treasure we have got,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Which, with ourselves, all rest at thy dispose.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Already have I been false to Valentine

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And now I must be as unjust to Thurio.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Under the colour of commending him,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I have access my own love to prefer:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But Silvia is too fair, too true, too holy,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To be corrupted with my worthless gifts.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: When I protest true loyalty to her,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: She twits me with my falsehood to my friend,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: When to her beauty I commend my vows,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: She bids me think how I have been forsworn

Author: Shakespeare
Text: In breaking faith with Julia whom I loved:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And notwithstanding all her sudden quips,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The least whereof would quell a lover's hope,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Yet, spaniel-like, the more she spurns my love,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The more it grows and fawneth on her still.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But here comes Thurio: now must we to her window,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And give some evening music to her ear.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter THURIO and Musicians

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How now, Sir Proteus, are you crept before us?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, gentle Thurio: for you know that love

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Will creep in service where it cannot go.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, but I hope, sir, that you love not here.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sir, but I do, or else I would be hence.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Who? Silvia?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, Silvia, for your sake.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I thank you for your own. Now, gentlemen,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Let's tune, and to it lustily awhile.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter, at a distance, Host, and JULIA in boy's clothes

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Now, my young guest, methinks you're allycholly: I

Author: Shakespeare
Text: pray you, why is it?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Marry, mine host, because I cannot be merry.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Come, we'll have you merry: I'll bring you where

Author: Shakespeare
Text: you shall hear music and see the gentleman that you asked for.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But shall I hear him speak?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, that you shall.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That will be music.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Is he among these?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay: but, peace! let's hear 'em.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Who is Silvia? what is she,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That all our swains commend her?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Holy, fair and wise is she,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The heaven such grace did lend her,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That she might admired be.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Is she kind as she is fair?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For beauty lives with kindness.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Love doth to her eyes repair,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To help him of his blindness,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And, being help'd, inhabits there.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Then to Silvia let us sing,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That Silvia is excelling,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: She excels each mortal thing

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Upon the dull earth dwelling:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To her let us garlands bring.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How now! are you sadder than you were before? How

Author: Shakespeare
Text: do you, man? the music likes you not.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You mistake, the musician likes me not.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, my pretty youth?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: He plays false, father.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How? out of tune on the strings?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Not so, but yet so false that he grieves my very

Author: Shakespeare
Text: heart-strings.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You have a quick ear.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, I would I were deaf, it makes me have a slow heart.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I perceive you delight not in music.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Not a whit, when it jars so.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Hark, what fine change is in the music!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, that change is the spite.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You would have them always play but one thing?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I would always have one play but one thing.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But, host, doth this Sir Proteus that we talk on

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Often resort unto this gentlewoman?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I tell you what Launce, his man, told me: he loved

Author: Shakespeare
Text: her out of all nick.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Where is Launce?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Gone to seek his dog, which tomorrow, by his

Author: Shakespeare
Text: master's command, he must carry for a present to his lady.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Peace! stand aside: the company parts.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sir Thurio, fear not you: I will so plead

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That you shall say my cunning drift excels.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Where meet we?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: At Saint Gregory's well.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Exeunt THURIO and Musicians

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter SILVIA above

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter SILVIA above

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Madam, good even to your ladyship.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I thank you for your music, gentlemen.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Who is that that spake?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: One, lady, if you knew his pure heart's truth,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You would quickly learn to know him by his voice.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sir Proteus, as I take it.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sir Proteus, gentle lady, and your servant.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That I may compass yours.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You have your wish, my will is even this:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That presently you hie you home to bed.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thou subtle, perjured, false, disloyal man!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Think'st thou I am so shallow, so conceitless,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To be seduced by thy flattery,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That hast deceived so many with thy vows?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Return, return, and make thy love amends.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For me, by this pale queen of night I swear,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I am so far from granting thy request

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That I despise thee for thy wrongful suit,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And by and by intend to chide myself

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Even for this time I spend in talking to thee.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I grant, sweet love, that I did love a lady,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But she is dead.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: [Aside]        'Twere false, if I should speak it,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For I am sure she is not buried.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Say that she be, yet Valentine thy friend

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Survives, to whom, thyself art witness,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I am betroth'd: and art thou not ashamed

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To wrong him with thy importunacy?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I likewise hear that Valentine is dead.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And so suppose am I, for in his grave

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Assure thyself my love is buried.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sweet lady, let me rake it from the earth.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Go to thy lady's grave and call hers thence,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Or, at the least, in hers sepulchre thine.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: [Aside]  He heard not that.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Madam, if your heart be so obdurate,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Vouchsafe me yet your picture for my love,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The picture that is hanging in your chamber,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To that I'll speak, to that I'll sigh and weep:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For since the substance of your perfect self

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Is else devoted, I am but a shadow,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And to your shadow will I make true love.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: [Aside]  If 'twere a substance, you would, sure,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: deceive it,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And make it but a shadow, as I am.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I am very loath to be your idol, sir,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But since your falsehood shall become you well

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To worship shadows and adore false shapes,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Send to me in the morning and I'll send it:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And so, good rest.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As wretches have o'ernight

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That wait for execution in the morn.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Exeunt PROTEUS and SILVIA severally

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Host, will you go?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: By my halidom, I was fast asleep.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Pray you, where lies Sir Proteus?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Marry, at my house. Trust me, I think 'tis almost

Author: Shakespeare
Text: day.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Not so, but it hath been the longest night

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That e'er I watch'd and the most heaviest.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter EGLAMOUR

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter EGLAMOUR

Author: Shakespeare
Text: This is the hour that Madam Silvia

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Entreated me to call and know her mind:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: There's some great matter she'ld employ me in.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Madam, madam!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Your servant and your friend,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: One that attends your ladyship's command.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sir Eglamour, a thousand times good morrow.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As many, worthy lady, to yourself:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: According to your ladyship's impose,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I am thus early come to know what service

Author: Shakespeare
Text: It is your pleasure to command me in.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O Eglamour, thou art a gentleman--

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Think not I flatter, for I swear I do not--

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Valiant, wise, remorseful, well accomplish'd:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thou art not ignorant what dear good will

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I bear unto the banish'd Valentine,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Nor how my father would enforce me marry

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Vain Thurio, whom my very soul abhors.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thyself hast loved, and I have heard thee say

Author: Shakespeare
Text: No grief did ever come so near thy heart

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As when thy lady and thy true love died,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Upon whose grave thou vow'dst pure chastity.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sir Eglamour, I would to Valentine,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To Mantua, where I hear he makes abode,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And, for the ways are dangerous to pass,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I do desire thy worthy company,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Upon whose faith and honour I repose.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Urge not my father's anger, Eglamour,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But think upon my grief, a lady's grief,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And on the justice of my flying hence,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To keep me from a most unholy match,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Which heaven and fortune still rewards with plagues.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I do desire thee, even from a heart

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As full of sorrows as the sea of sands,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To bear me company and go with me:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If not, to hide what I have said to thee,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That I may venture to depart alone.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Madam, I pity much your grievances,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Which since I know they virtuously are placed,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I give consent to go along with you,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Recking as little what betideth me

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As much I wish all good befortune you.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: When will you go?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: This evening coming.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Where shall I meet you?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: At Friar Patrick's cell,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Where I intend holy confession.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I will not fail your ladyship. Good morrow, gentle lady.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Good morrow, kind Sir Eglamour.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter LAUNCE, with his his Dog

Author: Shakespeare
Text: When a man's servant shall play the cur with him,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: look you, it goes hard: one that I brought up of a

Author: Shakespeare
Text: puppy, one that I saved from drowning, when three or

Author: Shakespeare
Text: four of his blind brothers and sisters went to it.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I have taught him, even as one would say precisely,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'thus I would teach a dog.' I was sent to deliver

Author: Shakespeare
Text: him as a present to Mistress Silvia from my master,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: and I came no sooner into the dining-chamber but he

Author: Shakespeare
Text: steps me to her trencher and steals her capon's leg:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O, 'tis a foul thing when a cur cannot keep himself

Author: Shakespeare
Text: in all companies! I would have, as one should say,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: one that takes upon him to be a dog indeed, to be,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: as it were, a dog at all things. If I had not had

Author: Shakespeare
Text: more wit than he, to take a fault upon me that he did,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I think verily he had been hanged for't, sure as I

Author: Shakespeare
Text: live, he had suffered for't, you shall judge. He

Author: Shakespeare
Text: thrusts me himself into the company of three or four

Author: Shakespeare
Text: gentlemanlike dogs under the duke's table: he had

Author: Shakespeare
Text: not been there--bless the mark!--a pissing while, but

Author: Shakespeare
Text: all the chamber smelt him. 'Out with the dog!' says

Author: Shakespeare
Text: one: 'What cur is that?' says another: 'Whip him

Author: Shakespeare
Text: out' says the third: 'Hang him up' says the duke.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I, having been acquainted with the smell before,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: knew it was Crab, and goes me to the fellow that

Author: Shakespeare
Text: whips the dogs: 'Friend,' quoth I, 'you mean to whip

Author: Shakespeare
Text: the dog?' 'Ay, marry, do I,' quoth he. 'You do him

Author: Shakespeare
Text: the more wrong,' quoth I, ''twas I did the thing you

Author: Shakespeare
Text: wot of.' He makes me no more ado, but whips me out

Author: Shakespeare
Text: of the chamber. How many masters would do this for

Author: Shakespeare
Text: his servant? Nay, I'll be sworn, I have sat in the

Author: Shakespeare
Text: stocks for puddings he hath stolen, otherwise he had

Author: Shakespeare
Text: been executed, I have stood on the pillory for geese

Author: Shakespeare
Text: he hath killed, otherwise he had suffered for't.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thou thinkest not of this now. Nay, I remember the

Author: Shakespeare
Text: trick you served me when I took my leave of Madam

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Silvia: did not I bid thee still mark me and do as I

Author: Shakespeare
Text: do? when didst thou see me heave up my leg and make

Author: Shakespeare
Text: water against a gentlewoman's farthingale? didst

Author: Shakespeare
Text: thou ever see me do such a trick?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sebastian is thy name? I like thee well

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And will employ thee in some service presently.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: In what you please: I'll do what I can.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I hope thou wilt.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To LAUNCE

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How now, you whoreson peasant!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Where have you been these two days loitering?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Marry, sir, I carried Mistress Silvia the dog you bade me.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And what says she to my little jewel?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Marry, she says your dog was a cur, and tells you

Author: Shakespeare
Text: currish thanks is good enough for such a present.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But she received my dog?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: No, indeed, did she not: here have I brought him

Author: Shakespeare
Text: back again.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What, didst thou offer her this from me?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, sir: the other squirrel was stolen from me by

Author: Shakespeare
Text: the hangman boys in the market-place: and then I

Author: Shakespeare
Text: offered her mine own, who is a dog as big as ten of

Author: Shakespeare
Text: yours, and therefore the gift the greater.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Go get thee hence, and find my dog again,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Or ne'er return again into my sight.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Away, I say! stay'st thou to vex me here?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Exit LAUNCE

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A slave, that still an end turns me to shame!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sebastian, I have entertained thee,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Partly that I have need of such a youth

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That can with some discretion do my business,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For 'tis no trusting to yond foolish lout,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But chiefly for thy face and thy behavior,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Which, if my augury deceive me not,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Witness good bringing up, fortune and truth:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Therefore know thou, for this I entertain thee.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Go presently and take this ring with thee,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Deliver it to Madam Silvia:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: She loved me well deliver'd it to me.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: It seems you loved not her, to leave her token.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: She is dead, belike?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Not so, I think she lives.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why dost thou cry 'alas'?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I cannot choose

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But pity her.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Wherefore shouldst thou pity her?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Because methinks that she loved you as well

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As you do love your lady Silvia:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: She dreams of him that has forgot her love,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You dote on her that cares not for your love.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Tis pity love should be so contrary,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And thinking of it makes me cry 'alas!'

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Well, give her that ring and therewithal

Author: Shakespeare
Text: This letter. That's her chamber. Tell my lady

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I claim the promise for her heavenly picture.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Your message done, hie home unto my chamber,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Where thou shalt find me, sad and solitary.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How many women would do such a message?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Alas, poor Proteus! thou hast entertain'd

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A fox to be the shepherd of thy lambs.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Alas, poor fool! why do I pity him

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That with his very heart despiseth me?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Because he loves her, he despiseth me,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Because I love him I must pity him.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: This ring I gave him when he parted from me,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To bind him to remember my good will,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And now am I, unhappy messenger,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To plead for that which I would not obtain,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To carry that which I would have refused,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To praise his faith which I would have dispraised.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I am my master's true-confirmed love,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But cannot be true servant to my master,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Unless I prove false traitor to myself.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Yet will I woo for him, but yet so coldly

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As, heaven it knows, I would not have him speed.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter SILVIA, attended

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Gentlewoman, good day! I pray you, be my mean

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To bring me where to speak with Madam Silvia.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What would you with her, if that I be she?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If you be she, I do entreat your patience

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To hear me speak the message I am sent on.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: From whom?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: From my master, Sir Proteus, madam.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O, he sends you for a picture.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ursula, bring my picture here.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Go give your master this: tell him from me,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: One Julia, that his changing thoughts forget,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Would better fit his chamber than this shadow.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Madam, please you peruse this letter.--

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Pardon me, madam, I have unadvised

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Deliver'd you a paper that I should not:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: This is the letter to your ladyship.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I pray thee, let me look on that again.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: It may not be, good madam, pardon me.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: There, hold!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I will not look upon your master's lines:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I know they are stuff'd with protestations

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And full of new-found oaths, which he will break

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As easily as I do tear his paper.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Madam, he sends your ladyship this ring.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The more shame for him that he sends it me,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For I have heard him say a thousand times

Author: Shakespeare
Text: His Julia gave it him at his departure.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Though his false finger have profaned the ring,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Mine shall not do his Julia so much wrong.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: She thanks you.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I thank you, madam, that you tender her.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Poor gentlewoman! my master wrongs her much.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Dost thou know her?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Almost as well as I do know myself:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To think upon her woes I do protest

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That I have wept a hundred several times.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Belike she thinks that Proteus hath forsook her.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I think she doth, and that's her cause of sorrow.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Is she not passing fair?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: She hath been fairer, madam, than she is:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: When she did think my master loved her well,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: She, in my judgment, was as fair as you:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But since she did neglect her looking-glass

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And threw her sun-expelling mask away,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The air hath starved the roses in her cheeks

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And pinch'd the lily-tincture of her face,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That now she is become as black as I.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How tall was she?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: About my stature, for at Pentecost,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: When all our pageants of delight were play'd,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Our youth got me to play the woman's part,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And I was trimm'd in Madam Julia's gown,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Which served me as fit, by all men's judgments,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As if the garment had been made for me:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Therefore I know she is about my height.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And at that time I made her weep agood,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For I did play a lamentable part:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Madam, 'twas Ariadne passioning

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For Theseus' perjury and unjust flight,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Which I so lively acted with my tears

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That my poor mistress, moved therewithal,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Wept bitterly, and would I might be dead

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If I in thought felt not her very sorrow!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: She is beholding to thee, gentle youth.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Alas, poor lady, desolate and left!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I weep myself to think upon thy words.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Here, youth, there is my purse, I give thee this

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For thy sweet mistress' sake, because thou lovest her.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Exit SILVIA, with attendants

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And she shall thank you for't, if e'er you know her.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A virtuous gentlewoman, mild and beautiful

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I hope my master's suit will be but cold,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Since she respects my mistress' love so much.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Alas, how love can trifle with itself!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Here is her picture: let me see, I think,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If I had such a tire, this face of mine

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Were full as lovely as is this of hers:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And yet the painter flatter'd her a little,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Unless I flatter with myself too much.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Her hair is auburn, mine is perfect yellow:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If that be all the difference in his love,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I'll get me such a colour'd periwig.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Her eyes are grey as glass, and so are mine:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, but her forehead's low, and mine's as high.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What should it be that he respects in her

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But I can make respective in myself,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If this fond Love were not a blinded god?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Come, shadow, come and take this shadow up,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For 'tis thy rival. O thou senseless form,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thou shalt be worshipp'd, kiss'd, loved and adored!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And, were there sense in his idolatry,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My substance should be statue in thy stead.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I'll use thee kindly for thy mistress' sake,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That used me so, or else, by Jove I vow,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I should have scratch'd out your unseeing eyes

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To make my master out of love with thee!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: SCENE I. Milan. An abbey.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The sun begins to gild the western sky,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And now it is about the very hour

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That Silvia, at Friar Patrick's cell, should meet me.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: She will not fail, for lovers break not hours,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Unless it be to come before their time,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: So much they spur their expedition.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: See where she comes.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Lady, a happy evening!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Amen, amen! Go on, good Eglamour,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Out at the postern by the abbey-wall:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I fear I am attended by some spies.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Fear not: the forest is not three leagues off,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If we recover that, we are sure enough.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter THURIO, PROTEUS, and JULIA

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Sir Proteus, what says Silvia to my suit?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O, sir, I find her milder than she was,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And yet she takes exceptions at your person.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What, that my leg is too long?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: No, that it is too little.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I'll wear a boot, to make it somewhat rounder.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: [Aside]  But love will not be spurr'd to what

Author: Shakespeare
Text: it loathes.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What says she to my face?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: She says it is a fair one.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Nay then, the wanton lies, my face is black.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But pearls are fair, and the old saying is,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Black men are pearls in beauteous ladies' eyes.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: [Aside]  'Tis true, such pearls as put out

Author: Shakespeare
Text: ladies' eyes,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For I had rather wink than look on them.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How likes she my discourse?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ill, when you talk of war.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But well, when I discourse of love and peace?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: [Aside]  But better, indeed, when you hold your peace.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What says she to my valour?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O, sir, she makes no doubt of that.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: [Aside]  She needs not, when she knows it cowardice.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What says she to my birth?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That you are well derived.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: [Aside]  True, from a gentleman to a fool.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Considers she my possessions?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O, ay, and pities them.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: [Aside]  That such an ass should owe them.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That they are out by lease.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Here comes the duke.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: How now, Sir Proteus! how now, Thurio!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Which of you saw Sir Eglamour of late?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Saw you my daughter?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why then,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: She's fled unto that peasant Valentine,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And Eglamour is in her company.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Tis true, for Friar Laurence met them both,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As he in penance wander'd through the forest,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Him he knew well, and guess'd that it was she,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But, being mask'd, he was not sure of it,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Besides, she did intend confession

Author: Shakespeare
Text: At Patrick's cell this even, and there she was not,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: These likelihoods confirm her flight from hence.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Therefore, I pray you, stand not to discourse,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But mount you presently and meet with me

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Upon the rising of the mountain-foot

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That leads towards Mantua, whither they are fled:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Dispatch, sweet gentlemen, and follow me.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Why, this it is to be a peevish girl,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That flies her fortune when it follows her.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I'll after, more to be revenged on Eglamour

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Than for the love of reckless Silvia.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And I will follow, more for Silvia's love

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Than hate of Eglamour that goes with her.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And I will follow, more to cross that love

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Than hate for Silvia that is gone for love.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: SCENE III. The frontiers of Mantua. The forest.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Enter Outlaws with SILVIA

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Be patient, we must bring you to our captain.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A thousand more mischances than this one

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Have learn'd me how to brook this patiently.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Come, bring her away.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Where is the gentleman that was with her?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Being nimble-footed, he hath outrun us,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But Moyses and Valerius follow him.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Go thou with her to the west end of the wood,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: There is our captain: we'll follow him that's fled,

Author: Shakespeare

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I pray thee, good Camillo, be no more importunate:

Author: Shakespeare

Author: Shakespeare

Text: sorrows I might be some allay, or I o'erween to

Text: As thou lovest me, Camillo, wipe not out the rest of

Author: Shakespeare

Text: son? Kings are no less unhappy, their issue not

Text: Sir, it is three days since I saw the prince. What

Author: Shakespeare
Text: his happier affairs may be, are to me unknown: but I

Author: Shakespeare

Author: Shakespeare

Author: Shakespeare

Author: Shakespeare

Author: Shakespeare
Text: lay aside the thoughts of Sicilia.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I willingly obey your command.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My best Camillo! We must disguise ourselves.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As now it coldly stands, when first I woo'd her!

Text: I am ashamed: does not the stone rebuke me

Text: For being more stone than it? O royal piece,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My evils conjured to remembrance and

Author: Shakespeare
Text: From thy admiring daughter took the spirits,

Text: And give me leave,

Text: I kneel and then implore her blessing. Lady,

Author: Shakespeare

Text: Give me that hand of yours to kiss.

Text: O, patience!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The statue is but newly fix'd, the colour's Not dry.

Text: My lord, your sorrow was too sore laid on,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Which sixteen winters cannot blow away,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: So many summers dry, scarce any joy

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Did ever so long live, no sorrow

Text: But kill'd itself much sooner.

Text: Dear my brother,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Let him that was the cause of this have power

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To take off so much grief from you as he

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Will piece up in himself.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If I had thought the sight of my poor image

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Would thus have wrought you,--for the stone is mine--

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I'ld not have show'd it.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Do not draw the curtain.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: No longer shall you gaze on't, lest your fancy

Author: Shakespeare
Text: May think anon it moves.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Let be, let be.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Would I were dead, but that, methinks, already--

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What was he that did make it? See, my lord,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Would you not deem it breathed? and that those veins

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Did verily bear blood?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Masterly done:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The very life seems warm upon her lip.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The fixture of her eye has motion in't,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As we are mock'd with art.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I'll draw the curtain:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My lord's almost so far transported that

Author: Shakespeare
Text: He'll think anon it lives.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O sweet Paulina,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Make me to think so twenty years together!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: No settled senses of the world can match

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The pleasure of that madness. Let 't alone.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I am sorry, sir, I have thus far stirr'd you: but

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I could afflict you farther.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Do, Paulina,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For this affliction has a taste as sweet

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As any cordial comfort. Still, methinks,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: There is an air comes from her: what fine chisel

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Could ever yet cut breath? Let no man mock me,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For I will kiss her.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Good my lord, forbear:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: The ruddiness upon her lip is wet,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You'll mar it if you kiss it, stain your own

Author: Shakespeare
Text: With oily painting. Shall I draw the curtain?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: No, not these twenty years.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: So long could I

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Stand by, a looker on.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Either forbear,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Quit presently the chapel, or resolve you

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For more amazement. If you can behold it,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I'll make the statue move indeed, descend

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And take you by the hand, but then you'll think--

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Which I protest against--I am assisted

Author: Shakespeare
Text: By wicked powers.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: What you can make her do,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I am content to look on: what to speak,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I am content to hear, for 'tis as easy

Author: Shakespeare
Text: To make her speak as move.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: It is required

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You do awake your faith. Then all stand still,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: On: those that think it is unlawful business

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I am about, let them depart.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Proceed:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: No foot shall stir.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Music, awake her, strike!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: 'Tis time, descend, be stone no more, approach,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Strike all that look upon with marvel. Come,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: I'll fill your grave up: stir, nay, come away,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Bequeath to death your numbness, for from him

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Dear life redeems you. You perceive she stirs:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: HERMIONE comes down

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Start not, her actions shall be holy as

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You hear my spell is lawful: do not shun her

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Until you see her die again, for then

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You kill her double. Nay, present your hand:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: When she was young you woo'd her, now in age

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Is she become the suitor?

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O, she's warm!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If this be magic, let it be an art

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Lawful as eating.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: She embraces him.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: She hangs about his neck:

Author: Shakespeare
Text: If she pertain to life let her speak too.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Ay, and make't manifest where she has lived,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Or how stolen from the dead.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That she is living,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Were it but told you, should be hooted at

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Like an old tale: but it appears she lives,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Though yet she speak not. Mark a little while.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Please you to interpose, fair madam: kneel

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And pray your mother's blessing. Turn, good lady,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Our Perdita is found.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You gods, look down

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And from your sacred vials pour your graces

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Upon my daughter's head! Tell me, mine own.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Where hast thou been preserved? where lived? how found

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thy father's court? for thou shalt hear that I,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Knowing by Paulina that the oracle

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Gave hope thou wast in being, have preserved

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Myself to see the issue.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: There's time enough for that,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Lest they desire upon this push to trouble

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Your joys with like relation. Go together,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: You precious winners all, your exultation

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Partake to every one. I, an old turtle,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Will wing me to some wither'd bough and there

Author: Shakespeare
Text: My mate, that's never to be found again,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Lament till I am lost.

Author: Shakespeare
Text: O, peace, Paulina!

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Thou shouldst a husband take by my consent,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As I by thine a wife: this is a match,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And made between's by vows. Thou hast found mine,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: But how, is to be question'd, for I saw her,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: As I thought, dead, and have in vain said many

Author: Shakespeare
Text: A prayer upon her grave. I'll not seek far--

Author: Shakespeare
Text: For him, I partly know his mind--to find thee

Author: Shakespeare
Text: An honourable husband. Come, Camillo,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: And take her by the hand, whose worth and honesty

Author: Shakespeare
Text: Is richly noted and here justified

Author: Shakespeare
Text: By us, a pair of kings. Let's from this place.

Text: What! look upon my brother: both your pardons,

Author: Shakespeare
Text: That e'er I put between your holy looks

Text: My ill suspicion. This is your son-in-law,

Text: And son unto the king, who, heavens directing,

Text: Is troth-plight to your daughter. Good Paulina,

Text: Each one demand an answer to his part

Text: Perform'd in this wide gap of time since first

Text: We were dissever'd: hastily lead away.

Author: Trump
Text: Thank you. Thank you. Thank you to Vice President Pence. He's a good guy. We've done a great job together. And Merry Christmas, Michigan. Thank you, Michigan. What a victory we had in Michigan. What a victory was that. One of the greats. Was that the greatest evening? But I'm thrilled to be here with thousands of hardworking patriots as we celebrate the miracle of Christmas, the greatness of America and the glory of God. Thank you very much. And did you notice that everybody is saying Merry Christmas again? Did you notice? Saying Merry Christmas. I remember when I first started this beautiful trip, this beautiful journey, I just said to the First Lady, "You are so lucky. I took you on this fantastic journey. It's so much fun. They want to impeach you. They want to do worse than that." By the way, by the way, by the way, it doesn't really feel like we're being impeached. The country is doing better than ever before. We did nothing wrong. We did nothing wrong. And we have tremendous support in the Republican Party like we've never had before. Nobody's ever had this kind of support. But this sacred season, our country is thriving and it's thriving truly like it has never, it has never happened before to the extent what's happening now. And by the way, your state, because of us, not because of local government, but because of us, because of the job that we've done. Because I understand she's not fixing those potholes. That's what the word is. It was all about roads and they want to raise those gasoline taxes on you. We don't want to do that. But she's not fixing the potholes. But Michigan's had the best year it's ever had. Best year it's ever had. And that's because we have auto companies expanding and thriving and they're coming in from Japan and they're coming in from a lot of other places. Look what's happening. And you know, I don't know if you know this, but probably 10 years ago I was honored. I was the Man Of The Year by I think somebody, whoever. I was the Man Of The Year in Michigan. Can you believe it? Long time. And that was long before I ever decided to do this. I was happy. I had a beautiful life. What the hell did I do this for? But look how we're doing. Do we love it? I love it. But anyway, I was the Man Of The Year and probably close to 10 years ago and I came to Michigan. He said, "You're still the Man Of The Year." Thank you. Who said that? Thank you. So I came in and I remember the speech so well. I said, "Why are you allowing them to steal your car companies? Why are you allowing them to go to Mexico and to go from China where they come in from China, they build them in China, they sell them into our country with no tax and you lose your jobs, you lose your factories, the companies leave and you get nothing. Why are they lying?" I asked that a long time ago and we stopped it. We've stopped it. And you see that. And we just made the USMCA. We're getting rid of NAFTA, which I think is the worst trade deal ever. And it's very exciting. It's a great deal. It's a great deal. It's going to stop exactly what we were just talking about. It makes it very, very prohibitive. They can do it, but they've got to pay a hell of a big price to do it. And history has proven that stops them. But we have a great USMCA that we negotiated with Mexico, with Canada. Now, from the standpoint of the farmers, you know what's going on. We had tremendous trade barriers in Canada. We had attacks on dairy products, 297% tariff, nobody talked about it, with Canada. And we had some really bad things with Mexico. We now have a wonderful deal. And if we didn't have a good deal, you know what I would have done what? What? I would have put tariffs on both countries and that would have been it, right? That would have been it. Unfortunately the deal's been sitting with Nancy Pelosi for a long time and what happened? And she had a lot of pressure, especially from manufacturing areas, farm areas, a lot of pressure to sign it. So here's what happens. So I get along with labor. I had a lot of union labor vote for me, tremendous amount of labor. In New York where I come from, we have a lot of unions. And that's okay. That's fine. So we left a little stuff for the union because we figured to get it signed, we'll give a little bit and we did it and we have one great deal. And now you have the Democrats trying to take credit for this deal and that's okay. Whatever it takes. For seven months, it sits. They don't do anything. We give. And by the way, I spoke to the unions the day before I say, "Fellows, you got to get it done." And union labor loves me and I love you too sir. I love you too sir. So we have a great deal with Mexico, with Canada. And it is true. I say it out loud because I say it to them right now. If they ever wanted to break the deal, that's okay. If somebody wants to break a deal with me, you always have to have an alternative, right? And this country, the deals we made, we did a deal with South Korea. That's great. We did a deal with Japan, 40 billion dollar deal with Japan. It was just a little piece of a deal. Okay? That was a piece of a deal. And I said to Japan, "Look, you got to make this deal or we're going to put a 20% tariff on the cars. And that's more money than anything we're talking about." That's all right. That's all right. That's all right. Get her out. Ger her out of here. Oh well. You're about to hear the greatest speech you've ever heard. And that's going to be the publicity because all the fake news back there will say massive riot… Massive riots. Fake news. But seriously, look, look, look, they won't say it. They won't say it, because when we have protesters all in favor, they don't talk about it, but there's a slob. There's a real slob. Wait, wait a minute. She'll get hell when she gets back home with mom. But she made… Look, she screams a little bit. And you know what I like to do? Avoid them. Because I'll tell you the big problem. I could hardly hear her. What happens is all of you people go crazy. Look, look, look, and the place. Okay, so there's one disgusting person who made… Wait, wait, who made a… I wouldn't say this, but made a horrible gesture with the wrong finger right? Now they won't say that, the fake news, they won't say it. If one of us did that, it would be like the biggest story ever. I think it's terrible. And I'll tell you the other thing, I don't know who the security company is, but the police came up, but they want to be so politically correct so they don't grab her wrist lightly and get her out. They say, "Oh, would you please come? Would you please come with me?" Sure. "Ma'am, would you?" And then she gives the guy the finger and he, "Oh, Oh." You got to get a little bit stronger than that, folks. And they… . Making another group of tariffs, seven and a half percent. This gives us a lot of currency to do the phase two deal, which they want to start, but we're taking in billions of dollars and to help the farmers who were targeted, 16 billion and 12 billion the previous year, helps the farmers. So you know what we do, out of that big check that we get, all that money flows into the treasury. Out of the big check, we gave the farmers 16 billion dollars and 12 billion for the previous year. And you know, the incredible thing, and I was with a lot of farmers. I was with a group of 36 farmers at the White House. You know what they said to me? I said, "Don't worry about it. We're going to take care of you guys." And I used a bad word. You know what word I used? We're going to get you a subsidy. And they said this two years ago, I said, "How much were you targeted for?" This was the first year. "12 billion, sir." The second year was 16. They were target. That's what they didn't get from China. So I said, "It's all right, we're going to give you a subsidy of the same and we're going to take it out of the tariffs and we're going to have billions and billions of dollars left over." And they said, "Sir, we don't want money. We just want a level playing field." I've never seen that before. I've never seen that before. So we will have invested in our military, since I'm here, which is less than three years. Our military, by the way, in all due respect to the previous two administrations, our military was depleted. It was depleted. It was in bad shape. We had fighter jets that were 35 years old. We had planes that were 60 years… You heard where the father flew them, the grandfather flew them, and now the young son comes in. We've got the best equipment in the world now. Spent two and a half trillion dollars, made in the USA. Two and a half trillion. We will shortly. That'll be all finished. We're going to have the greatest… Now we have the best planes. We're going to have the best ships. We're building a lot of ships now. We're building the most powerful weapons in the world. Now, we don't want to even talk about it. We never want to use them. But you know, the way we're not going to have to use them is if we have them. We're building submarines, the power of which nobody's ever seen before. Nobody's ever seen before. It's funny, we have these companies come in. I like to make good deals. You like to make good deals. That's what we do, right? So these really countries that come in, prime ministers, presidents, sometimes dictators, those we can't deal with too much. "Sir, we'd like to buy a nuclear submarine." I say, "No thanks." I turn them all down. You have no idea how many people… But we're building some of the… They're the most powerful weapons ever made by man or womankind. I say mankind and womankind. They can definitely fight. They're the real deal. These guys, so good looking. I said, "You could be a movie star. Go to Hollywood." "No sir. I like doing what I'm doing." So I said to these guys, you going to see, just like central casting, I said, I said, "Fellas, how good is this plane?" They said, "Sir, it's great." "Why?" "Because the enemy can't see it." That helps. Stealth. It's actually called super stealth. So I said, "You mean they can't see, so you shoot at them but they can't…" He said, "They have no idea where we are, sir." I said, "That sounds good to me." Nobody does it. Nobody can do it. We have the whole thing and we bought in a lot of those planes, we bought in a lot of great stuff. And I won't tell you the story, but very early on I thought we were going to have a problem someplace, and one of the generals came up to me and said, "Sir, don't go. Don't do it." "Why?" "We don't have the ammunition." And I said two things. I never want to hear a President. Right? We never want to have a President hear that again, nor do we want a President to have to go through the crap that we were going through back then. But, another thing we did, which to me is such an incredible thing to have done. It's such an honor. So our last US Armed Forces, the last branch was the Air Force, right? That was many, many decades ago. We are now building and we have now gotten funding for the sixth branch of the United States Armed Forces, The Space Force. So I'll be able to tell my kids someday and everybody else, "See that Space Force? That was my baby." And you think that was easy? That's not easy. Because you have Democrats that do not like our military. They do not like our military. And we did something yesterday, because for three years I would see people that run… Incredible people, the heads of the Historically Black Colleges and Universities in the country. And every year they'd come in and they'd be looking for help. They needed help and they do need help with it and it's great and they do an incredible job. So many great schools, but they need help. And every year they'd have to come and come. I got to know them actually. I said, "The only bad thing is you won't see me too much anymore." Because we just provided record funding for a nation's Historically Black Colleges and Universities. And it's longterm, they're not going to have to come. So I said, "Look, we could do it where we do it every year or we'll do what we have. What do you want?" They said, "Let us just have it." So we'll miss them. But they are great people. They've done an incredible job. And our extraordinary jobs boom, which created another 266,000 jobs last month, and then you add the undercount from the previous two months, you're close to 300,000 jobs. And they said, if you're a business watcher which I am, I love watching business, but they said they were guessing, could be 70,000, could be 80,000, maybe 90, maybe 110, somebody said. Then the number comes out, 266,000 with an adjustment. Remember about four months ago when we had one little period, right? We had one little period where there was a little downturn. They said, "Oh, Oh, we think we're going into a recession." I said, "Don't worry about it." "We think we're going into a recession." They were willing to lose their wealth. They were willing for this stocks and whatever the hell they own, what do you guys own back there? Let it go. They'll go bust. They don't care. Anything to get rid of us. Not me, us. And you know what? Then all of a sudden, and now for the last couple of weeks, we've set brand new records in the history of the various stock markets. So, as of yesterday, we've had 133 record days in the stock market now, and that's in less than three years. So when I see that I don't care because I don't… I'm not allowed to have stock. I can't have stock. They consider it a conflict of interest and that I can understand. I agree. I can. But you know what? I'll tell you what. What I see, I see tremendous job growth because we're setting records. But you know what I also see? The 401ks where people are up 90%, they're up 97%, they're up 82%. I tell you the story all the time. I mean, I have people coming up to me, and a man came up, a policeman. I've told this story, but I've had many, so many times, but this guy in particular, because it was early and that was a year ago. That was a long time ago. Right now it's much higher than that. But he said, "Sir, I want to thank you. My wife thinks I'm a loser. All my life, we never did well with the 401ks, with stocks. Everything I invested, I'm up 72%, sir. She thinks I'm a financial genius. She's so in love with me. She so in love." He said, "She said, ‘Darling, I think you're one of the greatest investors. Why don't you do this professionally?' And I don't even know what I'm doing, sir. I just have all these stocks." So I just wanted to tell you, I look at a 401k, who has 401ks here? So that's what I see. I don't care about the rich ones. I care about everybody. I care. I care about everybody actually. Ford motor company just announced that it is investing 1.5 billion dollars into auto factories in the Detroit area, creating another 3000 Michigan jobs. And that's on top of the many other investments we've gotten from Japanese companies, car companies, and other companies. But they're all coming in and a lot of them are coming to Michigan. And I say, "Hey, go to Michigan." Sometimes they'll go south and that's okay, whatever. I want them in this country. But ideally I want to fill them up. We're doing so well in Michigan with the auto companies. Now you're back. You're back. So, you're back. Very proud of you. Very proud of you. But while we're creating jobs, fighting for Michigan workers, and achieving numbers that you've never seen before, incredible victories for the American people are happening. The radical left in Congress is consumed with hatred and envy and rage. You see what's going on? I'll tell you, these people are crazy. You ever hear, "It's the economy, stupid." You know that was Clinton's saying. If you have a good economy. I have the greatest economy in the history of this country and nobody talks about it. Nobody talks about it. If you're a Democrat, they say, " Oh, it's the economy…" If the economy's any good. And let me just tell you a little secret. If crooked Hillary would've won, your economy would have crashed. You were going down. The regulations were taking it down. The taxes were taking it down, instead of being up 92% or whatever you're up, a lot, you would have been down, you would have been at less than half. It was crashing. For all those people that would say, "Oh, it's the Obama…" Let me tell you something. You were dying. And if you look at that first period of a couple of months, it was a disaster, but it was heading south. And as sure as you're standing, and I'm sorry we couldn't get you seats, we didn't have any room. And by the way, 20,000 people outside had to leave. You know? It's so cold outside we told them, "Don't worry about a screen, go home, go home and watch." But we had, this is about a 5,500 seat arena. And I said to my people, "Why so small?" Are we spoiled? I watch these guys come in like Biden, he has a big rally and they get 93 people show up. No, it's true. I don't understand it. And did you see the new polls from USA Today came out? I'm killing everybody. And they hate me. USA Today hates me. But there's a poll, we're beating everybody. But, so Biden has this rally, they've got 200 seats, but only a small number of people. So you know what they do? They set up a round table. So think of these people. They come in, they think they're going to listen to the speech, they end up sitting on a round table discussing… They must've been happy, right? We don't have enough room for round tables. I'm sorry folks. No, they set up a round table but I think we're doing great. And how do you beat what we've done? With the economy, with our great vets, with choice. You've finally got choice. They've been trying to get it for almost 50 years. Four more years. Four more years. Four more years. Four more years. Four more years. Four more years. And these people back here? Your seat or stand is better. Right? But you know what? They're going to be much more famous because the cameras can't see you. They can only see them. And the other thing, the cameras, do you ever notice, I go to these stadiums, 25, 30,000 people. They never show the crowd. You know why? Because they don't want to have… If crazy Pocahontas, if crazy Pocahontas goes to the middle of Central Park or whatever. She's in Manhattan. You got me. And people, I mean, I could have, I could have Baron Trump go into Central Park and he'd get a crowd that would be just as… He's 13. He'd get a bigger crowd. But if she has the crowd, "Oh, these crowds are so big." I've had crowds over the last couple of weeks. We went to different Pennsylvania, Florida. But I mean thousands and thousands of people can't get into these NBA arenas, right? Big arenas. And we set records at everyone because we use the floor. Thank you. I appreciate it. But we use the floor, right? The basketball court. So we set records at every arena. They never even mention the crowds. They never mention the crowds. It's sort of amazing. You know what? I don't think we've ever had an empty seat from the time I came down the escalator. That's a long time ago. I don't think we've ever had an empty seat. Now what the crooked media does though, if you got like over here, look how packed it is and there's thousands outside, but I… "Please go home. You're going to catch pneumonia." But here's the thing. If this man and that beautiful woman happened to get up because they want to go to the bathroom, those cameras will turn to those two seats and they'll say "Trump wasn't able to fill up the arena." I always get nervous when I see some… I know they're coming back. Nobody ever leaves our speeches. Because is there a better place to be in the world than a Trump rally? But every time I see a man get up, I see a beautiful woman with a baby and they're getting up. The baby's going crazy and they're getting up. They're going to take it… But I know they're going to be right back. And I say, "Fill those two seats. I don't want them to see it." Because they'll say, "Couldn't fill up the arena." These are truly dishonest people. After three years of sinister witch hunts, hoaxes, scams, tonight the House Democrats are trying to nullify the ballots of tens of millions of patriotic Americans. Capped off with one of the greatest election evenings in history. Was that the greatest? Remember when they all said, remember when they all said, "No, no. You can't win Michigan. You can't." Then I went, I did one in Grand Rapids, right? Grand Rapids. We had 32,000 people that night. It was one o'clock in the morning. That means it was Election Day when I started speaking. Hillary, Barack Obama, Michelle Obama, and Bill Clinton, they did an emergency trip. They did an emergency trip to Michigan at six o'clock. They got here at prime time. They started to speak. She had 500 people. I got here at one o'clock in the morning the next day, which is now Election Day. How many people were there? 32,000 people outside, inside. It was the last speech of Michigan. And they say, "Well, sir, it's very hard to win Michigan." I said, "Why would it be hard?" Here's the beautiful thing. Everything I told you I've done, but much more so.
